full_transcript: hi everyone Anthony Fantana here intranets busiest music nerd and it's time for a review of the new aghia and the Stooges record ready to die Iggy and the Stooges Detroit based band Iggy Pop frontman one of rock music's original badasses van has three seminal records under their belts they are bloody they're dirty they're filthy they're earned the band lived fast and they're very abrupt break up in the mid 70s reflected that because for their time there was very little about their brand of rock music that felt civilized and I would say that this energy that the band would put into their music really paid off in some long-term dividends because just the guts that they laid out in their records like raw power in funhaus have withstood the test of time and feel just as high-octane today as I'm sure they did back then after the demise of the band there were some post Stooges musical projects to take note of that were pretty great like Ron Ashton's destroy all monsters and Iggy Pop as well had a pretty successful solo career with a handful of grey records he mellowed out a little bit musically but not in a bad way he put out some interesting post-punk stuff some art rock stuff he got a little more adventurous past his Stooges material and put out quite a few records in the 80s and 90s but the 2000s saw these Stooges actually reforming for live performances with mike watt from the Minutemen playing bass and this performing in the band's popularity just kind of getting going again led to the result of a new studio album the band's first studio album in decades the weirdness in 2007 Steve Albini produced it and in my opinion this record easily one of the most tragic studio recording comebacks a band has ever made I mean literally so tragic that the band and its label literally omitted the existence of this album out from the press release for this new LP saying this album is like a direct release after rock power really the raw power on the weirdness was gone the band's intensity was just replaced with very terrible lyrics my idea of fun is killing everyone and these lyrics were delivered with vocals that really really lacked ferocity and the guitars really kind of lacked ferocity to just didn't have the guts that they used to back in the day to me there was just a certain tameness to their new sound on this record the Stooges were sounding like the groomed and commodified version of what wild rock music is sold as today as opposed to what it was when the Stooges were playing now with this latest record ready to die which unfortunately comes after the passing of Ron Ashton we have round two essentially this comeback and I have to say admittedly the Stooges are sounding a little gutsy er than they did on their previous full-length they are completely missing the mark the band still has their very Garage sound songs like dirty deal have a very fast energetic riff pretty solid solo as well but that desperation that just being pushed to the edge feel of the Stooges music is just still not on this record it's still not on this recording I mean I I can't express I can't put it into words just that that feeling of like my life depends on this music existing that vibe is not on here for sure this record is not really an insult to their legacy in the way that the weirdness was but essentially you're just getting a lot of wild garage rock tracks here that do not feel that wild and a few of them especially tracks like beat that guy that experiment with strings and background vocals venture into territory that has never really been the Stooges strong point so I'm just wondering why they're even going down this road to begin with there are some tracks on here that have lyrics that make me cry and cringe like the song job I got a job and it don't pay they're just the moments where he pops words just are too obnoxious for words to be completely honest and his voice it's it's like him and the band are really worried about how it sounds at all whether or not it's just underwhelming during a point that is I guess shooting for something high energy or just warbling awkwardly or just off-pitch on some of the moments where it seems like the band is pulling together something a little more ballad like I do think the guitars overall on this album are better they're more ferocious it's more nasty that's just showing those canines and as far as guitars and drums locking together and making a groove just making a tough-ass vibe songs like Dee Dee's dirty deal or ready to die these songs really have their stuff together and the song gun 2 is pretty good as far as guitars and drums go but there's so many tracks on this album I feel like would have gone over so much better if agiza vocals weren't so just a flat overall I did think this album was a step up from the weirdness however that doesn't necessarily mean that I enjoyed it though there were some bright spots coming out of the guitars and the drums together I didn't really care for the vocals I'm not a single song there were some tracks that I didn't really care for the mix either or it felt like the guitars were turned up so high I can really appreciate much of anything else in the mix and like I mentioned toward the beginning of this review there were songs on you were seeing like Iggy and the Stooges were experimenting with some softer ideas that I just don't really think went over all that well I'm really feeling a light two decent four on this thing if you've given it a listen what did you think of it did you love it did you hate it why what do you think I should review next and that's it Anthony Fantana Iggy and the Stooges forever

something hi everyone Anthony Fantana here the Internet's yes music nerd and it's time for a review of new Colin Stetson album new history warfare vol 3 Colin Stetson is a Canadian saxophone player and he has been quite the buzz over the past few years in jazz and experimental music circles but he has sort of an indie music appeal as well of course his last full-length album was also recorded at the infamous hotel to tango which has been home to many a great Canadian artists such as silver Mount Zion Orchestra and Godspeed you black Emperor on top of that Colin is actually toured a little bit with God speed too and while all of these connections have brought Colin a lot of visibility nothing is quite as attention-grabbing as this man's performances his live performances and just his musical style in general when it comes to playing the saxophone really no matter what the size this man is a machine and the man's albums in this new history warfare music series basically consists of these one take saxophone pieces that flutter and howl endlessly thanks to Colin's continuous breathing techniques making us a never really needs to stop playing not only are Colin's technical abilities really impressive but to take it even further his music has been recorded in some really interesting ways too with some very strange mic placements that not only pick up his breathing the saxophone as well the notes that it's making and the sounds of the valves on the saxophones opening and closing creating kind of a rhythmic background for the melodic side of these pieces that Colin is writing these have basically been the main characteristics of this new history warfare series and from what I understand this is going to be the last installment of it and I wouldn't say the Colin is ducking out prematurely or anything like that he does create music on this album that does have a sense of finality here there are a lot of tracks on this album that to me feel like very sentimental feel like a hug goodbye Colin takes a lot of the very obtuse and polarizing saxophone experiments that he indulged in on his previous two album and tries to interpret and express them in a way that feels beautiful Colin creates moments on the south and they feel like a new day some kind of ascension like I'm listening to an emotional wake-up call just some reminder that my heart is beating and that my lungs are pushing out air it's time to just stop walking through life as a stone-faced drone and just feel something there's just something about the way that the Stetson he blends very simple with very complicated ideas in his solo sax pieces from his endlessly evolving saxophone arpeggios and runs up and down a spectrum of pitches and how he has these howls coming out from his throat in the background sort of like this very eerie crying voice in the distance that is muffled by the sax Reed jammed in his mouth and also on this album singer/songwriter Justin Vernon aka Bone Iver comes along and contributes vocals on a number of tracks here helping to enhance that sentimental vibe that Colin was going for on a lot of these tracks however there are moments where I feel like Justin's version of sentimental and Colin's version of sentimental might not necessarily I guess mesh like the opening track on this LP and in truth where Justin is singing in his trademark falsetto multi-tracked soaring over Colin's fluttering saxophone lines and to me it just kind of feels like Justin's voice is overtaking what Colin's doing as opposed to sort of complementing it but Justin doesn't always sort of stay in his comfort zone on this album there is the song brew where Colin is playing especially fast on the track just plaquing clacking his valves he's breathing as hard as hell making his sax just blare out furiously and toward the back end of the song Justin Vernon actually comes through and contributes what sounds like death metal style growls on the song this album feels like a metal nightmare the only other track that featured Justin's voice that really sort of impressed me was the cover of what are they doing in heaven today originally a Washington Phillips song a gospel tune where we hear Justin's singing in sort of a normal range of voice which is actually very soulful very emot-- it actually complements the track really well and it makes me feel as if well maybe a normally some voice would have suffice not just a falsetto on some of the other tracks as well of course there is also the 15 minute monolith of a title track that is on this album that I am pretty in love with the beginning of this track has a lot of fluttering sax lines too but the way that they're played and the phrasing that they're running up and down it feels very pretty in a way but the back end of the song as the track evolves it gets really heavy really intense the track feels like I'm listening to just mammoth calls like extinct tundra mammoths that are 50 feet tall and made of gears and pulleys they're like mecha mammoths and they're just leaving giant freaking footprints in snow dunes and sheets of ice there are a lot of highlights on this LP for sure no question no doubt but for me personally the downsides that this LP offers some of the ideas are say me say me across the album especially if you were a huge fan of Colin's previous to LPS as well though yes there was a little bit more tenderness musically on this album it doesn't really feel like Colin is pushing his technical ability that far on this album at least to my ears which if you're head over heels for Colin might not necessarily be a deal breaker but for me personally I wasn't really in love with every single vocal contribution that Bon Iver brought to the table I was much more enamored with what Shara Worden and Laurie Anderson did on his last full length LP I'm pretty much feeling a light to decent 7 on the cell P if you've given it a listen what did you think of it did you love it did you hate it why what do you think I should review next and that's about it Anthony Fantana Colin Stetson forever you

monomania hi everyone Anthony Fantana here the Internet's busiest music nerd and it's time for a review of the new Deer Hunter LP monomania deer hunter is a Georgia based rock band this is their four full-length release and they've pretty much been one of the bigger names in indie rock for the past five or so years and their style tends to lean toward the more psychedelic side of things noise pop dream pop as well as a little bit of shoegaze the band's earlier releases were very much sonic explorations through rock music whereas on their later releases they would flex their pop sensibilities through the songwriting of Lockett punt and Bradford Cox with albums like micro castle as well as the very well produced and instrumentally lavish Halcyon Digest with the direction that the band was going and you would think that they were just one album away from making some kind of big indie cross over into the mainstream where you had this underground band and slowly over time they gained more pop appeal and then they sort of you know get that sliver of limelight from more general music listeners given the material that was on Halcyon digest the last album they came out with and how high that album charted on the Billboard charts I thought that Deerhunter would be capable of making an album that had a lot of pop appeal even more pop appeal but still maintain their personality but Deerhunter is nothing if not full of surprises and it seems that the band has completely turned around on this new album and have gone back to their noisier roots on this album Deerhunter dishes out a lot of rock tunes with a strong garage rock attitude and tracks that are really sort of straightforward and just get right to the point not so much the more psychedelic and spaced-out jams that were inhabiting an album like cryptograms so it's not like monomania is a return to form or anything in a way monomania is most definitely progression you could say that over time Deerhunter has been working to kind of eliminate from their musical formula and monomania in its own sort of way does that by getting rid of very lavish detailed layered psychedelic production in favor of a recording that sounds more like it was recorded very shoddily in a bedroom if anything a lot of songs on this album kind of feel like some of the more straightforward material to come out of Bradford Cox solo project Atlas sound but in this instance weighing more lively instrumental E and a little punchier in a way this new album actually kind of has the guts that I wish Bradford Cox's last full-length LP did the very rough aesthetic that Deer Hunter goes for on the self he definitely makes a lot of these songs stick out Bradford Cox's vocals are mixed very high smothering almost all of the instrumentation underneath his voice the guitars are pretty distorted and when they're not distorted they're just very clear sharp and upfront the drums are very dirty gritty the more subtle tracks on the cell P come off very catchy and clear as well but newer fans to Deer Hunter who are really huge into albums like micro Castle as well as Halsey and digest may see songs like this as as possibly being just a little overly simple for sure the direction that Deer Hunter goes in on this LP does have appeal it's helped the careers of many garage rockers over the years neo garage rockers like Jay retard as well as ty Segall so it's really gonna make this album stick with people is whether or not the songs are memorable if they're catchy if they're passionate the band starts the selfie pretty eccentric with the song neon junkyard which is this tune that features are pretty captivating vocal melody sharp guitar leads Bradford Cox on certain parts of the song makes these really weird mouth noises echo out into oblivion just kind of adding a psychedelic characteristic to this song the song has a pretty basic structure but that doesn't necessarily ruin it because the melodies are so sharp what sort of ends up being a downside to the tune is that at the very end when it seems like the band gets kind of tired of building the song one piece after another they just sort of embark upon this very static underwhelming noisy jam until the song just sort of Peters out this is something Deer Hunter doesn't quite a few tracks from this LP actually and sometimes it just feels sort of boring and other times like for example the song monomania the title track on this LP it comes off as really intense thrilling and chaotic if there was any question that deer hunter was going into garage rock direction with the south and the song leather jacket clears that up with some really jagged wailing guitars just an attitude filled riff I just cannot stress how much attitude just no more plays a freaking role on this album to the point where it really sort of overshadows the song sometimes or makes a really lackluster song seem a little more interesting than it really is the track the missing is maybe the first song on this album that people will acknowledge as being sort of a traditional Deer Hunter song it's more toned-down more subtle the instrumentation rings through clearly not much distortion on this thing Bradford Cox things are really sweet vocal melody and the emotion behind his voice comes off as as very charismatic yet sort of emotionally disconnected cool I like the really warm synthesizers that come in after the verses on this track too it adds a really nice touch I think people will find a lot of appeal in this song for a long time Deer Hunter fans as well as the track dream captain where Bradford Cox has some pretty quaint lyrics on the track that are really sort of cute and the song sleepwalking - is a quieter number on this LP that comes off pretty charming through its subtleties even if you don't necessarily love what Deer Hunter did on this new album I think that some of the quieter moments on the selfie are worth salvaging and just sort of you know taking into consideration in terms of ideas for when Deer Hunter does another full-length there are some moments on this album though where the simplicity doesn't necessarily work into your Hunter's favor like the song blue agent which I feel like in terms of a tune is a fine track but as the band is performing this song without introducing new ideas as it goes along the track just feels really tedious and the song THM as well and there are some instances on this album where some tracks don't even feel like that like the song Pensacola just sounds like really bad alternative country it's actually like the band was trying to do an alternative country parody with these really hokey guitar leads and very generic guitar chords and the way Bradford Cox is singing on this song this really can't be wait it seems like he's really kind of ended up on what might be a joke an honestly night bike toward the end of this LP is another sort of least favorite of mine where Bradford Cox seems to be very indulgently strumming and singing in this very directionless way that does not feel entertaining at all it's at this point on the album where it feels like the attitude that toward the beginning of the LP that felt very refreshing and kind of badass and exciting is now getting really tiring especially given how many tracks on the self he felt more like posturing than you know just a good solid song while in theory I would have been interested in an album where Deer Hunter went in a noisier garage rock direction I mean that's what I assumed based on the title track that dropped before this album which I still love but when it comes to the practice of putting this album together it seems like Deer Hunter left out some essential details some catchy er songs and really just some more raw energy I'm feeling a light 2ds and six on this LP if you've given it a listen what did you think of it did you love it did you hate it why and here's another opinion hey listen Cal's gonna give it to you straight I've listened to plenty of deer rider in my day and the man mania Rex I've heard plenty of sangs with guitar and drums but none of them nice is this there you go deer hunter monomania forever [Music]

so hi everyone Anthony Fantana here internets busiest music nerd and it's time for a review of the new seven skin 7-inch sugar red soap and skin is the pseudonym of Austrian singer-songwriter Anja Francisca last year she came out with the album narrow one of my favorite albums of that year very short too short so short that it made me a little sad inside but an incredibly potent album in terms of songwriting power of motion Anya has this fantastic voice that weighs so heavy on the heart sometimes it's very eerie and smoky and throaty and very high and soaring above all of this just sadness and despair other times it's very kind of deadpan and haunting and of course she does this once again on her new 7-inch EP I'm gonna call it an EP it's like three tracks and it's a solid set of songs it kicks off at the track sugar bread which is a really impressive track to lead this 7-inch off with on this track anya basically takes that more industrial and beat heavy vibe that came from her last album but really beefs it up with an epic choral group as well as some horns and strings the added instrumentation on this song sounds huge its massive I'm just crossing my fingers hoping it shows up on her next full-length and the blood-curdling screams that she has the beginning of this track it's just so chilling the huge horn hits on this track that sometimes feels synthesized to have this kind of rigid awkward robotic feel to them the driving beat behind this track that also feels very mechanical the song is really well mixed not only is it massive but it has this kind of ambiguity to it where I can't exactly tell what is synthesized or what synthetic or what's real all I know is that Anya's voice in those weird hurricane of apocalyptic sounds and effects and chorus vocals she is just singing so it's almost as if emotionally she's completely unaffected by all this insanity going on around her and she was just this chilled eerie freaky straight-faced demon bringing all of this hell up from behind her and she just like taking bitch surely her artistic vision is a little bit deeper and more interesting than that but that's how it feels to me if there's anything that's a crime about the song is that it is a short three minutes and 36 seconds I mean the song definitely works sort of on a verse chorus verse structure has a nice eerie organ lead bridge toward the end of the track but with bringing all this extra instrumentation in and just making a song that is absolutely huge I can't help but feel like Anya's ideas are getting just a little too big to just totally encase into a just normal song length because while I do feel like this track is great and I do think it has just stuck into my head from repeat listens what the song is doing musically and melodically isn't exactly obvious on the first listen because how much is thrown at the listener in such a short period of time the songs I actually ended up liking a little bit more on this track were the two more subtle ones after this song like me and the devil which comes second it's a string led ballad with Anya's voice singing very passionately and a lot of points on this song it's actually the most passionately sung song on the entire EP and a lot of the lyrical themes coming up in this track and the repetition that was coming through in her lyrics on this song it felt very blues inspired and then it freakin hit me it's a very I saw you can cover and it's a fantastic revision with key hits of strings and noise and just dramatic throws of panel quartz just jutting into the mix as Anya says key words and the lyrics like the devil and Satan and the song pray that finishes the EP I was one of her more somber piano ballads a lot of piano arpeggios throughout this track but the song just finds this very beautiful beautiful kind of uplifting brightness to it as horns start swelling up in the background and the piano courts change mood the marching staccato piano notes toward the end of the song or a nice touch as well but it just feels like the song could have gone a little bit longer than the two or so minutes that it lasts overall I really join the CEP I do think that these song lengths could be a little bit longer and that some of these bigger ideas could be spread out and just fleshed out into something a bit more climactic I think it'll make the emotional power of Anya's songs even higher to have some of these ideas just sort of grow still not really a lot of complaints on this thing I'm feeling strong seven to a light tape on this EP if you've given it a listen what did you think of it did you love it hate it why and what do you think I should review next anthony Fantana soap and skin forever

Ghostface hello hi everyone Anthony Pham tan oh here Internet's busiest music nerd and it's time for a review of the new Ghostface Killah LP with Adrian young handling production really Adrian young and Ghostface Killah double-billed 12 reasons to die Ghostface Killah is a new york NC who's best known for his work and his place and his affiliation with the infamous hip-hop outfit the wu-tang clan but his musical fame is not just limited to the wu-tang clan he is actually in my opinion one of the more consistent members of the outfit when it comes to so material over the years he's put out a lot of albums that people consider to be East Coast hip-hop classics like Iron Man supreme clientele as well as fish-scale the only album in his discography that I really sort of steer clear of is ghost Dini I just that LP is just way too tender for me to tender while Ghostface Killah is last full-length LP Apollo Kids was good 12 reasons to die is undeniably a bigger and more ambitious project for one Ghostface Killah works from front to back of this album with producer Adrian young and while this guy is not a household name it is great for Ghostface to work with one producer for the duration of an entire project especially someone who is so seasoned musically the dude is a soundtrack composer multi-instrumentalist and the guy has an unquenchable thirst for these old-school B movie soundtracks that are parsed psych Rock part soul so while the album sonically is is no fish-scale in a lot of ways twelve reasons to die is just as cinematic if not more cinematic for one it's the first album that Ghostface Killah has put out in a while that tries to string together a strong narrative from beginning to end this album is coming out through a record label affiliated with another root Tang member the RZA and apparently there's a comic book that has inspired the narrative of this album or vice versa while on the surface this does completely breathe gimmick gimmick ah gimmick the album does sort of live up to this connection to the comic book with a lot of strong features from wit affiliates RZA occasionally popping in to kind of move the storyline along with some narrations Ghostface Killah 'he's very vivid and directional linear storytelling through his verses and of course adrian young's very soundtrack influenced production style these guys together definitely do not let the concept of 12 reasons to die overshadow the listening experience it enhances it instead if there is one negative about this LP though right from the get-go for people who are familiar with Ghostface Killah ghost is not exactly creative or inventive when it comes to creating this brand new character for him to kind of act out in this new album because a lot like on fish-scale Ghostface Killah finds himself again being a drugged on movin keys he's sort of the leader of an organized crime syndicate there are all these references to italian mafia culture he's showering women with jewels and money he's pulling triggers there are a lot of parallels with fish-scale on this album themes of vengeance and not being able to trust people around you and of course drugs violence all these things come up once again however it's not like these albums end the same way though toward the end of fish-scale Ghostface kind of finds himself on the top of the world but kind of regretting his life choices and seeing that the drugs that he's been selling is sort of destroying lives at least the lives of the people around him and he's kind of having this moment of clarity if anything puts 12 reasons to die above fish-scale it's that 12 reasons is way more direct with its storyline and its concept it's way more focused on the concept there are no real or detour tracks or anything like that separating away from the story that Ghostface Killah is trying to tell Ghostface Killah is a thug he's a street thug he joins with a mob mafia the DeLuca family DeLuca's he moves up in the family gets a lot of credibility he makes money then he starts a war with them separates off from them starts his own gang falls in love gets set up by this person then he is killed by the family that he started bad blood with and then shortly after he was killed he arises from the dead to exact his revenge Ghostface Killah tells this story track by track by track in his enigmatic his trademark gritty Street cipher flow super enthusiastic Ghostface Killah has this ability to spit so fast and yet hit the listener with so many things that are so freakin quickly clear there's a reason people call his rhymes ghost stories because throughout the entirety of this album you get a lot of vivid pictures of situations and characters especially his character well mostly his character there are other moments where woo affiliates come in to spit verses that are vital to the storyline like on the song center of attraction with Cappadonna he comes in and spits this very loosely flowed verse that seems like it's purposely over acted to be as if it were from just really bad b-movie or kind of hilarious especially at the end of the track where he's like oh my god you sleep his eyes man oh she's a set up jack and once Ghostface Killah rises from the dead he's back to spinning those kind of hyper violent hyper vivid very graphic almost cartoony 36 chambers esque bars where he is out to get who killed him and if there's a way to sort of imagine offing somebody it seems that Ghostface Killah does threw out all the verses on this LP but you know some people take the violence and hip hop and then you're really offended by it or they think that the MC is is super duper duper serious about it when the fact of the matter is a lot of these situations that Ghostface Killah paints it's almost just comical with how outlandish ly violent some of them are and this outlandish violence which can at times be very hilarious lasts for about the last four tracks of the album if there's any downside to the last four tracks this album is that they can get a little redundant with this hyper violence I like that the first half of this thing told this story very directly and with detail and it seemed that each track was trying to tell a different chapter where is the last part of the album the plot doesn't really seem so exact it's more a bloodbath if anything I would have loved to have heard maybe some longer tracks or some more detailed tracks where Ghostface Killah is specifically getting revenge on these twelve or so people who were a part of this family who offed him in the first place not only would that have made the album for me a little bit more interesting lyrically and conceptually but it would have made actually kind of feel and read a lot like a Tarantino film which it already kind of feels like due to the beats the Adrian young brings to the table I think my only issue with some of the tracks overall is that not only are some of the songs toward the end of the LP a little redundant but there are moments toward the beginning of the LP like the song Rises the black suits though the song does tell a pivotal part of the story it seems a little short some of the songs and I guess this album overall can be a little short for something that is supposed to be so conceptual and telling a full-length story instrumentally this album is freakin solid if you listen to the instrumentals alone with Ghostface Killah not on the tracks at all it sounds as if the beats themselves are telling a story because you have faster more intense beats that drive tracks like blood on the cobblestone that very much fit the subject matter a lot of fighting going on a lot of black market crime going on fighting with the police that track specifically has this weird funk rock blend with very fast detailed drums other tracks feature very grainy guitars sometimes there's a little bit of tremolo on there warm warm bass some eerie organs as well rich pianos with a lot of ambient noise around them if there's any issue I have with the production overall it's that the ambient noise around some of the instruments specifically the drums does take some of the beef out of the sound that the beats could have brung but still Adrian young does do a great job of taking the flaws that some of these sounds have and making an aesthetic with that making that old-school be movie soundtrack aesthetic but having enough production prowess and is sort of detail in there to make it feel like it's modern and not just shot especially as you have these female group vocals coming in singing parts of the story in this really dramatic way you have a member of the Delfonics appearing on one track which is fantastic his vocal presence on this song is not only beautiful it's eerie it totally fits Ghostface Killah style and the way that his voice is mixed and recorded it has that old-school soul music Motown vibe to it other tracks feel really glamorous with touches of strings horns what feel like tubular bells as well seriously Bravo to Adrian young whether it's some of the more instrumentally or fine tracks toward the beginning of this album or the really gritty layered boom-bap on the latter part of the LP the beats on this LP have a strong old-school hip-hop vibe but Adrian's compositional prowess adds a strong musicality to a lot of these instrumentals so I really loved listening to this album I would definitely recommend it to a hip-hop fan to a wu-tang fan I'm pretty much feeling a strong a to a like 9 on this thing if you've given it a listen what did you think of it did you love it hate it why what do you think I should review next and yeah that's it Ghostface Killah Adrian young twelve reasons to die forever [Music] [Music]

hi everyone Anthony Fantana here the Internet's busiest music nerd and it's time for a review of the new Kurt Vile LP neo on a pretty days Kurt Vile is a Philadelphia guitar player and singer songwriter who first started gaining momentum in the late 2000s on a wave of popularity for lo-fi and home recorded music though the album constant hit maker in 2008 was not Vile's first LP it was an album where you could hear him moaning in on the sound that he would refine on later releases now this LP in particular had a lot of just bare simple indie folk tunes that sometimes were very straightforward and minimal and other times very psychedelic layered and hazy that more psychedelic side of vials musical persona was growing as he put out more releases until about 2010 when he really sort of had his first big breakthrough with the album smoke ring for my halo an album that I did not review the year it came out mostly because of just some very strong negative reactions to a few characteristics for one though I did like that the production was very sort of lush and and hazy and very psychedelic it made a lot of the songs feel so uniform throughout and on top of that I didn't really feel all that much love for vile as a lyricist though I haven't always been impressed with vile stuff once I dig a little bit deeper into it I've always thought that there is a certain charm to his slow tone down drawl doubt vocals style he always tries to surround himself with the most vibrant sounds that he can and his voice sort of explains things as he's singing in an inflection that's reminiscent of someone like Lou Reed I like these things about Kurt's style but there are times when I listen to his music and I feel like he keeps his lyrics his song structures and his melodies ultra ultra simple just for the sake of maintaining this style and maintaining this vibe this very sort of psychedelic homogenous vibe that is really only interesting on a surface level and even though that sort of lucid and very subdued vibe contain this new LP as well anyway Kurt kind of turns a new leaf and becomes surprisingly ambitious on a lot of these tracks on this 70 minute album I change some of the psychedelic haze gets put on the back burner with some of these tracks in favor of some stopping baselines a little bit of cowbell some very sharp guitar leads and phrasing it's definitely reminiscent of artists like Bruce Springsteen or even Tom Petty and the Heartbreakers this is especially true of a track like Cavey crimes where the guitar phrasing on this song feels almost like arena rock guitars but of course they're sort of very lightly distorted and modestly played but the bass line man it really struts out there on this track locked in step with the drums like it is the of the walk the song shame chamber too is one of the catchiest and most concise songs Kurt Vile has written yet really stepping beyond the psychedelic sounds and writing a song that feels really really confident strong hook strong riffing and a very clear emotional message coming through on the lyrics and on the song snowflakes are dancing it feels like some of Kurt's old ideas are being revitalized to be something way more straightforward and just sharp some very Neil Young inspired chords on this song the song is kind of psychedelic and the drums behind this track really punched through the A's and drive this song confidently which is kind of an idea a style that Kurt has explored on previous tracks as well as in the band the war on drugs Kurt's voice is front Center on this song too he is a very convincing vocalist in my opinion not necessarily the best singer in the world but he's very sincere in a lot of his songs my only issue with this track though is I'm not really in love with some of the lyrics snowflakes are dancing discman is pumping headphones are loud chilling on a pillowy cloud while you're at it add some Doritos and a bike it and some slippers or a cup of chamomile tea you know honestly when it comes to lyrics I'm not incredibly picky I don't need a lot of flowery language if you're a longtime viewer of my reviews you may know at this point that I don't even really dwell over leer that often but there are some times where I feel like the lyrics are unag Nora belong the song because they come off as just being so vapid like on the song too hard where Kurt seems to be making all these promises just out of nowhere he promises to smoke less he promises to do his best for his God in his country he promises not to party too hard then later into the song he says that a man has to hold tight to the heart of the matter at hand and you know I agree throughout this track Kurt makes a lot of promises to himself or someone else I'm not sure and just a lot of agreeable statements about maybe life or just his philosophy but it doesn't really seem like it's pointing to anything thankfully the production and the instrumentation is gorgeous it's just kind of disappointing to see how beautiful the sounds and just the instrumentation is on this album its blissful it's heavenly but then some of the lyrics just are so plain this is the case as well the song was all talked recur kind of falls back into his old ways by writing a song that sonically feels pretty homogeneous from beginning to end the production is slightly more lush than the stuff from smoke ring and I do like that the song is a little hypnotic but Kurt spits out this one line where he's like makin music is easy watch me if that was the point Kurt was trying to prove it this song I agree I feel the same way about the song err but to with how homogeneous it feels from beginning to end not quite so bad there are some very fast since that pop in and out of this track that I like again these are not really terrible songs in my opinion I just feel like they could be more interesting especially with what Kurt brings vocally thankfully that's really it for the songs on here that I feel sort of indifferent toward other tracks on here the vast majority of the tracks on here I actually think are great like the opening track on this thing the nine-minute not a pretty day a really awesomely grooving and sublime full rocker sharp guitar leads all over this thing cut through the psychedelic haze I love the stop that they do in the middle of this track the sort of segue that they play into immediately after the feels almost linear skynyrd inspired the song girl called Alex appeals to me as well in a lot of the same ways the song never run away is one of the sharpest singles Kurt Vile has written yet one of the shorter songs on this LP really catchy refrain verses with a lot of momentum being driven by some rhythm guitar just very punchy drums and another track I love on this LP the 10-minute clothes are gold-tone which is a spot on this album where Kurt again goes back into that sort of personal musing mode of his where he's giving a lot of personal thoughts feelings but on this song they come off in a way that feels sort of reasoned or sensible in a way that the listener can actually relate or just understand brokers coming from he says right at the beginning of the song that when he gets into his zone he gets into this mental state where if you saw him it would seem as if he is high so he says in the song he's never touched this stuff then he goes on to say this personal pain that he feels he tries to basically exorcise it get rid of it dump it through creating gold tones just pretty sounding music sounds that he feels are beautiful or sweet which to me says a lot about the makeup of this album philosophically and musically it's basically a behind-the-scenes look at Kurt's mental state when he goes into the songwriting process but aside from the mental state of this track the instrumental is beautiful as well again a sublime instrumental closing out this album I'm absolutely in love with the instrumentation on this thing it is so lovely is there vibraphone on this track it is so pretty with that the acoustic guitar the bass the drums the vocals they all blend together into yet another haze and yes there is a lot of haze on this album but there's a lot of detail and lushness to the haziness i mean it's all just so dense and detailed and that's what I really love about this LP though I don't think this is a perfect album it is Kurt Vile best yet and there is reason to believe that his next album could be even better because up until this point with every new release Kurt Vile has improved upon what he did before he selfie if you've given to listen what did you think of it did you love it did you hate it why what do you think I should review next and that's it Anthony Fantan oh all down a pretty days forever hi Anthony hi everyone Anthony Fantana here the Internet's busiest music nerd and it's time for a review of the new phosphorescent LP muchacho phosphorescent is the musical project of singer-songwriter guitar player Mathew hall he has six following albums under his belt all of which sit under the umbrella of neo folk indie folk all country as well as Americana the student is a singer-songwriter through and through and a lot of the early releases to come out of this project have more of a sort of raw tangible sound to the instrumentation sort of lo-fi and recording quality but still pretty mellow and having a lot of emotional vulnerability and this sense of mellowness really took over the bands of music in a huge way especially in 2010 word even showed up in the album title of the LP here's to taking it easy now there are a lot of different ways to play folk music and country music but it seems that these sweeter and more pleasant sounds in these genres are what really sort of speaks to Mathieu artistically yet he tops a lot of this heavenly Americana instrumentation with this warbly voice of his that is very pleasant as well but also maybe a little sad now the band's latest LP muchacho is no less easygoing than much of anything else they've put out in recent years I would actually say it's just as easygoing but it sort of goes about capturing this vibe in a different way because glistening reverb kind of psychedelic and pristine production is essentially the game changer on muchacho I wouldn't necessarily call muchacho a safe record but it is certainly a friendly record a record that is sure not to offend much of anybody it's quite pretty a lot of the time the lead vocals often have harmonies behind them the production melts them together and soars them above the instrumentation and the instrumentation itself is often very soft del like it and and joyous as well as far as Matthew's lyrical content goes a lot of what he says seems to kind of revolve around the same Americana type tropes evil good the devil love being downtrodden emotionally instrumentally a lot of the same sort of culprits show up on this record bass guitars drums vocals maybe a little bit of horn a little bit of string as well as some lap steel very funky and familiar chord progressions all over this LP a lot of which seem to be rooted back in traditional American music much like the track on this LP muchachos tune which is a waltz in three four three four waltz with very bouncy keyboards echoing out nicely guitars that wander up and down scales plinky pianos and though it's all playing at a tempo it's also distant there's so much space in between all the instrumentation it's as if it's all kind of like one small atom and everything is kind of rotating very loosely around this one idea and though Matthews voice doesn't exactly cut through the reverb in a really aggressive or or very ear catching way some of the things he says can be very poetic very sharp been  up Shepard to Lamb like wave to the sand and the very uplifting horns toward the end of this track this song has a very strong strong sense of romance to it another track I instrumentation is really reverb din glassy Matthews vocals have a really striking and memorable vocal melody to them and not only that but his lyrics seem to be a little more audible on this track than they are on others it's like there are moments on this LP where he is super impressed with his own lyricism and he wants to make sure that everyone hears it and there are some pretty interesting lyrics on this track where you singing about love disfiguring him into something that he's not recognizing or another line where he's saying that he is not going to struggle or stand to be acknowledged by his gnarled hands there are a lot of themes of just loving unconditionally rejection desperation and maybe I think a little bit of pride that comes up in this song in a really interesting way and another one of my favorite tracks on this LP is the longest the seven-minute quotidian beasts I really like that the band sort of ventures out into a jam on this track it is a strong Americana flavor jam there's a real hard groove to this track despite how pleasant and sort of reverb the production is on this song however I will say that this is one of the moments where I feel like something a little bit clearer and a little bit meteor would have been more interesting it actually sounds more like a one microphone live recording of the band just performing in the moment very far away from the stage the microphone that is sometimes the CRP production masks what could have been a good song even though I do think Matthew is a good singer capable singer he's a good lyricist as well when he wants to display it he doesn't exactly have the boldest voice or demeanor it also doesn't help that many of the melodies that he sings follow very closely in roots music footsteps maybe Matthew is sort of hoping longtime fans will follow phosphorescent up until this point and sort of fill in the gaps that are being created with all of this reverb that is being laid hi everyone Anthony Fantana here the Internet's busiest music nerd and it's time for a review of the new oh C's album floating coffin VOCs is a San Francisco garage rock outfit of the lo-fi persuasion that I've been following for a while now since like 2008 and though garage rock is definitely at this band's stylistic roots there are very clear elements of noise rock psychedelic and experimental folk and psychedelic rock - sort of bubbling within the OCS or a noisy cacophonous rock music the band is pretty prolific with an ever growing discography under their belts sometimes putting out two albums within a year span of time and though I did enjoy a lot of their early output there was a moment a few years back where I became just ever so slightly disillusioned by the o'seas music over time the band's production and just recording grew more and more brittle and just noisy and trebled for me it was difficult to hear interesting song ideas and riff ideas shining through all of the guitar distortion and the ear piercing echoed vocals still the band is really noisy they're colorful they're undeniably energetic they can really freakin rock a groove sort of blame it out in the way that a band like the fall may you can really sort of get lost in the momentum of their songs was last year when I heard Putra fires - that I kind of got back into the bands music a little bit more and wanted to just sort of see what they were up to and on this record though they did keep a lot of their usual garage rock sounds I heard them incorporating just a little bit more string work I heard just more tunes shining through with more clarity in the production - not quite so brittle and just noise ridden this did make me excited to listen to the band's next full-length LP and for sure floating coffin is nowhere near the OCS most distorted or noisy release there is quite a bit of clarity on this LP some heaviness - to the bass especially when the band is going at a slower pace on some of these songs where they maybe get a little sludgy but still the changes the OCS make to their sound on this LP to me are very very few overall floating coffin is the OCS back to their old tricks once again for sure this band has something really really special when it comes to rocking your freaking face off I think even really cynical listeners can at least see the appeal of moments on this LP like the opening track from the mountain the pummeling drums the noisy burning guitar leads on this thing the fevered vocals of course all these shouts of whoo and these quirky synthesizers too the song is fast furious and it's fun and I think the next track on this LP is pretty appealing too it's one of the slower songs I've ever heard the band done and the guitar riff on this thing is just buzz it's heavy it's mid paced it's a beefy ass riff grimy filthy garage rock vibes all over this thing this noisy riff kind of dies down and gives way to a quieter version of it the band starts laying some interesting guitar leads on top of it starts harmonizing them a little bit with vocals they sort of like to throw a louder version and a softer version of the same riff at the listener and build a song structure on that as opposed to having legitimately contrasting verses and choruses or just a really strong a lot of character director the title track on this LP has this incessant chromatic bassline that is just so repetitively boring and there are these redundant four note falsetto vocals that pop in it again this is a moment where the band has great fantastic energy and they are loud as hell but it's not really that much of a song and I find it weird that these moments aren't really appealing to me that much I do like jams usually I like hearing a band play together I like hearing interplay I like hearing momentum but I don't really think they have much of anything else beyond that because the band rarely showcases the kind of flashy playing or really the intensity or the kind of melodies that would make these songs a little bit more dynamic layered interesting the song strawberries one and two sort of breaks this typical song structure and introduces a new riff idea partway into the song but still the the melody on this track isn't really that strong the playing isn't that strong either the guitar chords seem very Sammy Sammy it's like a lot of the tracks on this album are based on half-baked improv the rest of the LP just kind of continues following this suit it's a riff idea riff idea riff idea riff idea but song ideas kind of come second a lot of the songs on this up here loud and they're exciting but not a single minute of any of them really sticks with me even immediately after I've listened to them I can't figure out whether or not what's playing in my head after I listened to an OC song is what I've just heard or me just sort of unconsciously making up something that sounds like what I just heard Nana Nana Nana Nana Nana da da that did aside from the surprising flute on the song tunnel time I think the only moment on the back end of this LP that I liked was the closing track miniature which was the track initially that I heard from the album that got me excited to listen to this thing in the first place now the track isn't amazingly written but it is a legitimate song in comparison with many of the other tracks on here it has a verse it has of course it has audible lyrics and the vocals sing a melody that's kind of memorable the guitar chords jut into the track very quaintly I guess and there's some strings backing the song too that are very nice the hook swells on this thing I like the female background vocals and the melody that the strings play on this track is really airy and angular I like it if every melody on every track here was was this sharp or at least every track incorporated a melody that was this sharp somewhere into the jam this would have been a pretty interesting album instead a lot of these tracks just seemed like very basic dime-a-dozen guitar riffs of the garage rock variety that play out for two to four minutes until the band just sort of has played them loud played them soft played them loud again and then play them soft and then it's kind of choose your own adventure from there like I said earlier there are some things I like about the OCS in general and this record to the Bands energy is just their their ferocity their noisiness and the recording on this LP but not much of this album is memorable and that's because the band doesn't really write the songs to be memorable honestly so I'm pretty much feeling the light too decent five on this thing if you've given it a listen what did you think of it did you love it did you hate it why what do you think I should review next and that's it Anthony Fantan oh oh cease forever you

ghost hi everyone Anthony Fantana here internet's busiest music nerd and it's time for a review of the new Ghost LP in infest assume ghost or ghost BC is a Swedish traditional doom metal slash heavy metal slash hard rock outfit and this is their highly anticipated sophomore LP very anticipated by me and much of the metal community since the hype died down from their very very popular full-length debut opus eponymous for the most part the band plays this old-school style of heavy metal that has a strong strong occult vibe Blue Oyster Cult and Black Sabbath influences aside opus eponymous had some characteristics that made it a pretty odd modern metal release the album is incredibly hooky and in melodic and not in a very technical way or a way that is alienating to your average music listener their course is all over this album that just buried themselves deep within the brain songs like ritual as well as Eliza Beth and in comparison with other frontmen out there these days ghosts vocalists is really one of the most agreeable metal singers out there not really having anything too sharp or abrasive or just aggressive about the way that he sings his voice is incredibly friendly at times kind of smooth if there's anything that's sour about it can at times be eerie the only thing that is overtly off-putting about ghosts music are these strong dark and and satanic messages that come through in the lyrics and they display these things in a really theatrical way not quite as torturous as some bands that seem to take these themes a bit more seriously despite all of these issues this album took the metal world by storm however I have to admit I'm not really enjoying the sophomore full length as much it is very clear that ghost shoots for some really ambitious changes on this new LP but not all of them add a prose for the most part it's it's a lot of cons for one this record was recorded in a new studio on a new record label with a brand new budget and it definitely shows and shows up in ways that on paper would seem like a really good thing like for one there's all these huge monstrous gothic choruses that pop up occasionally on these tracks bringing this huge sense of epicness the songs overall on this LP are longer there are more guitar solos some more instrumental passages more movements to the songs more layers of guitar more layers of background vocals synthesizers come through in a big way on a lot of these tracks on this LP no question ghost is sounding thicker they're sounding more detailed they're sounding more fleshed out but all of these additions have created some really glaring issues in my eyes it's sort of distracted ghost away from songwriting and hooks which was the best thing opus eponymous had going for it and instead they're turning their eyes toward things that aren't necessarily their strengths like pulling together these sort of epic instrumental moments which has never really been one of the best qualities of the band mostly due to how stiff some of the guitar playing can be on their records as a fan of opus eponymous I can admittedly say that the four minute closing instrumental on the album is really one of the weakest points on the entire LP so I'm a lot of these tracks the band is showcasing this instrumental and compositional power that they don't particularly have and on top of that all of these added about bells and whistles and sounds and and choral vocals they all add to this sense of hokey Nastase they were close to being maybe a little over the edge with it but like I said earlier the songwriting and just that strong eerie vibe that they had made up for it certainly there are spots on this LP where ghost is able to take these choral vocals this newfound detail these longer song lengths and pull them together with a really good tune the song Body and Blood sticks out to me as a song like that it's a very very eerie ballad lots of guitar leads interjecting between chorus lines on this track it's just so freakin dark and cultish and successfully blends the sound that you typically expect from ghosts with some ideas that feel sort of psych rock inspired and progressive rock inspired however it's really the song Year Zero that I think is able to maintain the most focus with all of these new additions it's a great song that gallops away valiantly with this monstrous gothic chorus right at the start of the song great verses great choruses a really fantastic guitar solo toward the end of the track with some tubular bells chiming away epically it's a huge ending with a really dreary outro right on the tail end of the track it's just a full package deal these awesome choral vocals also show up on the very melodic closing track on this album another favorite on the LP for me to me these are just highlights on the album some of my favorite moments and and really tracks that I'm happier there because it gives me at least some level of faith that the next album will be better and maybe whatever issues I have with this LP will kind of be smoothed out by them it songs like idolatry which really kind of get me cringing the song is just littered with these inexplicably wimpy guitar riffs and schmaltzy organs and I can't really put my finger on it because the vocals sound roughly the same as they do on other tracks here but on this particular song I just feel like I'm listening to some really bad bark of herb and the vocals just don't really have that eerie vibe on this song that they do on others they just sound kind of silly on this track the song just kind of sounds like this really old bad psych pop single that would have never ever ever seen the light of day if it had been written in the 60s for me this track really sort of steps over a line and I just can't believe that the band didn't see it especially with the terrible falsetto is all over this song and they sound even worse when they're harmonized one of the lead singles off of this LP secular haze also crosses this line for sounding like it was conceived underneath the circus tent these same obnoxious scents dampen a perfectly good vibe on the song per aspera the song Kiki gollu is another track that just sounds like really had heavy psychedelic rock that would have been better if the instruments were actually played with any guts but there none because they're not and there's not really a particularly interesting song on this track just sort of a guitar riff that's supposed to have some momentum maybe it just falls flat and feels hokey and I have to say I was pretty disappointed for the most part with the longest track on this LP gulen zombie queen sure it's ambitious the man is trying to write a longer song something that's gonna feel epic but the slow melodic intro without that strong compositional power there the moment at which the song starts just feels kind of boring and when the band finally kicks in and starts bringing some power to the song the drums pop in the guitars pop in synthesizers pop in baby it just sounds like a really bad surf pop tune blending surf with metal is something that I've heard before in bands like ghoul for example but even they maintain some level of badassness as they're doing it whereas ghost just sounds ridiculous the huge climax at the end of this track is really the songs only redeeming value for me overall I was just not feeling this LP was really really sort of let down by it I feel like ghosts really let their budget and let their ambition blind them from just writing good Tunes for sure all these additional elements could have been added to the recipe to make it fantastic it happens on this album with songs like Year Zero but rarely do the stars all aligned in this way on these songs there are moments where just all these additional things block the song from even shining through and there are moments where ghost is really sort of trying to put forward a hard rock and psychedelic rock influenced riff that just doesn't have any real balls on it overall I'm feeling a strong four to a light five on this album if you've given the listen what did you think of it did you like this album did you hate it why here's another opinion don't listen to this guy over here I listened to this album the vocals wrecked the guitars wrecked the big voices wrecked in the key Birds rats Anthony Fantan Oh ghost forever [Music]

Hey hi everyone Anthony Fantana here internet's busiest music nerd and it's time for a review of the new Big KRIT mixtape free album collection of tracks thing a king or king remembered in time Big KRIT is a Mississippi rapper and producer known for his very personal lyrics detailed Southern Fried beats catchy hooks and versatility these strengths of his have given him a lot of visibility a lot of exposure outside of the Mississippi area over the past few years with his breakthrough mixtape scrit was here as well as return of forever and his forever in a day free mixtape slash kind of concept album as well as his full-length commercial debut live from the underground on Def Jam Records which actually made it to number one on the charts which was a pretty big step up for Big KRIT at least in terms of music industry noticeability he had some pretty large features and ambitious features on this LP featuring people like BB King as well as 2 Chainz and this bigger budget definitely showed up in crit's production as well with guest singers horns guitars their smooth soulful music samples though it is easily my least favorite of his recent projects still proved to me that he could put out a big-budget album on a major record label but still come out with a series of tracks that didn't cheapen his style his direction or just his sound in general and maybe that partially has to do with the interesting position that Big KRIT is in in the world of hip hop right now he's one of the few MCS that is so versatile he can put together bangin catchy very hook heavy singles but also turn around and do something that's really a motive or vulnerable personal socially conscious as well the fact that he can wear many different hats as he is making songs and not sound like a fool when he's doing one or the other is a big help to him and it's the guys rapping style in his production that sort of adds this very solid base underneath every narrative he tries to string together on a given LP that brings the consistency that I guess sort of makes it all believable when it comes to changing the sound of his rapping or his production style crit is very much about slow and steady wins the race however as crit has continued to release music it seems like maybe a little bit more and more he is recycling and reframing a lot of the catchphrases that he uses in previous tracks song topics and themes euphemisms flows when he's rapping as well as maybe grooves and in synth lines and his beats and looking back on all the big crits recent albums now it's become kind of apparent that many of his full lengths flow in roughly the same way and Creek pretty much carries that redundancy on to this new LP as well because between a lot of the tracks here he rounds many many familiar basis in terms of song themes and where certain songs of certain emotions are placed at certain points in the album for one on the cell P there's the track king without a crown which is very hard-hitting essentially it is a personal determination anthem of which there are a lot of that pop up at the beginning of crit's full-lengths however this one is incredibly well done and there's no reason to sort of throw it away just because there are a few songs out there right now that may be sort of telling the same story as it but this version being a little more updated because crit right now is that a different part in his career than he was two or three albums ago on this track he does manage to rehash some lines that have appeared on previous releases like what's a king without a crown what's the car without some sound and I'm not sure if I was totally feeling the line split in the peach fruit ninja' the song shine on is sort of a hard grooving the slow and chilled kick off of the album which crate has definitely done before and the vibe that saw meditate goes for as well will be familiar to crit fans it is a slow burner where crits singing vocals are right at the forefront although this is in my opinion is definitely one of the best songs that he done in this angle because of how melodic and detailed the beat is I love the guitar on this track as well as the jazz vibraphone very pretty I also like the lyrical angle that this track takes with just vices crit has some other interesting messages on this LP as well later in the album where typically the more highfalutin deep tracks are placed the song banana clip theory is an interesting track about somebody who has a gun for protection mostly but of course there comes a time where he acted irresponsibly with it and then he's dealing with sort of the aftermath and the regret that can come with making the mistake of pulling the trigger at the wrong time or at the wrong person or just for the wrong reason the song multi till the Sun die is another one of these tracks right at the end of the album where quick kind of checks his mental state his status and music his personal life and this is really one of the most epic tracks that he has done in this vein yet a lot of these songs especially ones like the vent tend to be very sort of sad and introspective this one just as introspective but really sort of triumphant and it should be considering where crit is right now in his career nice work on the sample there too even though there are times where crit sort of approaches structuring an album like doing a mad lib or something okay we need something sad in this slot we need something upbeat in this slide he does manage to put himself into some interesting situations on this album like with the song REM which very successfully I will say samples the James Blake song the Wilhelm scream he flips this sample perfectly and he does it in a way that doesn't feel too cheesy or in a way takes this Blake sample and and creates a theme where he seems to sort of fear his dreams or be doubtful about them right now especially with the line on this track where he feels like he has sort of Mack pepper stand - hi everyone Anthony Fantino here the Internet's busiest music nerd and it's time for a review of the new mecha verse can album - these guys are a Swedish rock outfit this is their second full-length LP obviously and on this album they're doing a little bit of a tweak to their sound their debut full-length was chock full of punk in Iraq and post-punk influences hectic guitars and drums and all this sonic chaos was sliced through by the band's very sharp voiced lead singer Maya Milner and Milner's voice still kind of cuts its way through to the front row on this album but it's not through incredibly distorted guitars on this LP the band still has a lot of gutsy punk energy just look at the refrain on the opening track on this album which is essentially but this time what Milner is sort of singing through on this album is reverb it's sort of noisy / jangly guitars cat6 style melodies the attitude and the distortion is most definitely still there but it's replaced with the kind of songwriting that influences other modern bands like the panes being pure at heart now even though this band is kind of a few years behind the revival of this kind of stuff back around 2009 they still sound really great doing it and it's nice to kind of hear a group take this kind of rock songwriting this kind of rock and pop songwriting and add a bit of noisiness to it be kind of feisty with it a lot like some of the older more noise pop oriented bands in this style used to like the shop assistants or black tambourine because of the straightforwardness and the melody and just the speed and the energy of the span throughout this album a lot of tracks on this LP are incredibly catchy the opener anti bus or the song asleep which comes right after which is just as infectious not so much fun actually a little bit sweeter a lot of tracks on this LP are kind of the perfect combination of sadness angst eNOS but also in in-your-face attitude and on top of that very sharp blissful melodies that make me kind of want to run outside and spin around in circles staring up at the Sun not caring just being very unfortunately a lot of the guitar strumming patterns and chord progressions do play into those jangle pop stereotypes but for the most part the band is entertaining and catchy enough to sort of make this quality ignore I guess another major issue for me on this LP is is Maya even though she sings very well on a lot of these tracks her transition from being kind of this punk heroine to someone who was really sort of singing some ballads or just some pop tunes on this album she I guess is a little too overbearing with the sharpness of her voice this is most definitely the case on songs like slowly sinking as well as something more but there are some points on this album where I do feel like the band does make some of these pretty songs intentionally ugly they do bring a an element of gruffness to some of them like the songs outshine and no mercy which both at certain points on the tracks have guitar leads that toss in all sorts of wonky or too sour notes to kind of just muck up what the song is trying to do musically and plus this long drama wind Maya's vocals also sort of reaching her upper register on this track but they come off way more pleasant not so much I like that this track in comparison with others on here is kind of a slow jam has that 60s to do to epic drumbeat quality to it heavy guitar chords pounding and ringing out and there are some points on this album where Maya's abrasive voice does sort of work in her favor when she's
