hi everyone Anthony Fantana here the Internet's busiest music nerd and it's time for you review the new Flaming Lips LP the terror this is the latest full-length album from Oklahoma band The Flaming Lips really one of the most important groups if not the most important group in modern psychedelic music really one of the biggest advocates of taking psychedelic rock and pop and just furthering it progressing it with modern technology and ideas and a lot of rock bands even experimental rock bands as they get older they tend to kind of mellow out a little bit however that has not really been the case for The Flaming Lips at all it seems like since the late 2000s stylistically they've been getting stranger and stranger with their music and their antics like the very textured noisy challenging and difficult album embryonic that they dropped in 2009 as well as the collaboration streamed compilation that they put out last year Hedy Fwends gummy skulls 24-hour songs Pink Floyd cover album hmm disturbing music videos verizon advertisements the band has been incredibly entertaining to follow in terms of their antics but all of this has you know sort of been in the way of putting out a new freakin album however I don't think one could say after listening to the terror that the band was at all distracted or was there are cheapened by all of these sort of extracurricular activities because for sure the terror is one of the Flaming Lips most focused and odd musical experiences thus far that they have released in their career in terms of concept and sound now the album embryonic that the band put out in 2009 in comparison to some of the more psych pop-oriented albums that they put out just before it is really a chaotic and freewheeling record and the terror in comparison with all of that is is most definitely not wild it's not rocking hell it is not even poppy instead the band goes on a sonic journey on this LP that is very cold it desolate its robotic all over this LP there are just throbbing pulsating rhythms on electronics wandering guitars that are very repetitive in nature vocals that tend to sort of hang in the falsetto range and range from being heavenly or even eerie you really could have named this album the terror : The Flaming Lips in space slash 2001 a Space Odyssey because there are a lot of parts of this album that remind me of the frightening and surreal imagery that that haunts the latter portion of that film as I move through the album and I'm listening to this album I can see that time is passing by and that the songs are going from beginning to end but there's a serious sense of stillness that is just all over this album in general the opener on this LP feels like it's pretty much in the same chord from front to back and a lot of songs on this album feel the same way the band will jam on one single chord for the length of an entire track but they will progress the track and introduce new ideas by experimenting with sound instead on this particular track throbbing electronics synthesizers that are both sort of light in area and ethereal and heavy low and monolithic brittle guitar screaming and panned all the way to the side of one channel and while this track seam is very repetitive for the five minutes that it lasts on the surface it sort of glides into the next song nicely not only does it have a cool segue like many of the songs on this album do moving from one to another but the song seems to sort of fade into the next logically as well like this album in a lot of ways feels like one giant song the next tracks on this LP be free away and try to explain are easily my favorite songs on this entire LP I actually think they're the best moments that the Flaming Lips achieve with this aesthetic that they're going for on this album the songs are very still they're very repetitive they just feel suspended in space and the vocals that just fly over the the weird soundscape that the band creates they are heavenly they are just haunting they're beautiful and simple as well it's like the opening track on this album was creating a ruckus and sort of propelling things forward whereas when we get to these next two tracks you're literally kind floating in space now you've gone from the ground into the atmosphere and you're past these songs the album continues to be even more psychedelic twisted surreal with the song you lust with just 13 minutes long and length this song is massive and it actually feels pretty krautrock inspired to tell you the truth if this song came out at around the time that noise was dropping their early stuff it would have been revolutionary but the thing is it's 2013 and as of today this song didn't really come off that way to me because while the song did open up with some really interesting sounds that were seductive very weird I felt like I was tripping into this whole different world by the time we get to the middle of the song things aren't really moving at a pace that keeps me engaged or interested the song gets pretty thin when it comes to new or interesting ideas the very simple guitar leads and the stale sense on this part of the track just get very old very fast and to me this progression is actually mirrored in how I enjoy the entire album in itself even though this album is under an hour and only nine tracks it feels like it draws on much longer because it doesn't offer a lot when you get to the middle point of the album in terms of melody or playing and even sound craft - I appreciate that the terror is very sound oriented and the band wanted to create a more sound and texture based composition as opposed to just a traditionally musical one but it seems like around the middle point of the album they're sort of recycling ideas that they used at the first portion of the album and not in a way that feels interesting or fresh either I just get a lot of these falsetto moans that aren't even necessarily on pitch a lot of the time over a slew of different synth sounds and noises or percussions the song you are alone to me just feels way too obscured to be enjoyable and the falsetto on this track is is really one of the most sour out of the entire album I'm just really too distracted by how off it is to really feel much of anything about I like the song butterfly a lot but the reason that I like that track is that it kind of houses a lot of the same musical or sonic ideas that the first three songs on the album do actually to me this song feels like a fusion of the first three songs in a lot of ways and I like that the song turning violent has a pretty apocalyptic ending to it with some chilling group vocals but the song serves up just another sour falsetto that I don't have much interest in and the closing track on this LP is easily the most rockin and cathartic on the entire album and not that really needed a song like this to sort of make it a good LP but actually despite the fact that it is loud and that it does have a strong beat to it it feels like just extremely anticlimactic for sure the terror has style it has an aesthetic and it has some vocal melodies that are worth buying into the sound palate on this album is awesome but I just don't feel like The Flaming Lips come up with enough sounds to justify an album of this length and the thing is the album isn't even that long the band is undoubtedly created something nightmarish but I will not be waking up from this in a cold sweat anytime soon I'm feeling a decent two strong six on this thing what did you think of it if you've given it a listen did you love it hey des why and what do you think I should review next Anthony Fantana The Flaming Lips the terror forever [Music] you [Music]

epic all the time it just all kind of seems like it's only relative to this overproduced pop rock offshoot of metalcore music sure there are choruses on this album that reach for the stars but numerous tracks on this thing are loaded with dime-a-dozen boring uninspired metalcore riffing and breakdowns the riffs don't really hit any interesting or unique angles or grooves much of the time hi everyone Anthony Fantino here Internet's busiest music nerd and it's time for a review of the new black heart rebellion album har Nev oh these guys are a Belgian rock outfit as far as I can tell this is their sophomore full-length LP the thing is about forty minutes and these forty minutes are spread across eight different tracks and it's a pretty intriguing release with a combination of genres such as post rock psychedelic rock folk music maybe a little bit of post metal drone doom mmm I could definitely tell that these guys appreciate maybe a little bit of the Mogwai maybe a little bit of the swans and even though this band's stylistic genre influences are very apparent they don't always necessarily come together in in a really obvious way which is great like the song crawling and eating dust which starts off with just this dark sickening and eerie ominous drum circle there are these chilling chorus vocals that pop up over the drum circle and as the song progresses some droning guitar and bass comes in and it is heavy and resonant these guys are really great at using sound and texture to just create drama create darkness after this part in the song these spoken-word vocals come in but they've got this sort of just whisper quiet sort of sinister character to them this song and many others on here just get more and more intense as they go on the primal drone on this track eventually goes toward this huge sike rock climax wailing guitars heavy bass the vocals turn from whispering to just all-out aggression and they do all of us without losing the occult vibe that the song started off with like I said other tracks kind of work with this same sort of arc the same sort of progression but the band does it with different flavours of music like the song a NAR dot which I don't know if I'm pronouncing correctly but it too gets more in as it goes on but it kicks things off with sort of a 70s heavy metal style to it kind of like Black Sabbath when heavy metal still had a really prominent bluesy hardrock influence and even though they definitely go a little heavy metal on this track they still managed to make the song just very slow dramatic jeroni deadpan vocals on this thing pots and pans percussion bunched up with the drums to again give it that kind of prime evil vibe I love the passionate group vocals at the end of this track two moments like this really sort of stick with me even though these guys aren't exactly a course oriented band the production the experimentation the adventure the sounds they're all there the variety on this LP continues with tracks like gold and myrrh which opens up with these chords that feel as if they're a little inspired by Spanish guitar music maybe a little bit of flamenco the downside to this particular track though is that some of the noisy and psychedelic builds that the band goes on are a little more interesting than others this one particularly nothing really about it sticks out of me if anything it kind of reminds me of a cut from that new god speed album that came out last year and there are other tracks on here like abraham which are a great start to the album add a lot of color to this LP but they're a lot shorter than some of the other tracks on here and while it's not bad to have a shorter track on this album theoretically it's not like the band is able to kind of tie things up efficiently give some closure or write a song that feels concise within a three or four minute time span instead some of these relatively shorter songs can end up feeling like they could have gone somewhere as interesting as some of the other tracks still overall there's way more highlights on this album than does even though I wasn't completely in love with it maybe my favorite song the entire LP being animal esque which has a twisted song structure the guitars on this track just jangle epically and I love the the angry ass vocals on this song just how fierce they come across dust dust the explosive ending on this thing too is awesome this album and in this track in particular it's just monolithic it shoots four monolithic much of the time and I will say that it succeeds the black heart rebellion has a huge sound they definitely have a nice recording on this album and they know what to do with it instrumentally this album is so heavy and yet it can at times be sort of eerie or quaint like at the start of the last track which has some interesting banjo on it I do feel like the cell P could be a little bit more cohesive in terms of a narrative or a story or an arc it seems like every song on here is sort of its own little nook or cranny or niche instead of the entire album sort of having an interesting progression to it and even though I did end up with some tracks paling in comparison to others still this is a really solid set of tracks and I feel like this band is doing some really interesting stuff on this LP but they're just like this close to doing something whoa hopefully that ends up being the case on their next release I'm feeling a decent too strong seven on this thing if you've given it a listen what did you think of it did you love it did you hate it why what do you think I should review next and yeah that's it Blackheart rebellion forever

marionette hi everyone Anthony Fantan oh here the Internet's busiest music nerd and it's time for a review of the new marionettes marionettes LP hit the waves these guys are a Swedish pop and rock outfit this is their third full-length LP and on this release they're sticking with roughly the same sound that they've been purveyors of for a majority of their career let's just say the marionettes aren't exactly well known for their originality if you give a listen to this LP pretty much what you're going to get is 80s era dream and jangle pop with a hefty helping of synthesizers on the side a lot of danceable beats on this LP explosive hooks and very very emotive vocals from frontman Philip ekstrom who a lot of the time vocally is a dead ringer for the Cure's robert smith and though the cure is a huge influence on the marionettes music it's not really like the more post-punk e goth abrasive side of the band really sort of comes out in this record it's really more of a crossbreed of Robert Smith's vocals along with these sort of light papi catchy but sort of you know single tear streaming down my face vibe that you typically get from like a Smith's record so the marionettes have some really obvious influences but on every single one of their records they always manage to at least dish out a few infectiously awesome tracks now on this third album of theirs I can't exactly say they're doing much of anything new they pretty much come through with the same sound that they've always had maybe there's a little more synthesizers in the mix but still the marionettes can come off a little one-dimensional at times even though that's the case and they kind of drown in their influences a little bit I do think this record has the most consecutively catchy and sharp and well-written tracks that the Marianas have put together so far from the start of the first track on this thing it becomes very clear that the marionettes are not a very modern band there is a huge sense of nostalgia that just bashes me over the head as I listened through this record which maybe was not as strong in their previous stuff they really kind of ham it up on this new album especially with some of the synth tones like for example the song evil coast once the bouncy echo guitars and the epic floor tom drumming and the chili synthesizers come in on this track it's 80s 80s 80s 80s and why a lot of these tracks are very basic and sort of straight forward in terms of just kind of a verse chorus verse sort of thing they're all beautifully produced the colors are really heavenly their blissful they're pretty on the ears and those definitely the marionettes will appeal to people who loved not just the cure but some of the more mainstream acts in New Wave music as well like when they track hit the waves the title track on this LP comes through the song is incredibly upbeat I love the hook on this thing hit the way it's honestly one of the best and sexiest pop grooves I've heard on a verse this year and it just totally screams like toto to me I'm feeling totally toto on this track the song years also was kind of a slow burner has a sensual sexy groove to it and yeah even though Phillips vocals sound just like Robert Smith's he hooks me in with his freaking refrains stay away stay on this record these guys are so diehard passionate about trying to recapture this old-school 80s synth-pop production sound it almost feels as true to detail as like an aerial pink tune but in this case there's no tongue in no cheek not a single ounce of irony leaks into any one of these songs they're all very heartfelt they're all very sincere don't forget don't forget however I do kind of feel that this LP mmm falls apart at the tail end to an extent through a handful of tracks they're really atmospheric and slow moving closer is pretty on the ears but kind of in underwhelming climax and a few other tracks like unblessed and can't stop the aching are jangle pop tunes jangle rock tunes but the melodies that they use the guitar leads on these tracks are just a little too obvious not only do the marionettes feel like they're ripping off the sounds of other bands on these particular tracks but they almost feel like carbon copies of songs are in the genre as well plus there is the issue that it's been a while since the band has put out their last LP and they've only managed to drum up really nine new tracks overall I did like this LP it was a fun sweet catchy pop album with just a lot of infectious a lot of contagious choruses a lot of nice grooves great production however the marionettes continue to drown in their influences and don't work with them in a way that feels refreshing or all that constructive really and at this point the question kind of comes up if this is always going to be the case for the marionettes I feel in a strong six to a light seven on this LP if you're into pop music if you're in a dream pop jangle pop you want something concise straightforward it's just going to hit you and stick in your head and then leave then give the Salma listen ok ok love you Anthony Fantana marionettes forever you

Future this is his third full-length LP a highly anticipated release a follow-up to his 2011 album Goblin at this point due to the saturation of hype which came out before goblin and came after goblin as well I'm going to assume you don't really need a history lesson on this guy but if there's one thing that I can say in retrospect because it's been two years since the release of goblin it's The Odd Future has really kind of been an integral part in this rising demand for alternative personalities and messages in popular hip-hop music yes Odd Future is not the only face in alternative hip-hop and they're definitely not the first and they're nowhere near my favorite but they are a favorite for a lot of people out there and if you actually listen a little bit deeper into Tyler's music past identity these are things that made bastards such an intriguing album though it wasn't the best produced album or the best rapped album however when Tyler put out Goblin in 2011 it seemed that a lot of the shadowy secrets and a lot of the intimacy sort of floated away in exchange for just Tyler's fame he was deafened in a way on wolf we see Tyler kind of regaining focus reaching back and grabbing once again at that darkness that made bastard an interesting album and on top of it the production is more ambitious too now like bastard and like goblin there's kind of a theme there's a progression as well as wolf and there are moments where Tyler seems to be kind of rapping just from the standpoint of himself not every track on this LP plays into the emotional theatre that Tyler has created it lives and destroying neighborhoods it kind of gets to him emotionally the closing track on this LP loan is a touching sad and heartfelt ode to the passing away of Tyler's grandmother he's got all these descriptions of being in the hospital dealing with this kind of pain and awkwardness in her final moments and I love the beat on this track which is really really jazzy but kind of has this elevator music quality as if it were being pumped out through speakers that were like in hospital ceilings or something like that in the hallway the song Colossus is essentially Tyler's version of the mmm song Stan he's dealing with just over excited fans who were obsessed over him maybe for all the wrong reasons and feel like they loved him when they really don't understand that much about him and some of the weirder experiments on this LP actually go over pretty well - like the song - male which has this weird clunky heavy world beat influence instrumental and this weird female vocal sample beat kind of reminds me of like what I would hear on an m.i.a album and Tyler lyrically delivery wise comes off as really brash offensive entertaining just colorful some of the other risks that Tyler takes don't go over so amazingly though like this on a tree home which has a pretty nice vocal contribution from Erykah Badu not one of her best but even though I like the jazzy sort of neo-soul vibe of this track I'm not really into some of the cornelius on this thing but I have to say maybe my least favorite part in this entire LP is the party's over campfire Beamer medley toward the middle of the album party isn't over and campfire just meander too much they sort of gets thrown in together to kind of add to this storyline that Tyler wasn't really riding all that hard up to this point anyway and instrumentally lyrically they're not that interesting Beamer is the best song out of the three and I feel like the first two songs wouldn't even be listened to if B her weren't thrown at the end of them but generally I don't even think Beamer is that good of a track the instrumental the tune the beat is okay but I think a lot of the trashy woman car comparison metaphors are well I said trashy overall I liked wolf honestly I thought it was a decent album though the highlights on this album are high it's kind of spotty too there are tracks on here that meander or just really kind of feel like filler and Tyler is clearly not interested at least at this point anyway and improving his technical abilities as a rapper because a lot of his flows on some of these tracks can be kind of awkward despite the fact that they may be heartfelt and very emotive the instrumentals are a definite improvement the feature list is pretty impressive and getting people like Erykah Badu and even Letitia Sater on your album is I'm feeling a strong 6 to a light 7 on this thing if you've given it a listen what did you think of it did you love it hate it why what do you think I should review next and that's it Anthony Fantana Tyler the Creator forever

you see waves of blue hi everyone Anthony Fantana here internet's busiest music nerd and it's time for your review of the new waves LP of afraid of heights you don't know how high I am up here you don't know I could be 4 stories up for all you see waves is the musical project of singer songwriter guitarist Nathan Williams and Nathan and this project blew up around the 2008-2009 time period when lo-fi Rock Garage and pop music was kind of in it's craze stage this LP featured a lot of garage rock and punk tunes that a very poppy personality to them but there were shrill blankets of distortion and over modulation covering almost every single track not to mention the pretty obnoxious vocal effects that Nathan would occasionally put on his voice on some of these songs I guess this point in time is not that long ago but it feels like it was so long ago especially when you sort of look at Nathan's musical evolution since this LP and the thing is the transition didn't really take that long to happen it was as early as 2009 that Nathan Williams was putting out tracks that were pretty well recorded with the one and only Zach Hill on drums and by the time 2010 came around Nathan dropped king of the beach which was essentially it sounded to me like a studio recorded album and I guess she could say relatively his songwriting was getting a little more ambitious now with this new LP Nathan's personality stays relatively the same pretty much everything you have heard up until this point it's not really a big surprise what is sort of the kicker here is the mix of influences because afraid of heights incorporates way more elements of grunge and alternative rock the production on this LP is way heavier the drums are punchy er the guitars and bass meld together in this really thick resonant way the entire makeup of this album sonically sounds scary alike to Nirvana nevermind truthfully which I guess is not all that surprising for a guy who wrote a song called I want to meet Dave Grohl and the album Nevermind has not just influenced this album sonically but from a songwriting standpoint as well the song dog on this LP there are moments especially in the acoustic guitars and the chord progression that sound eerily alike that of Polly and the explosion of slacker guitar riffs on the hooks of particular songs on this LP like that's on me sound very nevermind desk as well there is a very clear breadcrumb trail of influences throughout this LP like for example the verses on the track beat me up sound eerily alike that of where Eagles dare by The Misfits now even with this huge embrace of Nirvana's Nevermind waves still stays pretty true to its sound its personality its ethos with all of these the repetitive lyrics the simple vocal melodies as well though I guess if there's anything that is a change to this album narrative ly afraid of heights is actually way more in tune with Nathan's more emotional side his more depressed side which I actually kind of liked hearing on his previous full-length LP with tracks like take on the world where you had Nathan dissecting his musical abilities saying that he hates all of his writing and hates all of his music because it all sounds the same and that dissection continues on a much deeper level on this new LP with a track like demon to lean on and the title track on this LP which has severe feelings of loneliness coming through the hook moments of insecurity and self deprecation continue on other tracks on here like paranoia and I can't dream however with this slight change in Nathan's tune I still can't really say that he's matured all that well as a songwriter I have to still kind of agree with the statement he made about his writing sounding the same on the song take on the world and I guess a lot of the though Nathan's singing and his songwriting style does have a certain personality you know a wave song when you hear it this is the first LP I've heard where I really kind of feel like it's more of a crutch than a help to his cause because it's made so many of the songs on this help he just sound so homogeneous and what's weird is that Nathan seems to be very conscious of this weakness but he seems to embrace it as opposed to fix it and maybe that's because he loves his flaws in the way that he finds inspiration from them for songwriting material which is very clear from a lot of the subject matters on this LP however I don't really buy Nathan as a depressing singing songwriting sad-sack because while I'm sure that Nathan has legitimately sad feelings that do bother him I don't think you could argue that he conveys them all that well or all that poetically or passionately on a lot of these songs at least in a way where it makes the listener feel for him or even relate to him in a way none of you will ever understand me there are rarely any spots on this LP where I feel like Nathan says anything that's significantly deep or moving or even twisted even as Nathan is throwing out imagery of a gun to his head you know there are some things that I really liked about this LP overall the production is great the energy is there though this album is waves cleanest production yet it still rocks what ends up getting me down at the end of the day is the songwriting the lyrics the vocal melodies as well as just some of the hooks are so shallow and so Sammy Sammy that many of them are just completely unmemorable though not really terrible or offensive to the point where I want to turn off the album still I can't really say I disliked or hated this album it was just sort of a fun poppy rock record with a kind of heavy grunge sound I'm feeling a strong five to a light six on this thing if you've given it a listen what did you think of it did you love album huh yeah well that's not annoying waves afraid of heights forever [Music] [Music]

lappa lux that's all she hi everyone Anthony Fantan over here Internet's busiest music nerd and it's time for a review of the new lappa Lux LP nostalgic lappa Lux is an electronic music producer based in the UK I first ran into his music last year through an EP that came out early in the year titled when you're gone came out on brain feeder records and this new full-length album of his which he has worked up the courage to assemble and release is also on brain feeder records now when you're gone compiled a bunch of different electronic music styles together current electronic music styles like wonky as well as future garage maybe a slight baby itty-bitty bit of R&B and stylistically it was just a little inconsistent kind of jumping around all over the place AZ and a handful of tracks on this EP I thought were produced maybe a little too densely to the point where nothing really stuck out in terms of a groove or a melody or really anything interesting because there are so many interesting things are just so many very good sounds all sort of buzzing at once I thought that this new album and when you're gone it's maybe not a night and day difference it was maybe more of like a night and Dawn difference the biggest change on this new collection of tracks lappa Lux organizes his sounds so much better on this LP resulting in most of these songs sounding much more well orchestrated there are clear grooves awesome synth variations that come through and translate very well and what's also awesome is that this album seems to kind of pile on even more genres of music and still manages to come through sounding pretty good not too disjoint it or anything like that because a good couple of tracks on this thing embrace a very awesome alternative R&B sound and the overall result on this record is just an album that sounds blissful psychedelic there is one though on this LP that caught me as being sort of lappa lux letting his maximal tendencies kind of get the best of him the song Kelly broke it catches my attention definitely with how dense it is but I'm still not sure what to make of the song really with all the pitch shifted vocals on this thing and the slow synth funk melodies it does feel oddly sexy but I still can't help but feel like I'm listening to some kind of vapor wave bastardization of the soul glow add jingle another track that kind of kicks off this LP a track that was dropped before this LP came out girl it kind of brings the title of this album home the Stahl chic it's definitely got an 80s vibe to it I felt almost a Peter Gabriel toto kind of thing coming from the synthesizers with the way that they were shaped in terms of a groove and just the tone of them the sound of them but still has a song the beat a progression the sequence it doesn't really hook me it doesn't really grab me honestly this song kind of had me not anticipating that much from this LP when I first heard it aside from a very pretty opener on this album a nostalgic is kind of off to a rocky start thankfully it gets pretty awesome pretty quick right after these songs the song one thing which has a vocal contribution from Jana Andrews is an awesome track and awesomely smooth and sensual psychedelic R&B flavored slow jam not only does he make space for her very beautiful and emotive voice on this song but he surrounds it in sounds that make it feel like it's from an entirely different solar system I actually think the aura the sonic aura this track rivals some moments on the one-and-only kozma grandma there's another R&B flavored track later on the LP with Carrie Latham on vocals and while it is not as Spacey or as I guess intergalactic it's a little more serene and subdued it's really kind of the same strengths but on an entirely different track and with some interesting future garage inspired vocal cuts sort of peppered throughout the song and yes on this album once again future garage music does show up as a prime influence but I feel like honest Shiekh lappa Lux does a better job of combining it with his sort of brain feeder records nature and style because on the song flower you get these burial s focal cuts and chops against this very thick weird bass heavy walk EB and the vocal melody on this thing is absolutely earner infectious and lappa looks pretty much trips through this album consistently with different variations of this wonky future garage combo along with some slower prettier vocal led jams but he brings a few more surprises toward the end of the LP the song walking worlds on this album is is easily just some synthesizer led art pop I love the electric piano on this track the way it skips along on the groove and the very shy vocals with the melody that they're singing that seems very lullaby esque there's also some vocals on the outro track on this thing as well which brings up another surprise with sort of an acoustic guitar right at the start of the song that sounds like it was recorded on like a tape recorder or something there's a bit of a tape hum and lap luck starts to chop up all of these chunks of the guitar playing and the the vocals whether it be during the take that I'm hearing or through some other take that was recorded later in this vocal recording with the guitar and he turns it into a beat itself and it's a fantastically cinematic closer overall I really liked this LP I thought it was easily and improvement past what lap looks did on when you're gone last year not only is it more consistent all the influences that he takes on are brought together in a more interesting and unique away most of the vocal led tracks on this album are fantastic really great intros and outros just a lot of highlights still there are a few issues on this thing with hi everyone Anthony Fantana here Internet's busy piaced music nerd and it's time for a review of the new Cuellar Talk LP Mir which is the latest sophomore LP from a Norwegian metal outfit I reviewed him a while back on the channel back when I had the tree intros really getting nostalgic missing the tree I just got to do this fella talk yeah that might just be the way we do things from now on again this band's full-length debut LP came out in 2010 and at the time it turned a lot of heads in the metal world thanks to some pretty hefty endorsements from artists like Dave Grohl some fantastic production from converges Kurt blew some beautiful cover art from John Baisley of Baroness and of course touring with torch and converge helped along with some of their popularity in the States too but more than anything what grabbed attention for capella talk was their sound a combination of vocals that felt inspired by black metal as well as punk music the tremolo picked leads and the minor chords strummed quickly as well as blast beats totally came from the world of black metal and on top of that a ton of melody coming from the worlds of heavy metal as well as rock and roll not only was this LP awesome had a lot of detail and a lot of replay value but the enjoyment of it is so damn instantaneous it's infectious now the band is back again with this sophomore full-length mirror and they are catchy ER and more melodic than ever and I can understand them wanting to turn up the melody on this LP turn up the hooks because they certainly are what kind of separated them from a lot of other metal acts in 2010 and as a result I do think this album is maybe a little less extreme a little less pummeling and aggressive but it's not like the album goes so far into accessibility that it loses its punch even as the band lays some cleanly some vocals over some very just harsh black metal chords and the opening track here and on the song brain bren which was one of the lead singles from this LP and has an incredibly melodic chorus the production on this LP overall feels pretty much the same which isn't necessarily a bad thing on the last record and this record the guitars the drums the vocals all sound really muscular they're clean they're BBB beefy there's a lot of clarity there and what I find to be so awesome on this album is that the production complements all of the influences all the ingredients this LP so well of course the band is working with Kurt Balu again and he with the group makes sure that the black metal parts are are fast and pummeling that the guitar chords being strummed really faster sharp they make sure that the rock-and-roll and heavy metal riffs have a nice groove to them and that the rich and melodic solos and leads just shine out past the rest of the distortion and the overpowering drums nothing really gets lost in translation as the band speeds up to play something more in a hardcore punk vein and the acoustic guitar which the group uses a lot more on this album feels really warm and sticks out nicely so Feller talk on this new LP their style they're recording pretty much stays intact it's still really good but in terms of songwriting and performance I would say the band delivers once again impressively though some people can definitely say that this LP feels like a sequel to the debut there are some clear moments of ambition on this LP not only does it have a really big introduction a clearer and more interesting flow to the tracks some really long songs as well one that's almost nine minutes the opening track on this LP starts off with sort of an ominous drone that builds up the guitars are just rising and rising and rising in the band eventually breaks into this black metal stick and there are all these really righteous melodies attached to these black metal chords it feels so just uplifting in a way the second track on this LP to play places more major chord melodies against black metal chords and drums of course there are plenty of rock-and-roll riffs throughout this track and the very end of the song there's this awesome guitar flourish ending the track out that feels like I'm listening to the finish of some kind of Southern Fried rock-and-roll tune something like Creedence Clearwater Revival inspired in a way it's moments like this that make me feel like yeah the band really works with a combination of different things but they somehow do them all justice and bring them all together in a way that doesn't feel that corny maybe it might feel like a sort of a bastardization to a purist for any of these genres but the accurate melodic references and the playing definitely shows that valor talk has at least a passionate appreciation for a lot of the things that they're emulating now there are some moments on this LP like the track trip Han which honestly don't really bring that much novelty to the table and just kind of feel like I really heard this from cellar talk before and even though overall I do think valor talk stays in their comfort zone on this LP they still managed to bring just a little bit of extra variety like the tractor which in the middle of it all of these guitars fly in they have sort of a middle-eastern Egyptian vibe to them and go on a pretty awesome instrumental interlude right before the band kind of heads back into yet another black metal inspired verse now toward the end of this LP there's three tracks right next to each other and they are kind of the lengthy trifecta on this album all of the long songs just bunched together and they range from this six to almost nine minute range and these tracks on the album might actually be my favorite I'm not going to spoil every single detail in all of these songs but it's here that I really feel like feller talk proves that they're not just a one-trick pony in terms of writing a short song that just kind of hits you and runs and throws a few catchy hooks at you because a lot of these songs just build up epicly with black metal inspired interludes noisy solos quieter parts loud climaxes and all these tracks especially the longest of the three just stay engaging throughout the closing track on this LP is titled after the band it's a bit of an anthem and maybe the catchiest on the entire LP it really sort of brings all the elements to the table that define valor talk as a musical act it sort of has this edginess of hardcore punk and black metal but is just so rich with melody and an awesome hook that it feels like it's almost got an arena rock kind of vibe to it at this point in terms of the sound that the band has on this album Mir is not incredibly revolutionary but I got to say color talk did hell of a performance a hell of a recording some really good songwriting and they put together a really interesting arc for this album resulting in an album I think is maybe a little more cinematic for me personally this album is on par in nearly every way with the debut though I do think that some people may not necessarily jump on top of it as excitedly because at this point Fela talk is no longer a fresh face in music or the metal world in general I'm feeling a decent discriminate on this thing if you've given it a listen what did you think of it did you love it did you hate it why what do you think I should review next and yeah that's it Fowler talked Muir forever [Music] [Music]

hi everyone Anthony Fantana here internet's busiest music nerd and it's time for your review of the new bonobo LP the north borders bonobo is a uk-based electronic music producer who blew up a bit in 2010 thanks to his full-length album black sands which came after a pretty steady stream of full-length albums and EPS which reached back to the early 2000s and even though black sands was sort of the entry point for a lot of people to bonobos music bonobos style was pretty well established by that point bonobo typically puts out very subtle shellacked and groove based electronic music it's very beat heavy sometimes very downtempo and slightly hip-hop influenced and the progressions of the tracks that he creates tend to be a little more hypnotic than they are climactic now considering in 2010 that other popular electronic music albums were caribou swim as well as for tetes there is lovin you the climate the musical climate was definitely ripe for an album like black sands however I can't really say the black sands was resonating all that deeply for me on a personal level the downtempo and trick pop sounds that would pop up on this LP the micro house influences as well just very minimal simple and Airy spacious grooves that it was putting forward and the occasionally jazzy undertones of some of these songs to me the songs on this LP just felt very pretty very relaxing and that's all I can really say about them and maybe that's all that bonobo was really trying to go for however I can see very clearly that bonobo is getting a little more ambitious on this new album bonobos music on the North borders still feels very beat driven it's very serene it's very understated but the sounds definitely feel a little more vast the atmosphere is a little bit bigger and the vocal guest that he brings on to sing on a handful of the songs on this hour-long LP are a little more impressive in terms of performance and and name wise too because he does managed to nail a feature from the one and only Erykah Badu on this album as well as some lesser-known who give some very good contributions as well I have to say on this album bonobo continues to display the beauty that was always there in his music but it's turned up a little louder on the North borders a little to the point where it can occasionally become aunt inspiring like the opening track on this album which has a vocal contribution from grey Reverend who I had not heard of before this track and man am i sad about that that that because his voice sounds beautiful on this song he sings wonderfully or this very delicate instrumental which has this sort of rolling snare on the start of it and the way that it builds up it feels almost like a post rock song until the beat really kind of kicks in with this very low and subtle bass in a way this point in the song kind of feels like a drop but it's not drop into like oh let's rage it's more like let's ah the strange synthesizers the thumb piano the strings on this track it's all beautiful as far as the other vocal features on this LP go of course Erykah Badu's song is a complete standout her very sort of nasally odd vibrato voice is very calming and it's seductive on this track and slides into bonobos style just perfectly and this track is wonderfully colored with awesome strings some harp it's very much electronic music but on songs like this bonobo breaks that mechanical feel that typically comes with this genre and just lays on layer upon layer upon beautiful layer to the point where you're hearing something that sounds not electronic but very organic in my opinion bonobo really steps up his production game on this album when it comes to a song that features a guest vocalist even one of the tracks in the middle of this LP Towers which doesn't have the best vocal contribution on the entire LP still sounds beautiful because the vocal is complemented so well it's really just cradled lovingly in all of this awesome guitar these watery scents and again more ascending instrumentation which just makes me feel like I'm floating on a cloud however other tracks on here that don't feature vocals like m'kay and and Sapphire for example while they're not terrible songs they just kind of feel like passable tolerable future garage inspired productions that I would have in no way been able to guess where bonobos if my life depended on it even the song no you which has a slightly harder groove to it is kind of breezy and forgettable as well I know that bonobo doesn't want to make hard aggressive fast music that just hits the listener but I feel like there's a line separating subtle music and just forgettable music I think the only instrumental tracks on this LP that I really enjoyed were 4:1 Cirrus which I hope I'm pronouncing earlier it was the first song that was dropped before the release of this LP I love the way that bonobo uses space the thumb piano and this really undeniable groove on this track to make a song that is just hypnotic and the song don't wait has a sort of similar quality to it as well with some nicely placed vocal samples chopped and chopped and chopped in but I just feel like this level of detail doesn't show up everywhere clearly from listening to this album bonobo has very good taste in vocalist he has this ability to maybe expose some vocalists that can give great performances that maybe people wouldn't have heard of otherwise and when he works with some great vocalists there are some real flares of ambition and beauty on the north borders however many other tracks on here the instrumental tracks especially I can't really say there anything much more than just Pleasant and on top of that I just feel like there weren't enough to warrant an entire hour of music on this album but here's another opinion hey everyone you're number one calleman here capture Cheston here to say is sometimes Anthony doesn't know what he's doing you know here's the sang and maybe a nice sang but he's like yeah yeah when anthony hears sweetness sometimes he don't get it so that's all I gotta say that's it ooh if you do like your beats if you do like your electronic music a little quieter a little more subtle maybe you dig on producers such as nutria beasts as well as slum Oh bit of burial as well you may totally dig on this LP but just don't expect bonobo to be as gloomy or as experimental I'm feeling a decent two strong six on this LP if you've given it a listen what did you think of it did you love it hate it why what do you think I should review next and that's it bonobo the North borders forever [Music] you [Music]

snide vocals the blaring guitars fans of other Aussie garage rock acts like eddy current suppression ring could totally get into what this album has to offer but the slower tracks on here that are a behind Gareth's vocals just increasing the intensity and the tension of the story he's telling which has imagery of stepping into our swamp and the chorus on this track is just explosive it's bombs songs on this LP which were lead singles like how to see through fog while I did like this track is a hook to initially listen to this LP it just feels like a morsel compared to some of the other just spots on here like they'll kill you which are very explosive but the tune is just not there the vocals melodically meander in a way that is not memorable at all thankfully these two tracks are like the biggest missteps on the LP after these songs the track the gray leader drops this really heavily emotionally potent ballad in three things just feels so rickety they feel so noisy they feel like they're just barely being held together but things sort of clean up in a way after this instrumental interlude pops in quickly after the first third of the track it introduces this guitar riff which just explodes and soars over this very down in the dumps song and it feels in a way kind of Pink Floyd Ian and the end of the song with Gareth screaming these mantra-like lyrics nothing will ever change your mind he feels so hopeless at this point in the track especially with how he is freaking out vocally on the song the next track like a I hope I'm pronouncing that correctly but I think the nine-minute track is just a killer killer and sad depressing ballot and the perfect ending I actually think that's one of the more cinematic closing tracks I've heard this year it's kind of a piano led track and Gareth really lets his lyrics stand out on this song singing about how people don't really write letters anymore but my friend wrote something like a letter the other day and let me tell hi everyone Anthony Fantana here internet's busiest music nerd and it's time for a question comment thing haven't done one of these in a while asking what you guys think of hype you know buzz it's like when you go on the internet and you're looking for music and it seems like no matter where you turn people are talking about this artists doing this thing in this album and it's everywhere it's on TV it's on the it's on the radio it's on every single blog you visit I'm even talking about it maybe right now in the major musical media sharing internet age where we have things like Harlem shake and Yonkers and little B we have this ability to totally make something like I guess sort of an overnight sensation an artist can just be totally buzzed off of the heat of one single song or music video and I want to know if in your opinion this is a good or bad thing not only for the artists that is getting buzzed or getting hyped is it a good thing for music fans musical listeners the music listeners win out at the end of the day because this sort of seems to be a regularly recurring thing is this good for the music industry as a whole now in my opinion this kind of hype this kind of overnight sensation whether it be through sharing mp3's or whether it be through just views on YouTube something like that it does show to me that in a way people do have choice and the people do have power to kind of force the trends that resonate most with them as opposed to like a trend being handed down to us via a record label or something like that no matter how you feel about the buzz of artists like Kendrick Lamar or Odd Future for example they did kind of have a pretty naturally occurring fan base underneath them before they kind of rocketed into superstar television record label type Fame however as we all know deafening hype or you're just hearing an artist all the time everywhere they're collaborating with everyone featuring they're putting out records that are topping the charts it can kind of you know attract some haters but aside from that another issue is that we all know that for every one single Kendrick Lamar there are ten other artists that may get the same bump of hype that Kendrick did at the start but for some reason or another they totally get mulled over and we never hear from them again or we hear from them again and it just seems that this time around nobody really cares even artists that are more well-established and on major record labels and have an album release that comes out and maybe is successful or semi successful it's not like they're hyper their buzz is gonna last that long past the release of their album like take Justin Timberlake for example right now his LP is really really hot right now but think forward to next month or even the month after that people are gonna completely forget about it and think about buzzing over the AAS or Daft Punk who have a new LP coming out in May Kid Cudi as well and just any number of artists who seem to have some kind of crossover listener base with Justin it's just one hype cycle after another and it seems like right now in terms of the whole music industry that this is the most profitable model that we have going for us in the internet age with record sales following with piracy rising while I guess right now we do have more choice and more variety as listeners the thing is that a lot of record labels will totally jump down I mean really desperately pounce upon the hype of an artist without really considering things like talent or work ethic or stability within the music industry take an artist like Kreayshawn for example not only did it take her too long to come out with her new full-length after the buzz over her single goochy goochy but the thing is a lot of the hype wasn't necessarily translating into pure fandom which resulted in extremely lackluster sales of something about Cray when originally drop only selling several thousand copies you've got azealia banks as well who took much too long to come out with a full-length after - one - dropped plus some volatility with a lot of her twitter fights it really all kind of built up to getting dropped from her label and as much as I am a fan of these guys Death Grips as well knowing they're kind of angry noted sort of renegade style and how much their fan base sort of questioned them moving to Epic Records you know I think some people could see that there was a storm a-brewin with the whole NOLA Deep Web thing so is all this hype just blowing up artists we've never heard of before left and right really helping the listener is it exposing us to stuff that we would have never heard of otherwise exciting stuff or is it drowning out albums that are really more worthwhile and from the artists perspective are these hype cycles making careers or are they really breaking them because like I said earlier for every one artist that we can point at that has made a successful career out of their initial surge of hype there are many others who sort of seem to get bulldozed over and thrown under the bus because people don't really care about their next release or don't really care about their first release by the time their hot debut single is is no longer relevant or popular plus if you're an artist who gets a lot of hype in one of these hot new micro genres that people make a big deal over like chillwave or alternative R&B or which house to come out with a full-length a debut full-length that is just really popular but to want to change directions on your next album considering the fly-by-night fans that sometimes come with hype cycle some people might not be that receptive of your new direction and just want to kind of hear something that sounds like what initially got them hooked on your stuff so again hype is it good or bad is it good or bad for musicians is a good or bad for the industry is a good or bad for the listener and what separates an artist to successfully hi everyone Anthony Fantana here the Internet's busiest music nerd and it's time for a review of the new David Bowie LP the next day oh hey David Bobby David Bowie is a songwriter multi-instrumentalist producer and this is his 24th studio album amazing fantastic and his first studio LP in ten years and when it comes to living rock stars there are a few who are as big and as relevant and as impactful as David Bowie the dude supported great musical acts produced a few awesome records and made plenty of classic albums himself I'm not gonna get too deep into this guy's trajectory his back story his back catalog because I just rather get into this new album because this new album is worth talking about in a recent video I talked a little bit about David Bowie's new track that he dropped before this album where are we now it kind of underwhelmed me was feeling a little met on the track and I made a comment on the song saying that yeah while it didn't move me I'm not really expecting an immensely amazing piece of music from David Bowie at this point in his career anyway he's pretty much come out with his amazing records already he's made his impact on music what does he really have to prove at this point this statement confused some people didn't really understand why I would feel that way but considering how tame I felt that this new track was it just didn't feel like to me that David Bowie was planning to over reach his abilities in any way on this new album truth be told the next day is actually a really pleasant surprise especially considering how underwhelming David Bowie's last full-length LP was musically and cover art fully now is the cover our there's a new album any better well I mean it is kind of lazy but mmm at least it's trying to make some kind of statement a statement that becomes a bit clearer once the album is listened to and maybe a few fantastically classic albums from David Bowie's catalog now what goes on with this new David Bowie LP contextually actually reminds me of an album from another alternative rock star Lou Reed the blue mask came out in 1982 and on the blue mask Lou Reed took a long hard look at some of his past albums that were great but he went about it in a way where he tried to recreate this magic in a more mature way without being as wild or was reckless or as I guess swanky as he typically was and there are references to this newfound maturity in the lyrics as well a musing about the dulling of his his wild side I feel like this issue is also kind of attacked and discuss on this new David Bowie LP particularly on the song the stars are out tonight although David Bowie seems to be singing more about this kind of complacency coming from being famous being set stars and celebrities who are sexless and uh neuron stantly being thirsted after by the public but themselves personally very broken up on the inside and dysfunctional and the music video itself for the song seems to portray this mundaneness that typically gets attached to everyday life so there is definitely a sharpness to some of the lyrical themes that are on songs on this LP the track where we now seems to have a bit of a personal sentimental feeling to it for David Bowie and on top of this there are other moments on this album that feel just like classic David Bowie glamorous poppy rock songs like Valentine's Day or you feel so lonely you could die which is an awesome ballad in three four the title track on the cell Pete has some really punchy heroes flavor drumming on it the song if you can see me showcases that are rock side of David Bowie that occasionally pops up and and shows that it's very much intact with some very fast-paced drums weird abstract vocals and some odd synthesizers bouncing all over the place over the years David Bowie has showcased a lot of different personas personalities and on this new LP he shows that there for the most part pretty alive and well there's a lot of evidence on this LP that David Bowie is still very much in tune with many of his best moments in his back catalogue and a lot of the time he does seem to channel that energy especially with awesomely spunky tracks like the title track and really emotive vocal deliveries on the stars are out tonight which is really one of the major moments on this album when it comes to age not really having an audible effect on David's voice but there are a lot of songs here on the cell P that I mean it kind of feels like time has not really been that big of a friend to David Bowie when it comes to his performance and artists like Doctor John comes off really freaking raspy and his recent stuff and Bobby Womack sounds fantastically emotive on on his new LP as well and Scott Walker completely whacked but amazing unfortunately in the case of David Bowie he no longer seems up for making those grand flamboyant over-the-top vocalizations that would typically make his song so emotive and powerful though I will say the really solid Tunes that are throughout this album they make his voice tolerable and at least the production is kind of a saving grace it gets the job done all the instrumentation the bass the guitar the drums the extra keyboards as well with the last track a bit of string work to it all sounds pretty nice the only downside about the production is that occasionally it feels a little tame and David's voice I mean it clearly tries to compensate for it at times by burying it a little bit if there's any other issue that I have with the production on this LP it's that at times it can have a little bit of an edge Liszt's adult contemporary feel to it very just mundane sounds coming from songs like where are we now as well as I'd rather be high those songs to me just have no guts whatsoever there are other tracks that are more interestingly colored instrumentally like dirty boys a song that in terms of a beat kind of lurches forward has these heavy chunky horns blaring and blurting throughout the track the only issue for me with this song and maybe a few others on here is that it ends a little abruptly and structure-wise it's it's kind of skeletal for a David Bowie song a lot of songs on here feel a little bare-bones actually not really reaching for some of the supreme lengths or the big climaxes that would typically be at the finish of an amazing David Bowie song if there's any other major issue that I have with this LP it's that there are a few what-the-fuck moments which you know is kind of a typical thing for some David Bowie albums and it's kind of hard for me to bury some of these moments into the back of my head considering that in comparison with other David Bowie LPS the next day isn't really incredibly cutting edge or graceful I'm talking about tracks like dancing out in space which in terms of subject matter and hook I'm just like huh and I have no clue what's going on with the background vocals on the track does the grass grow at least the LP ends pretty well with the track key which seems like this really dismal spacious new-age inspired epilogue to the entire LP the previous track really seems like more of a proper finisher for this LP whereas the song he seems to be this more abstract self analyzation for David Bowie this album could have been maybe a little bit better if some of the songs were longer and a little more fleshed out and if the production was just a little more creative outside of that I think we're dealing with a pretty good album here I'm feeling a light two decent seven on this LP if you've given it a listen what did you think of it did you love it hate it why what do you think I should review next and yeah that's about it David Bowie the next day forever [Music]

hi everyone Anthony Fantana here Internet's busiest music nerd and it's time for your review of the new strokes album comedown machine The Strokes are a New York indie rock and pop rock band whose full-length debut album is a perfect or a near-perfect album for very many people the band's debut LP is this is loaded with extremely concise catchy and sharp as hell rock tunes that stick into the back of your head with magic ear worm guitar leads great beats and of course Julian Casablancas hisses trade mark Kroon the band's sophomore full-length LP further solidified their place as a worthwhile act in modern rock but in my opinion things kind of went south around the time of their third full-length LP and unfortunately for others things when even further south when the band put out the album angles just a couple years ago which is kind of a polarizing LP for a few different reasons contextually because when the band reconvened kind of came back from their hiatus to start putting out music together again Julian Casablancas said in an interview with Brian missile on NBC News that pretty much the band got back together because of the money but the LP is also polarizing because on angles The Strokes started experimenting with their sound in a really big way they started using more synthesizers incorporating elements of New Wave music which were really huge players when Julian Casablancas came out with a solo full-length and just overall they were distancing themselves from that original sound that people kind of grew up loving from The Strokes I personally really liked the diversity the angles brought to the table and I was also hoping that that would be a really likable factor on this new LP as well especially considering how much of a surprise the track one way trigger was when originally came out not a perfectly executed song but the acoustic guitar and the really bouncy synthesizers as well and Julian Castle mrs. freakin falsetto vocals on that track a lot of people were comparing it to aha steak on me which I don't really see at all I mean I think the fact they have an explosive course that has a falsetto on it that's really the only thing that you know feels similar to me between those two tracks however that's not to say that The Strokes don't have really clear influences on this new LP on other tracks they most certainly do for one new wave is still a pretty big influence on many songs on comedown machine the song welcome to Japan has a really huge disco backbeat on the track the opening song on this LP tap out with the guitar Lee it's been an intended then it did then the guitars on this track are a dead ringer for at least a couple different Michael Jackson songs and on the song 50/50 The Strokes had never sounded so Punk if angles was a sign of The Strokes kind of letting go of their inhibitions which were penning them into their original style then come down machine is a sign of them dropping them almost completely I guess The Strokes kind of went into this LP with a problem and that problem is that they want a different sound they want a different style they just want to do something different in general but for me the issue as a listener is that I don't really feel like they're all that picky with their solutions on paper is the idea of incorporating a falsetto vocal on many of these tracks a bad thing know however is Julian Casablancas is falsetto all that well some most of the time no it's it's not Julian's falsetto is very very off on a lot of these tracks to the point where it sounds kind of ridiculous especially on the closing track where the band was definitely sort of going for this vintage sentimental jazz style ballad that is very very little joy like it's like I'm listening to the recreation of some kind of song that I would hear playing through some old tube radio something like that but in my opinion the song kind of gets lost in its own nostalgia it hears what it wants to copy but it's not listening to itself because if it was it would hear how much of a mockery it is and the other track that the jerks drop before the release of this LP all the time which in my opinion is really the only song on this album that sounds like a traditional strokes song it feels completely flat lifeless it's really the only stroke song that I've ever heard that I would label as being almost completely soulless there are some tracks on here that I do think are just generally enjoyable though they may take on a little bit of influence somewhere else but at their core they feel like just nice catchy stroke songs tracks like tap out happy ending partners in crime slow animals as well these tracks are proof that The Strokes are still writing competent catchy pop rock songs that in a way I can kind of in the back of my head hear them play these tracks and they're older more traditional style and what's even worse than these very surface level changes is that a lot of the alterations The Strokes make to their songs it's not like they come off as versatile enough to actually execute well what they're going for they haven't refined a lot of these songs enough to the point where they don't sound silly like on the track slow animals where Julian's background and foreground vocals intertwine with one another in a really just lazy bad way or all of the weird talking sort of welcome to Japan sort of narrating vocals on the track welcome to Japan it turns the song into a bigger cornball than it already is and the title track on here could have used a bit of refinement as well it would have been a beautiful beautiful ballad had the band cut it down from a minute length and really just made it a bit punchier and in terms of punch I mean Julian isn't really there either emotionally though his falsetto vocals are there it's not like he comes off as I guess sort of bold as he usually does on this LP in comparison with previous strokes releases he's much more shy understated which is an angle that works for a lot of artists on a lot of albums but I don't find it to be particularly effective on this one you know overall I think the songwriting on this LP is is okay I mean it's it's what you would expect from The Strokes the songs are decent and the production overall is really good - aside from some ill placed vote effects and some vocals that feel drown now from time to time the guitar sound great the drums are punchy and clear the synthesizer sounds stellar I love what is that that organ on the title track on this LP - with the arpeggios the instrumentation sounds great and maybe that's really the only true saving grace that come down machine has going for it but the thing is the band ends up stubbing their toe on all these changes they want to make and it's not that the band wants to change in general that makes comedown machine a kind of week album it's that it doesn't really feel like they care if any of these changes sound good honestly there are moments when I listen to this album especially with the vocals that I feel like The Strokes are just kind of screwing around a little bit I'm kind of feeling a strong for - a light five on this LP if you've given it a listen what did you think of it did you love it did you hate it why what do you think I should review next and yeah that's it The Strokes comedown machine forever
