hi everyone Anthony Fantana here the Internet's busiest music nerd and it's time for a review of a new little EP from the band dope body Saturday these guys are a Baltimore band their 2012 album natural history was easily my favorite loud rock album of last year came out on Drag City Records and now they're following that full-length up with a little 7-inch EP two tracks on it really more of a single but they're calling in DP or the two tracks on this EP are titled Leatherhead and youth relic are they gonna be on a new full-length LP are they just kind of a thing of their own I'm the good dude addicted to this bands combination of psychedelic rock sludge metal as well as rock and roll with this sort of party hard Andrew W K attitude but kind of with a caveman like edge its guttural it's heavy and that's pretty much the overall impression that I'm getting from these two new tracks as well if there's any huge difference that will be apparent to dope body fans and listeners from just putting these tracks on first thing it's that the recording quality is a little bit different it can feel a little shoddy with how the drums are kind of overtaking the guitars here and there the vocals are swallowed in the mess the haze of all the chaos of the instrumentation a wee bit and there's some ambient sound around the drumming as well it's like this track was recorded in a basement or something with only a few microphones on hand still despite the fact that this is not the best recording no body has ever worked with they still bring their a game in terms of ferocity and energy and just bringing that heaviness that is really trippy and kind of surreal in terms of strangely shaped guitar riffs and odd guitar tones as to be expected these two tracks feel like a really sweaty party this pumping into the air losing control and awesome guitar grooves except maybe with this recording it doesn't feel as powerful maybe slightly dulled a bit now in regards to the track leather head it's got kind of an obvious riff groove and chord progression on the song then that definitely kind of gets stale by the end of the song I thought it's not exactly the most unique of riffs but the band really kind of dances this groove out with these 16th notes on the hi hats on the drums some really hefty kicks if anything saves this track it's that the band brings an explosive psychedelic Cooke has a lot of energy a lot of guts to it that I love I actually ended up enjoying the song youth relic a little bit more I liked that the song built up to a huge climax at the end the guitar leads were a little more interesting kind of diddling away with this really quirky melody that made the song feel maybe a slight bit nutty the throbbing bass line on this track is awesome as well I just love how this band is just so massively just heavy metallic sludgy cock rock just kicking ass all over the place but it's so blatantly psychedelic and experimental too dope body just has this knack for bringing together elements of weirdness abstractions but also just visceral and as long as they have that and they keep bringing surprises and good songs to the table maybe the recording quality is it going to be the most important thing in the world I am pretty much feeling a decent too strong 7 on this little EP dug it quite a bit it's more of a fan pleaser in in my opinion it's really not gonna pull anybody that is unfamiliar with dope body to the table in the way that I think that some of their full lengths will that's pretty much how I feel about the CP what do you think about it did you love it hate it why what should i review next and that's about it Anthony Fantana dope body forever

Hey it's track review hi everyone Anthony Fantana here internet's busiest music director and it's time for track reviews where we talk about the latest in rock pop electronic and experimental music of the independent persuasion and yeah in this video to brand freaking new tracks from Vampire Weekend they're coming from the band's forthcoming LP third full-length LP modern vampires of the city the songs are titled step and Diane young dying young it's acute play on words this band dropped their first full-length LP in 2008 rubbed me the wrong way ever so slightly wasn't really into the way that they were mixing all these indie pop elements with African music and ska music a little bit of reggae as well it felt a little hokey but when they came out with the album contra in 2010 I totally did a 180 on how I felt about the band's music I felt like these elements coming from music from various parts of the world that they wanted to incorporate into their albums were executed so much more tastefully the production was a little more interesting more textured better drums better synthesizers the songwriting in my opinion became a little more eccentric I thought Vampire Weekend was blossoming into just this very bold pop act they were showing personality and a lot of songwriting strength and that made contra one of my favorite albums of 2010 so now of course I'm excited to hear this new LP of theirs coming out in just about three years later modern vampires of the city it's gonna be dropping this May and the two tracks they've come out with from this LP I'll start with the song dying young great track proof that Vampire Weekend if anything can write a pop song that is completely accessible its melodic its lush it's fun it's multi-textured but it's also just really energetic and intense it's accessible it's fun and it's bright but it's fierce as well I think another example of them succeeding with this kind of formula is with a track like cousins the hard ass drum beats on this track some of which feel like they're coming from a drum machine hit really hard have a sharp punch to them I'm loving the way that Ezra is just all over his vocal range on this track with these ridiculous chorus vocals babe but the ban kind of feels like in a way they're copying this old rhythm and blues band kind of sound but doing it in this very new modern just fun playful kind of way especially considering they're using all these weird pitch shift effects on the vocals which I guess in a sense they were using on contra through auto-tune which really did not agree with me all too well on the track that they used it on but I'm actually feeling like the way that they're executing some of these pitch shifts on this particular track it's just way more experimental it's weird it's a lot more I guess smile inducing it's kind of funny in a way but it makes the song no less catchy occasionally popping up some very refined synth arpeggios if anything Vampire Weekend is is really great at writing pop songs that sort of hint at this sense of upper crust hmm snootiness in a way where it feels like they're simultaneously embracing it celebrating it but kind of you know making a mockery of it too by making pop music they just change gears instrumentally so often throughout this track and just keep it so high energy throughout it's an awesome couple of minutes I really really love this track I love the blaring horns or synthesizer horns on this song it's just got a lot of flavor - it's got a lot of punch now the next track on here that I have to talk about in this video step it's the slower of the two songs it's the longer the two songs it's the sentimental and tear-jerking ballot the lyrics here especially play again with that kind of privileged upper-crust kind of background ezra with the lyrics that he's singing though throws in this colloquial terminology like you know you're stepping to my girl or I'm gonna front and name-dropping things like Berkeley and then communist reader and in the previous track that I was just talking about living like the Kennedy talking about that Kennedy kind of lifestyle the way the Vampire Weekend mashes speech and cultures together from different classes in America um there's a lot of people see it as kind of tacky or offensive or a little I guess lacking in self-awareness but I actually think it's the exact opposite I think they bring all these things together in such a way where it just all kind of seems silly sort of in the same way that all of these snooty privileged and kind of sheltered characters in the Wes Anderson movie can seem kind of silly with their various personal dilemmas and actually I would have to say that listening to the lyrics in this song kind of feels like I'm reading through the script of a Wes Anderson movie and even though that may be the case and I do sense a little bit of a tongue-in-cheek this - what Ezra is saying in this track it doesn't change the fact that I feel that this song is is very romantic it's very sentimental and pretty clever at a lot of points - I love the hook on this track where Ezra says the gloves are off and the wisdom teeth are out and the amazing library says stale conversation deserves but a bread knife it just makes me maybe Azra flats the whole snobbish set thing a little too hard at times on this track talking about punks not being dressed for the weather but I love how slow this song moves and how refined a lot of the Arrangements around this track feel with all these Pachelbel inspired arpeggios dancing all around the track I really admire Vampire Weekend for bringing together all these elements that people do not necessarily assume on paper will work and then actually you know mix them and stack them into a really well-crafted pop tune despite the fact that Vampire Weekend's influences continue to be very very very obvious I think they're growing to be an even bolder pop outfit with these two songs that they've just dropped from this forthcoming LP because I feel like these songs really sort of play off of a lot of elements that I loved on contra but has refined them into something that sounds even better hopefully every track follows the level of quality that I've heard on these two tracks I love this track as well honestly that's really all I have to say about these two new Vampire Weekend tracks if you've given them a listen what did you think did you love them did you hate them why what do you think I should review next what are you thinking that this new Vampire Weekend LP will hold are you anticipating good things bad things let me know Anthony Fantana Vampire Weekend forever need a shave

hi everyone Anthony Fantana here Internet's busiest music nerd and it's time for a review of the new Ryan woman where I is a pop music duo who is responsible for a few of my favorite singles of 2012 and this is their debut full-length LP the two singles that drop before this LP open in the fall the songs that I love on this album that I heard before this album it seems rise pretty quick to place these songs right at the beginning of this new album and just follow it up with all this new material which I suppose sort of makes sense since these songs were the inception of rye in a sense but before these two songs existed rise two members were involved in other projects first Mike Melosh whose name I hope I'm pronouncing correctly is an electronic music producer he hails from Toronto he has a few albums under his belt who has an incredibly feminine voice and Robin iake is a singer and producer and they were both relatively under the radar until they came together with this project and songs like open we're getting a whole ton of buzz on the internet but what was interesting as they kind of put the name of the project and just the name ROI first before themselves and make no mistake rye has caught on because of the power of the songs that drop before this full-length album but still it definitely goes to show kind of the power of a fresh face musical elements of previous projects from Mike and Robin show up on this LP through electronic music soul music pop music as well but on here you're getting a much more refined take on these styles it's much more sophisticated there are moments that are very very baroque touched gently and lovingly with strings and horns there are moments where I'm hearing some jazzy woodwinds as well there are moments where it kind of reminds me of Jesse where a little bit or has a bit of that throwback flavor of the latest destroyer full-length and sort of gender bends in the way that perfume genius or today and the Johnsons sometimes do however in comparison to those two artists I will say that Riya is way more subtle way more soft just much more smooth and pleasant on the ears silky its buttery it's like fresh ice cream there is a certain kind of sexiness that right rise to push forward on on nearly every track here it's a youthful sexiness that is simultaneously unsure of itself at times feeling a little shy especially from the vocals it's basically the dorm room lovemaking soundtrack that will be pumped through many a laptop speaker for the duration of this year RIE is really good at conjuring sexy sensations but there are times when I feel like maybe they don't bring too much to the table other than that because when it comes to subject matter and sound and songwriting this LP can get a little Sammy Sammy and it's not necessarily because I feel like there's no talent here in this project I feel like there's an incredible amount of potential I just think that RIE can get a little lacks here and there on some of the songs because maybe the sensuality that they want to convey to their listeners come so easily there are some tracks where I sense some real ambition coming from this project like on the opening of the track open which ascends the album so high into the sky with horns and strings it's a beautiful introduction it's inspiring much more inspiring than some of these slightly lethargic dance grooves to come afterwards and the song the fall which I definitely think could have gotten away because it is such a good song could have gotten away with just putting the bass groove the drums and the piano out there and sticking with that instead RIE covers this song very sweetly wrapping it like a ribbon with strings and horns that pop up so subtly throughout the track it's beautiful now honestly these two tracks that start the album off are really as awesome as the album gets when it comes to this particular vibe I feel like there are a lot of songs that come afterwards that try to continue the same theme but to varying degrees of success like the song last dance which comes right after the song has all the synthesizer horns I think their synthesizer Lawrence they sound like it and in comparison to some of the horns that come on the previous tracks they feel so measly and when I have our voice on this track and others is interestingly androgynous you know definitely has a personality it has a sound and he is an able singer I mean he has no issue with pitch or anything like that his voice is pleasant but it's very rare that he actually pulls emotion from a place that feels really fiery or passionate the moment where you hear him saying make note to me that's like really about the fiery ISTE gets on the whole LP some of his vocalizations at the end of the track shed for blood which has this abrupt ending to it that I didn't really care for are nice but as some of the tracks on this help you get a little simpler get a little more stripped back instrumentally they're not as decked out in strings and horns no doesn't really fill in the gaps with any incredibly moving vocal performances he seems to be just as quiet sort of coloring things lightly just as if he were a piece of instrumentation in the background this doesn't lead to any terrible tracks on the LP but it just makes many of the songs here kind of agreeable breezy in one ear and out the other the only song that I really disliked was three days which had this synth groove to it and then them just not interesting enough to be replayed and replayed in the way that it was had a bit of blue-eyed soul to it a bit of disco to it the track I mean I actually prefer the beauty and the spaciousness of the song one of those summer days which heads away from the dance grooves it's just these lone guitar chords with just a little bit of sense dancing around in the background subtly and in comparison to some of the more sleek and sensual songs it's much sadder much more there's pretty on a track with this emotions and they've our very shy vocals go over so much better and my other favorite track on this LP has got to be the closer the title track which has these awesome progressive synth arpeggios all over the place it's like as inspiring as the opening track again it feels like I'm ascending but this time up into space the horns are stellar on this track - it's really wondrous ending it has the inspiring wonder that I wish was a little bit more consistent throughout this LP because I feel like I get hit in the beginning and I get hit again in the end and the whole trip in the middle is just not that memorable there is a lot of potential here this album is produced really well the singing is good the grooves are there but sometimes the songwriting and the vocal performances can be a little underwhelming I feel like Wray wants to appeal constantly to this very vague sense of steam eNOS it's like they want to get sexy without getting hot I'm really kind of feeling a light too decent six on this thing if you've given it a listen what did you think of it did you love it did you hate it why what do you think I should review next and that's it rye woman forever

hi everyone Anthony Fantana here the internet sleepiest music nerd and it's time for a sleepy little review of the new Autechre LP x i Autechre is an electronic music duo hailing from the UK who for decades have been creating everything from experimental techno to IDM glitch music and through the many full-length albums that shaun booth and Rob Brown have produced together over the years they have proven themselves to be extremely extremely creative and explorative personalities when it comes to the world of sound and sound manipulation and that applies both to percussion just the Tambor's the textures that these guys put together in their beats along with synthesizers which typically have a pretty phat analogue sound to them when Autechre is putting synth chords and melodies together and the way that these guys manipulate synthesizer sounds it's really somewhat of a lost art in my opinion something that was much more prevalent back in the 90s when a lot of people perceive Autechre to have been having their their musical heyday but what I feel that makes Autechre different than many other artists that are on a similar sonic journey is that their search for sounds their exploration for sounds tends to be extremely extremely methodical sort of like a chemist looking for the perfect amount of the right element to create the just right right right Chain Reaction for some kind of extremely complicated equation now the sounds and the textures that Autechre works with have evolved over the years sometimes deciding the overall path of entire full-length albums especially like a few of their most recent coarseness and oversteps both of which had a much more ambient and experimental feel to them in comparison to some of the more beat oriented work these two LPs also combine elements of glitch and IDM which typically show up in Autechre x' music but no matter how little or how greatly these guys change on a given full-length one thing kind of remains the same it remains constant and that is the emotional quality of their music rarely is aught ecers music very visceral or visceral in the way that we typically see visceral music it doesn't get your blood pumping it doesn't get you thrashing about like a punk song would or you know really hard hip-hop beat would or a metal song would or like a dubstep song or even a traditional techno song instead Autechre shoot for something that is much more cerebral much more thought-provoking something that is going to attract extremely analytical listeners like flies to a dead corpse and those extremely analytical listeners may be very pleased by the challenge that Autechre presents to them on this new LP which is two discs and two hours long I'm sure hardcore fans will completely soak this album up but Excise is not for your casual or maybe even first-time Autechre listener possibly for the most part Autechre is sticking to a lot of the same genre confines that people place them into the glitch the IDM the experimental or avant-garde techno a touch of ambient music - they constantly look for new and different sounds to engage the listener with on one track after another through this 17 song affair however there's not an immense amount of emotional variation throughout this LP there are some tracks that stand out past others in the fact that they may feel a little bit sweeter through some synthesizer chords others like the opener on here have a bit of a drum and bass influence I feel but the drums that would be no typically being a drum and bass song are replaced with noisy sharp glitches and Autechre presents slower moments as well like the clothes are on this album which feels like to an extent kind of a synth Odyssey still that doesn't stop this LP from kind of feeling like an overnight cram session and that's because even in its most upbeat and intense moments ex I really only kind of gets my head bobbing moderately the stimulation that the album brings to me is much more of a inside of my head my brain just really starts kind of firing off electricity in many different directions because of all the sounds that they hit me with and the array of sounds the Autechre bring to the table does make this LP pretty ambitious it's also ambitious from a length perspective although I think some people could charge this album is not really being that outside the box for Autechre in terms of just the way their music feels it's still very cold it's still very kind of scientific and because of that does become sort of difficult to say what is a highlight on this album and what is it there there are tracks on here like IR light which are 10 minutes a song that Autechre presents right at the second track of this LP and this song with a handful of others man these guys are presenting these 10 or 12 minute monoliths something that they kind of gravitated away from on some of their more recent releases and I'm actually happy to see them return to this style because they really know how to develop a track and make it interesting from beginning to end but still always kind of remaining very abstract and kind of chilly that's not to say that Autec errs music doesn't have humanity to it it most definitely does there are patterns that are pleasing and easy to get into there are clear chord progressions that do have sort of a logical progression to them however there are other tracks on here like prac F for example which when it comes to grooves or patterns or anything like that feel incredibly irregular the beat on this track feels like it almost skips a beat and the way it moves it's this track and maybe a few others like it on here where I feel like I'm hearing maybe three to four different elements of beat maybe a few different synthesizer phrases and it feels like the only thing they truly have in common is a tempo and that's about it and as I listen through to this LP again and again and again I sort of began to see a little bit more of a pattern between some of these tracks where maybe some of the synthesizer melodies or the beats backing the synthesizers seem a little bit random I guess another standout on here is the song tes X I which to me has kind of a tropical flavor to the synthesizers sort of reminding me of that loan album that I dug so much last year it's really kind of got this Caribbean feel to it but eventually the track gets kind of dark sort of murky submerging itself back into the ocean where it came truly where this album finds its magic is in the variety of sounds and flavors and speeds and intensities that it brings to the table like I already said I feel like I'm repeating myself again but I have to bring this point home that this is what makes this album appealing though on the whole it's not anything altogether new for Autechre it's still coming from that same emotional place where I feel like this album reaches a new maybe a subtly new and higher level of awesomeness is in just how freakin detailed it is because of how cold that this album can feel some people may sort of tune it out just in general because it doesn't really bring the attitudes or the emotions that people typically look for in music anger happiness sadness love maybe a little bit of lust this album has little to none of those things however that's not to say that it's not beautiful or inspiring or extremely proficient from a technical standpoint and well produced really it's it's all of those things I can't help but stand in awe of just its vastness of its expansiveness the amount of electronic nooks and crannies that have been placed throughout this LP can be listened to and observed for months upon months and still not be fully appreciated or understood and in my opinion that's actually a pretty fantastic feat it's like this never-ending puzzle it brings this constant sense of intrigue to the listener all of these things add up into what I feel has been one of the more unique experiences I've had with electronic music over the past half a year or so I'm feeling a decent too strong eight on this LP listen what did you think of it did you love it did you hate it why what do you think I should review next and yeah that's about it pucker X I forever you

hi everyone Anthony Fantana here intranets busiest music nerd and it's time for a review of the new men LP new moon the men are a New York band and this is their fourth full-length LP and over the course of their relatively short career up until this point they have showcased a serious neck for emulation and versatility meaning they know how to play a lot of different styles of music everything from noise rock to shoegaze to psych Rock garage rock as well maybe a little bit of post hardcore country the band is really difficult to place stylistically and I'm not sure if they want to be placed anywhere especially given the fact that their last full-length album was easily their most diverse so far but on top of that the men make another surprising change of pace on this new album as well the men actually kind of go country for a good portion of this new full-length LP there are numerous tracks that have harmonica maybe a little bit of piano of the honky-tonk inspired variety some guitar chord progressions that have a very very funky flavor to them however I wouldn't say the band gets too caught up and they're chameleons like nature to copy these different musical styles they're Punk garage and Lofa roots are still very apparent in their kind of rough playing that can be a little loose at times on tracks like without a face and the seeds the men definitely head out west but they don't forget to bring their New York attitude along the way the song without a face has this screaming harmonica playing against these guitar riffs as well as drum beats that just chug along quickly like a train and have some real tension and the song seeds with it's kind of strange imagery coming from the lyrics with these seeds of my mind and the vocals which are singing these lyrics in a sort of eccentric way it's one of the weirder tracks on this LP Plus on top of that the acoustic guitar playing in the background on this song is is really really loose adding to this kind of endearing sloppy quality that this track has however there are many other moments on this album where when the men go country it really comes off as like city slicker country about a city slickers you're gonna get city slicker country in the highest order like the opening track on here open the door door the playing on this song especially coming from the piano is so freakin timid I almost thought it was like kind of a joke song the singing on this LP actually turns really really sour on the track I saw her face which was a bit of a surprise because typically the men's vocals are are usually on point it's not like they're beautiful or gorgeous singers or anything like that I mean a lot of their vocals do have kind of a punk a garage aesthetic to them but when they're trying to sing clean like this sing maybe a ballad it's it's not really going over too well the singing is actually really weak on other moments here too like birds song and the playing the performance of the instruments on this track is especially freakin weak the way the piano and the harmonica open up this song it feels like I'm listening to just a really bad bar band play this horrific alt-country that slaps the genre of country in the face the band starts to pull some teenage heart strings circa 1958 with the song high and lonesome which is a cute little instrumental and then miraculously the men start to kick some ass they start whipping out that punk aggression with the track of the brass it's a track that in comparison almost every other song on here just makes the seiz'd run red with blood but honestly from a melodic standpoint it's it's really not much of a tune there's there's not really anything memorable about it but it has an attitude it has an aesthetic to it that the men pull off so much more convincingly than many of the country tracks on this LP the band's rough around the edges sound takes a sort of rock-and-roll twist with the song electric which dropped before this LP it was a good song when it dropped it's still a good track kind of like the song the brass the tune isn't really a standout catchy stick in the back of my head tune but the band has electricity to the way they play together when they go for a more aggressive rock sound after having reviewed three full-length albums from these guys it just feels like at this point that I'm destined to just get a mixed bag of tracks on every single new men album which wouldn't be a bad thing if all of them were as consistent as open your heart but especially on this new LP that doesn't seem to be the case it doesn't work in their favor for them to be embracing genres where they're not really that comfortable and can't perform to the extent that they should to make an entertaining song this shows up in most of the country flavor tunes on this album and the last track as well which is this just hard-hitting eight minute long psychedelic rock song with a garage Punk edge to it and while I do like the fact that the band wanted to go out and do a jam it just doesn't feel like they have the musical chops to make a song of this style that is this long engaging from front to back because a lot of the guitar phrasing gets kind of old after a while the drums feel just too static and the song itself becomes just a bit of a snoozer after several minutes with a guitar riff that just screams mc5 kick out the jams given the fact that I felt the album leave home that came out a few years ago was pretty good and that open your heart was a great improvement upon that and was more adventurous had better tunes on it I thought the men were ready with new moon to write a fantastic record I mean a tip-top record but in in my opinion it seems like their ambitions to create this musical group that is is hyper evolutionary changing in this a great way with every single release kind of caught up with them in a way because it backed them into a corner in which they weren't really able to live up to the genres they were trying to copy performance wise the plane wasn't there to back up these new sounds that they were shooting for and it just resulted in a very lackluster record in my opinion I'm feeling a decent too strong for on this thing if you've given it a listen what did you think of it did you love it did you hate it why what do you think I should review next and yeah that's a the men new moon forever

hi everyone Anthony Fantana here Internet's busiest music nerd it's time for your review of the new Shlomo EP laid out schwa mo is an electronic music producer whose name completely confuses me and what confuses me even more is that I can't even really say that he has a set style because when I first heard of this dude's work back in 2011 up to today where he's had a pretty steady stream of releases he's embraced everything from glitch hop to ambient music maybe a touch of drone as well as future garage sawaki as well it's come to a point where I am very very impressed with this dude's versatility and if there is a constant thread running through much of his stuff it is a very deep appreciation for all sounds shadowy nocturnal with maybe just a touch of atmosphere his productions do have a tendency to be on the softer side as well now of course this new EP of his jumps on board with some newer musical trends but of course he twists them into the somewhat melancholy moody vast and open vibes that typically come from his music for example Shlomo kind of hops on the bandwagon with nuanced alternative R&B which is pretty hot right now with a guest vocal from how to dress well a guy who was really ahead of the curve when it comes to this whole alternative R&B thing the song is called don't say no it's gone semi viral on soundcloud where it has racked up tens of thousands of listens and it's for good reason because the collaboration goes off without a hitch it's like slo-mo and how to dress well though maybe someone wouldn't think off the top of their head to combine these two artists they both have an appreciation for mesosphere ik tracks texture also plays a really huge role in the releases of both of these artists and that is apparent on this new track as well right from the get-go with these very watery synth chords how to dress Wells vocals just flow on top of these chords they're sleek they're a motive their high pitch they're in this very very nice falsetto it feels way more OnPoint than some of the stuff I remember hearing from his last full-length LP I reviewed last year I just like the mid-range that his vocals come through with sometimes it's really really painful in a way not in a bad way in a mood in an emotional way but how to dress well can reach up into those very very high notes where his voice does tend to get kind of feathery now on top of this Shlomo takes what feels like chunks of improvisation x' from how to dress well as vocals and just turns out the distortion on them makes them really just kind of obscured and plays them against his voice throughout the track and it's to a really nice effect especially as Shlomo's synthesizers are swelling and getting heavier and really creating an ocean for how to dress well vocals to just swim through and what I love so much about this track is that Shlomo and how to dress well create for this song such a seamless seamless progression it just slowly gets more intense gets heavier gets deeper gets sadder and once the beat finally goes hard and kicks in all these traps style high hats are twittering away the final form the final groove of this song is a killer and makes this track a great opening track just to stand out in slum bows discography in general trap is another thing that plays a pretty significant role on the five tracks of this EP this is especially the case with the track later which is the first song that dropped from this new EP and maybe my favorite production on this EP one of my favorite productions of this year not only does Shlomo lay out a detailed trap beat on this thing with the high hats and the snares just clicking and clacking away but this beat is causing a ruckus against these scents that are so busy much busier than you would expect a trap instrumental to be the synth arpeggios and the synth leads it's all really epic and Shlomo complements these greatly produce since with this awesome awesome vocal sample and man he plays these vocal cuts like an instrument I love the melodies that they're singing I love the way that they're placed in the beat it's just so freakin drum marek I actually think this is sha Mo's most emotionally powerful song yet because as he introduces these vocals the beat gets heavier it's it's sort of a drop in a sense it actually hits me with this overwhelming sense of oh that's so pretty Shu Ouma with these vocal samples and the synths and the trap beat I mean creates a perfect rush now my issue with this EP is that I feel that shlomo surrounds these songs with a few lackluster ones as well I feel like there are some filler songs on here given that they are working with roughly the same recipe as later and don't say no but with less layers it's not like he switches gears or anything the gloomy flavor trap music is still there in a sense the production kind of reminds me of the things that happen at night that I review from my low earlier this year except maybe not quite as detailed or as layered the final track on this EP does make sure that things are leaving off strong out of hand is a solid freaking track and though it does have like I said some of the elements of the previous songs it does have way more layers and a much more interesting progression to it than some of the other tracks here it's not really so much the similarity that bugs me but the comparative amount of detail in one song versus another and I like the beats which around the middle of this track - which changes all the sounds into something much more murky much darker than what the first half of the song was it's a surprise and a really cool change of pace overall this is a very very enjoyable 25 minutes of music feeling a strong seven to a light eight listen why don't you think of it did you love it did you hate it why what do you think I should review next and yeah that's it schwa mo lead out forever

hi everyone Anthony Fantana here intranets busiest music nerd and it's time for a review of the new Steven Wilson LPD Raven who refused to sing Steven Wilson is a modern progressive rock figurehead multi-instrumentalist producer singer songwriter frontman of the infamous porcupine tree and over the years responsible for penning some of what people consider to be modern progressive rock classics mostly in the late to mid 90s and early 2000s since and I personally know a lot of people who who hold porcupine tree and Steven Wilson in very high regard very high artistic regard which is why I've always found it to kind of be a personal tragedy of mine that I've never really enjoyed his music no matter how much I listen to it no matter how much I revisit it and the thing is it's not that I don't appreciate the genres that he typically toys with I love progressive rock I love jazz rock I love the sound of a group of very talented proficient musicians pushing each other's limits performance wise that's why I listen to Frank Zappa as well as soft Machine and Mahavishnu Orchestra and specifically artists that mr. Wilson takes a ton of influence from like Pink Floyd as well as a little bit of rush some Jethro Tull and King Crimson as well ranks are very high in the league of influences Steven Wilson likes to wear on his sleeve he takes a ton of cues from these artists he essentially with these artists does his progressive rock homework he's memorizing he's cramming he is mastering the art of regurgitating the musical ideas that these artists perfected over their careers and taking influence from the artists that move you emotionally as a musician is something that pretty much everybody does to an extent but doing his homework is really all I personally feel Steven Wilson does especially on his most recent solo efforts grace for drowning and the Raven who refused to sing Steven Wilson seems to have made a career out of just being a student of prog and that's it none of his music to me personally showcases the turbulent tides of real life or personal experience pretty much everything Steven Wilson has put out on his most recent stuff to me is is just a product of studying just very close study of the art of old-school progressive rock and the music actually suffers because of it even though Steven Wilson is really great at creating this music to an extent it's not like somebody who's actually familiar with this era of music would mistake this new album for an authentically vintage piece of progressive rock the sounds throughout this LP in my opinion are actually really flat and kind of unimaginative there's not much in the way of interesting production on this LP the drums sound really flat really plastic they don't have a lot of body to them they feel as if they were recorded on a shoestring budget in a home studio and other elements in this LP like the faux mellotron sounds and the very pristine piano chords that sound like they're coming out of a synthesizer it's kind of like that fake cringe-worthy kind of piano sound as well as the very pristine shimmering guitars it all just to me says knock off knock off knock off not only do the sound say that but compositionally this album says that to me as well the bass lines as well as the drumbeats and fills are incredibly incredibly textbook on this LP and the vocals in my opinion consistently lack passion Steven Wilson has never really been one of my favourite rock vocalists and it's because his voice kind of hangs in this very high range but isn't particularly a motive or attention-grabbing in terms of inflection or just putting a powerful voice forward for the most part it feels like the vocals are there because they should be there according to the progressive rock blueprint that Wilson is working from whereas I feel he has the chops to make this an instrumental album if he wanted to or at least employ a vocalist who is better at singing than he is which with all of his musical connections I'm sure could have done you know honestly when it comes to emulating Stephen Wilson has a gift I'm not surprised he has fans he's really great at emulating he can play he can arrange according to these formulas that he has studied and memorized so well audibly aside from maybe some nitpicking that I have with some of the sounds not being lush enough or being interesting enough there's nothing technically wrong there's just a severe lack of adventure and and Soundcraft on this record that just hangs over every song in a really annoying way like the track watchmaker which actually was one of my favorite songs on here a very pretty acoustic ballad opens this song up but it just kind of feels like vocals by greg lake with lyrics by peterson filled with some acoustic guitar peji Austrade out of the robert fripp playbook and then a flute comes in which makes the song feel even more formulaic and really takes me out of the sweet tender moment that mr. Wilson is trying to make this song become I like the lyrics on this track quite a bit Stephen is telling a beautiful story that feels very aged archaic kind of romantic but the years of ice that have kind of built up over my heart when it comes to listening to stuff Stephen Wilson has made because of just the lack of surprises that comes with his music he syncopated drum hits and then the bass riffs on the opening track here right at the start of it which feels a little like rush inspired in a way maybe the bass is kind of repetitive not really altering as much as I would have liked it but at least the song hits a good groove and starts the album off at a modest pace and the song drive home the way the track starts off with these piano chords it's very atmospheric and these guitar solos just come in whaling soaring over all of this rock instrumentation it's really kind of floyd esque then a King Crimson desk acoustic guitar interlude comes in smattered with a little bit of horns it's very beautiful it's very detailed but I feel like I'm taken out of the moment right away because this acoustic guitar flies in that feels like it's arriving on a train schedule or something like that again a great idea a great idea that I feel has tested and proven to be great on other records for me personally it's it's hard to enjoy this LP because I feel like I catch Stephen Wilson with his hand in the cookie jar just too many times I would say the most modern thing about this LP that isn't so distracting with all these prog rock stereotypes is the title track which is actually a very pretty piano ballad I wish the sounds were more interesting like on many other tracks on here but Stephen Wilson's voice actually sounds pretty great on this song there's some symphonic instrumentation coming in as the song progresses it's a nice point on the album that actually moved me in a sense emotionally and though there are some good ideas on this LP like this and Stephen Wilson like I said is really great at recreating those classic and fantastic prog sounds there are some moments on here that I don't feel like a prog for father would have done or just maybe would have not done as chisa lee as Stephen Wilson has like the dududu ascending vocals on the track watchmaker toward the end of the song if you're into prog rock and you really just want to hear all the great albums that you've loved over the years rehashed into a new LP and just all the pieces you're already familiar with just placed in a different order in a different succession then raven may just entertain you unfortunately I'm not looking for that really so like I said again this album left me cold so I'm pretty much feeling as the strong forty with like five on this thing certainly it's not terrible it's not horrible like I said it's not like this album is offensive to the ears from a technical standpoint but from a point of emotion and inspiration there's really not much of anything here for me really so that's it if you've given this LP listen what did you think of it did you love it did you hate it why what do you think I should review next Stephen Wilson the Raven who refused to sing Anthony Pham tanno forever you you [Music]

X choir did actually the issue for me is that many other MCS on this LP sound mix badly kind of drowned out sort of muddy with their vocals or maybe not even that enthusiastic with their verse when they come through especially Action Bronson as well as Cappadonna overall the production on this LP is pretty good the lyrics are pretty good the flows occasionally can be shaky and there's really not enough variety or original inspiration on this entire thing to make it feel as fresh as as some people are making it out to be unfortunately this album really does kind of bite off a little bit more than it can chew by throwing out all these vocal snippets and all these narrations which at the end of the day just come off as a gimmick because they don't really develop it into anything other than just sort of a distraction or a bumper between tracks feeling a decent two strong six on this LP if you've given it a listen what did you think about it did you love it did you hate it why what do you think I should review next and yeah that's about it 7l esoteric inspected Dec czar faced forever

hi everyone Anthony Fantana here the Internet's busiest music nerd and it's time for a review of the new darkthrone LP the underground resistance darkthrone is a metal duo who has had one of the most interesting trajectories of any group to really kind of come out of the Norwegian black metal scene in the 90s darkthrone was responsible for penning a few of black metals true classics and then later after that they progressed a little bit into death metal which they dabbled in for a very short period of time but then in the 2000s they eventually found the beauty in old-school heavy metal and crust punk combining those with their black metal sound for some pretty interesting full lengths which are decent metal releases but the people who wanted them to stick to their true blood black metal sound were understandably disappointed now not only did arc throw and bring to their music a change in musical style but it was kind of a change in character - because albums such as circle the wagons and dark Thrones and black flags are nowhere near as brooding there's not this pervasive sense of Darkness and demonic feelings or occult nests instead these more recent dark throne releases feel like testosterone fueled chest beating with vocals that reference the old school of metal but are maybe like a little kind of cartoony a little over the top and their guitar riffs and their drumbeats and their solos reference this era of metal - taking ideas from artists like Iron Maiden and Judas Priest and Motorhead as well as merciful fate and the underground resistance is yet another sequel in this saga but this time it's personal not really I just wanted to say that the band is actually sounding more old-school metal than ever on on this LP with their crust punk and their black metal influences kind of dissipating on these six tracks the introduction to the track dead early is old-school as hell it sounds like a combination of ac/dc and Motorhead with this bass drum and bass guitar kind of stomping a over and over and over on top of the speedy guitar riff and once the song gets going the vocals just croak I mean in this way that's kind of funny I know that the band must be conscious of what great metal vocals are I mean they've been in the metal scene for so frickin long and have had great fantastic black metal vocals on their earliest releases however I can't help but feel like the vocals they've been putting on their most recent releases especially this one are kind of satirical and in this specific case maybe a little bit of a mockery of the old school maybe not in a way where they're trying to directly insult and piss some people off but it doesn't really feel like dark throat is that into taking themselves too seriously which if your dark throne might be something they're kind of sick of at this point considering the very very serious black metal scene that they've been surrounded by for most of their musical career so the underground resistance is is definitely an LP that if you're gonna enjoy it requires an extra helping of context not only do you need to be familiar with what dark throne used to do musically but I feel like you need to also be aware of what old-school metal stereotypes are so you could kind of see and hear what exactly dark throne is playing off of taking inspiration from and ever-so-slightly parodying as far as the guitar riffs on this LP go throughout they are pretty predictable and familiar but solid and very well performed against the drums the guitar and the drums hit some pretty awesome metal grooves on one track after another the song dead early right at the start of this thing is very head bang worthy and the song Valkyrie is like a beautiful awesomely written metal ballad it feels snowy and the way the song paces along it feels like a trudge in foot deep snow it is epic there's some great guitar melodies on this one a bit of acoustic guitar at the intro and then after this track the band basically hammers out one heavy metal riff after another until they basically reach the 13 minute closing track leave no cross unturned which is a bit of speed metal worship that has this King Diamond like introduction leave no crosses and all of the really bad cartoony vocals from the past five tracks all kind of show up for this one group appearance sometimes singing all at once sometimes trading places throughout the track the band really yucks it up and I mean they have to be completely conscious of how bad the vocals sounds sometimes that falsetto that I just impersonate it a second ago that part on the song actually feels like it was a splice of two different vocal takes or something because they don't really transition in a way that feels smooth or even humanly possible and there are other very very audible vocal flubs all over this LP I mean the melodic vocals on Valkyrie are really flat and the song the ones you left behind the vocal harmonies the male vocal harmonies all over that track they are messy as hell I mean sloppy Slaven Lee the band seems to put so much effort into crafting some of these 4-minute songs with a lot of different riffs and segues and in parts and some great solos however the vocals are so terrible the closer is especially where things get kind of confusing because some of the worst vocal parts on this entire LP are there and yet it was no small undertaking for the band to craft this 13-minute monster that when it comes to the drums and the guitars is actually pretty engaging throughout the entire thing I mean it feels like they really wanted to pull off an authentic speed metal track with an antenna character to it for me the vocals on this LP are either the way they are because of two different things either Darkthrone doesn't give a about how they sound or they're intentionally bad in either way that's only going to attract a certain kind of metal listener overall in this LP the riffs are pretty good they're dusty but they're performed well the production is is pretty decent and stays true to that old-school metal sound but the cartoony vibes that I'm getting from the vocals are just too distracting when it comes to being kind of silly with your vocals I feel like at this point dark thorn has surpassed even a band like ghoul I do love that darkthrone wanted to put a fun metal album together I mean I do love fun metal music that's why I like thrash metal so much and the vocals on underground resistance definitely do give the band character where if they maybe played the vocals as straight as they do the drums and the guitars it might have just been a boring nondescript record that really kind of had nothing to report and this weird sort of funny crazy character does make the album fun for most of the tracks but by the time I get to the last song on here the 13 minute closer which is one of my favorite tracks on here it gets kind of old honestly I'm feeling a strong 5 to a light 6 on this thing if you've given it a listen what did you think did you love it did you hate it why what do you think I should review next and have a nice day Anthony Fantana Darkthrone forever [Music] you

hi everyone Anthony Fantino here Internet's busiest music nerd and it's time for your review of the new Starfucker LP Miracle Mile ion Starfucker is a Portland synth pop outfit that I have been conscious of for quite a while they were actually one of the first groups I ever remember blogging about on like a consistent basis back when they were coming out with releases like Jupiter around 2009 the first impressions were good I mean it just pretty much felt like synthesizer led indie pop with very light male vocals kind of hitting a high pitch a lot of infectious grooves some disco influenced rhythms like on the tracks big toy and Biggie Smalls and actually a pretty good cover of girls just want to have fun the rest of the LP however didn't really stick with me and at the time I never really reviewed the album so I wasn't really forced to think of why the album didn't appeal to me all the way or or why it didn't you know really entertain me as much as I guess it should have star-fuckers next full-length release reptilians is another album that you know I kind of skipped in 2011 however I guess my reasons for doing so kind of became a little bit more clear after hearing another full-length LP from these guys though I do like the electronic indie pop sound that they shoot for the instrumentation that typically shows up in their tracks it feels so flat and kind of just borderline colorless these guys are incredibly just unimaginative when it comes to sound honestly the synthesizers sound like they're either coming from some kind of digital audio workstation preset drums kind of feel the same way too they are there you can hear them you can hear pretty much detail in the fills and stuff like that but they are miles away from being sharp or resonant or beefy in the same way that you would hear on like any record that has come off of DFA records and the vocals that front all these tracks feel kind of like maybe they reach this high-pitched sort of MGMT kind of quality but they're way less memorable and and distinct I honestly feel like the band hasn't really crafted a sound that is faintly distinct across their four full-length albums and and the reason for that being is that they don't really try it's it's not really a focus it's not something that they even want to put effort into it seems just take a look at the album reptilians after which the band dropped a demos version of the album and it's it's kind of funny because when you listen to the demos version of the album songs like white is noon on the demos album the demos version of reptilians sound just is flat and unfinished and just normal regular plain sounding as the version that actually made it onto the LP same with Hungry Ghost and buried us alive sure the sounds and the instrumentation do come off as being slightly different but in terms of the heaviness of the sounds and the vibrance of the sounds especially the vibrance of the sounds the quality is the same and unfortunately Miracle Mile is pretty much the same in terms of sound quality for years the band has just rocked this sound that is not low Phi enough to be gritty or weird but it's not sharp or well recorded enough to be professional sounding or impressive as far as the opening track on this LP goes while I'm alive the guitar has this really bad direct in tone as if it's being directly plugged into a soundboard or a computer it just feels just bodyless in the falsetto vocals not only do they have this no personality to them but they sound like a Bee Gees inspired nightmare the song saysed the opening of this track has this kind of quaint crappy sounding like little baby keyboard throbbing away right at the start of the song which is kind of funny because most groups would throw that in and then sort of rush in a bunch of great sounding instrumentation to sort of contrast this very cheap synthesized sound coming out of the baby keyboard however the transition doesn't work because all the instrumentation that rushes in sounds like it comes out of a cheap keyboard too the vocals are typically mixed so badly you can't even really tell what they're saying when it sort of feels like they're so upfront that you be able to make them out and it's not like the vocals are singing anything that's just mind-blowing Lee emotive or genuine or anything like that they're just singing these basic forgettable indie 101 melodies that the band seems to have crafted up over these very plain drum beats and grooves that we all have heard rocked way harder by contemporaries like Hot Chip LCD soundsystem Cut Copy as well as m83 when it comes to the beats on this thing they just do not hit hard the most I could see this album inspiring is like some foot tapping and there are some softer moments on this LP some acoustic spots but there just is lacking in detail as the dance ear tracks and lacking in good sounds - like the track 9 equal H the autoharp that flies in on that track it's muddy as hell at least the vocals are a little more audible than they typically are but the melody is is just kind of you know cheap sounding I think the only track I came away from this LP actually thinking sounded halfway good was the song leave it all behind which has these blaring electro Keys pulsating away all over the song but honestly that's it I mean I just do not know where this band is coming from I mean obviously they must be passionate about what they do they come out one album after another maybe they're more passionate about performing or writing songs or something like that because it really seems like the sound of what they do is horrifyingly neglected and and continues to be with album to album with just no progression or evolution in how the band comes across deafeningly bland really I'm feeling a light too decent three on this thing if you've given it a listen what did you think of it did you love it did you hate it why what do you think I should review hi everyone Anthony Fantana here Internet's busiest music nerd and it's time for a review of the new clipping album mid-city could be could be being sounds good thank you for the support clipping is in LA hip hop trio and it's an interesting collection of dudes including Jonathan he is one half of the DIY electro pop duo Captain Ahab who actually had a pretty lengthy discography under their belts then there is William Hudson who also goes by the name rail and under this pseudonym he creates a lot of noisy strange ambient vast sound scapes that are pretty textured and then there is Davey Diggs who is the lead emcee in the group and together they make some really weird head-turning noise hop that will most definitely get a lot of comparisons to artists like Blacky as well as Death Grips now clipping shots of harsh bone-crushing distortion glitches static their moments where stuff off of this LP reminds me of like MERS bounce as well as maybe some more recent stuff from Tim Hecker like on the track off of this LP guns up where you have these really kind of sad apocalyptic court speaking through all of this just it's it's abrasive and yet kind of minimal in a way - I'm yet to actually long freakin song that kind of takes up a fifth of the entire mixtapes runtime that becomes no longer a phrase but just kind of this sound that just gets washed with effects and becomes pretty just hi everyone Anthony Pham tanto here Internet's busiest music nerd and it's time for a review atoms for peace among this is the full-length debut LP of a band fronted by Thom Yorke sort of a recording project he has going on with Nigel Godrich who you also may know as the producer of Thom Yorke's debut solo LP the eraser and originally this group had been formed to perform material from that album a handful of years ago when Tom was touring behind it now even though Atoms for Peace is this new band it's this new album it's really not all that far off from other Thom Yorke related releases for one this album is very electronic and synthetically textured in a lot of the same ways that the eraser was and this LP has an extremely kind of rhythmic quality too with a lot of looped beats that pulse a mechanically but have a ton of detail and layers to them just like many tracks off of the King of Limbs and even though ADM's four-piece is supposed to be a band with billed musicians such as flea from the Red Hot Chili Peppers on bass this does not feel like a live band and really any way shape or form the sounds on this LP feel so rigid robotic exact and meticulous to the point that there is no way whatsoever we are listening to live instrumentation which isn't really the worst thing in the world I guess what I'm getting at is that atoms for peace is basically just another Thom Yorke solo effort under a different flag now in a way in comparison to the eraser this LP is maybe even more meticulously planned out the eraser did have the very rigid and electronic beats that this album has but that LP also featured some guitar just waves of instrumentation kind of cascading over those beats whereas this new LP the sense the guitars they seem to sometimes be as looped or as rigid as the rhythms themselves a lot of these beats just kind of follow in lockstep with the guitars in the sense a lot like many spots from the of limbs that were just more beat oriented but I actually think that this new LP has a bit more punch it's got a bit more clarity it's got a bit more detail I think in a way I actually kind of wish that the King of Limbs sounded a bit more like amok because honestly a lot of the ballads and a lot of the softer spots off of that album since I have listened to it and have ever viewed it have actually kind of just lost their flavor for me a little and a lot of the more beat oriented tracks off of the LP feel so static to me it's like there's nothing in terms of a groove or a progression that moves me amok does bring a bit more progression and some really good ballads I think it may end up kind of getting swept under the rug a little bit though because it just kind of feels in a lot of ways like just typical Thom Yorke very icy very emotional his nasally wails are all over the place and underneath these vocals and just the balance themselves are these layered and throbbing rhythms that just go clickety clack clickety clack and aside from the vocals over these beats are all of these tones that are sweet their melancholy sometimes they're kind of glitchy this LP definitely does have a sound it has a vibe but still at the end of the day it ends up kind of feeling like a collection of tracks because there's not really a huge obvious arc or anything like that to the entire LP what this LP sounds like to me personally is just further tuning further alteration of the sound that Thom Yorke has been chasing after since the middle of the aughts and I actually think with with amok he's come closer than ever to perfecting it the song that opens up the selfie before your very eyes there's something about this beat that to me says gears it says switches says buttons but there's something about just Thom Yorke coming in and singing and I know his voice isn't for everybody but there's just something about his voice that that gives these songs just enough humanity to make them I guess bearable despite feelings so you know Bridgette and the song itself structure-wise is really linear there is kind of a swell toward the middle of the track that feels like a chorus with all these synthesizers all these random sound effects kind of bumping around everywhere but the rhythm pretty much stays exactly the same as it has been since it kind of kicked in toward the beginning of the track and that sort of seems to be a theme on numerous songs here Thom Yorke is trying to basically keep these grooves and keep these beats going and just maintain while changing things over in giving movement and giving progression to the song which is something Radiohead also did on the King of Limbs but there wasn't enough change detail or progress to keep the songs interesting to me the songs on this LP don't pop they don't really you know kind of give you a rush they don't shift gears excitedly when a course kind of comes in they are much more meditative they're kind of hypnotic in a way with how they just continue on and just change shades very slowly and subtly like the song unless which is really one of my favorite tracks on here it's got this you know a B C sort of structure with just one part moving into the next part moving into the next part and just not really looking back this long slowly builds into its groove these bad at-bats since pop in the rhythms eventually get beefier they get thicker bass eventually introduces itself along with these weird vocal samples of Tom's singing popping up all over the mix kind of encasing my head in the left and right channels with just weird whimpers and moans even lead tracks off of this LP like default that I reviewed earlier this year and enjoyed kind of follow that same pattern another track that dropped before this LP as well follows that pattern judge jury and executioner the acoustics stand out on this LP a song that I like a lot I feel like this track has one of the best beats on the entire LP with the reverb moans hanging in the background in this bassline that sounds like like you're kind of recording this throat humming sound and it's being looped and the basses kind of equalized very high on it so it's very resonant there are a lot of clicks in this rhythm and just oddly placed kick drums and I think the track is one of the prettier vocal melodies on the entire LP - my only issue with the song is that I wish it were longer it's one thing about this track and many other songs on here rarely does this album really kind of come out and grab me grab my attention or anything like that however I don't really think it's boring because I think the songs and I think the sounds are nice enough to the point where they actually lure me in but Thom Yorke is just really not at a point now where he's writing those rock songs those very emotive and and somewhat experimental art rock songs that people have loved from Radiohead for so long rather he's kind of taking his vocals and he's taking a lot of the same instrumentation and he's trying to make an electronic song a linearly structured electronic song he's trying to apply it all of these familiar elements to an electronic structure where you kind of take a groove you take an idea and basically for a handful of minutes you sort of not come up with these several different large lead contrasted parts in a single track really it's just one subtle change that comes on slowly another subtle change that comes on slowly if there's anything I really kind of dislike or I am sort of disappointed with in regards to this LP there are some nice synthesizers and vocals on this thing for sure that are treated and some just heavy wet effects just cavernous cascading vocals just layering on top of each other in a really nice way on some of these songs but the beats feel so freakin dry and flat sometimes it's like a burnt piece of Turkey between two pieces of toast the sounds can feel really kind of plain if you listen to this entire 40-minute LP from beginning to end sure it does have a style and it does have an approach but there could be a little bit more texture in some of these beats to make them a little bit more worth sinking your teeth into the sounds of the rhythms are just mysteriously mysteriously untreated like there was a severe lack of post-production in the making of these songs no doubt there are some cool songs and melodies on this LP especially nasty grooves like on the song stuck together pieces there's some detailed instrumentation and Thom Yorke has improved when it comes to taking this rock instrument and applying it to an electronic structure what this album really could have needed were maybe just some tracks of a different energy level a different flavor some different sounds and you know the the sonic experimentation that explorative edge that albums like a music and kid a have I'm actually feeling a strong six to a lay seven on this LP I enjoyed it quite a bit but if you've given it a listen what did you think did you love it did you hate it why what should i review next and yeah that's it Anthony Fantana Atoms for Peace forever [Music] music

hi everyone Anthony Fantana here internet's busiest music nerd and it's time for a review of the new ice age LP yo nothing me no that that wasn't directed at you ice age is a Danish punk rock outfit this is their sophomore LP but not only are they a punk band but in their music they are brought together in this new LP and their debut LP elements of hardcore punk post-punk noise rock and tons of compression on the overall mix of these tracks giving the songs a very kind of heavy Bhoomi quality the band can be pretty Brutus but there are no strangers to detail when you kind of dig deeper beyond the fact that everything is so echoey so distorted so noisy because even though these guys are very loud in a sense they're kind of carrying a depressive torch for groups like Joy Division and other Danish post-punk acts as well like the sods and it's no surprise that these guys are fans as well of groups like death in June of black metal artists as well through these influences these guys take their hopelessness they take their anguish emotions and they get really aggressive with them the band is just as abrasive as they've always been but on this album you're getting a few dance beats there are some group vocals here and there singing low low low low the instrumentation and the production overall is a bit cleaner a little less lo-fi there are some new ideas but what originally has made the Bands music so appealing to some but I would say unappealing to most is still there to the point where there are some tracks on here where I really do kind of feel like there's nothing new to report like the song burning hand or the other track rasas haha to me these tracks are a little maybe middle of the road for Ice Age they're not particularly aggressive or fast or depressive or noisy or anything like that they are passable and they're fine and they feel like they fit within vans typical style but it's not like they do anything new to define it or experiment with it overall they kind of blend into the ferocity of this 28 minute blast that sneaks in just to tick longer than the debut LP aside from those two tracks for me personally there's not any really major downsides for me on this album outside of a very eerie well textured and well put together but kind of ill placed interlude right at the third track on the album which unfortunately kind of cuts off the momentum that the LP has going up to that point thanks to the first two tracks the opener of this album is the song ecstasy and when this song hits if you don't like it I would say just get the hell out and turn back because this song kind of highlights what turns a lot of people off when it comes to Ice Age they're playing can be really really loose and that seems to be the case as the band kind of breaks into this disco dance beat with these sixteenth notes on the high hat with this alternating bass drum in this snare and over this are these tremolo guitars and bass which are just being strung really quickly but not necessarily in tandem with the beat and you know perfect syncopation and it creates this really dense thick wall of guitar noise over this dance beat which I mean to me is wildly catchy and just sort of weird but you know could be kind of I guess needlessly noisy to other people after this the band kind of reveals this looseness to be kind of an act kind of a facade as they quickly shift away from these tremolo guitars to this very fast-paced you know sets Arista and Denon and they totally switch gears go much faster and when the hook breaks in they switch gears yet again and not only change the speed but kind of change the emotion too because it goes from this aggression and it goes from this passion to this you know dark sadness that you know it seems like the singer of the group can't even awake himself from brush up oh god no after this the pummeling and surprisingly clear track coalition comes in a track that I loved earlier this year talked about in a quickie video earlier this year and I was actually surprised to just hear how composed the band felt on this track but just as biting the song in Hayes has these treble e guitars kind of causing a ruckus and the right channel against this relentless punk groove that is enhanced by the band's very boomy sound I love the jumpy kind of erratic melody on the hook and the vocals on this track to me personally are fantastic yeah they're not amazing vocals in the traditional sense but they're so freakin angry their fiery yet apathetic it's like a pissed-off swan song for defeatism for me the biggest surprise on this entire LP is the song morals which actually to me kind of feels like a post-punk prom song and a bit of a piano ballad led by the band's lead singer the drums behind this track kind of hammer away on the snare militaristically and overall the track kind of seems to bring the band into this sort of downtrodden singer/songwriter like state where all I can kind of you know see is like this post-punk prom going on where everybody's sad and breaking up and the punches spike tell the girls mascaras smudged and there's a sense that I get from this song specifically from the lyrics of just kind of personal weakness which is a feeling I get throughout most of the Bands music this band is is far from projecting any kind of emotions or personalities that feel confident or even strong instead it's kind of self-loathing self-deceptive and gain some kind of catharsis and power and strength from that the strength to make the head bashing music that they create kind of like another lyric on this LP where I believe the singer says wounded hearts can fight but it all comes down the same which is I mean an extremely pessimistic state of mind after this track the extremely catchy song awake comes through which has a great guitar melody very lively vocals I would say it's really the most high-spirited song on the entire album and the closing track on this LP is is fantastic as well and has this mantra of you're nothing over the hook kind of you know reminding the listener of the Bands ethos as the album comes to a finish overall I love this LP I feel like it's pretty on par with everything that made the debut album fantastic with a little bit more diversity as a result maybe there were some missteps here and there especially with that interlude
