hi everyone Anthony Fantino here internet's busiest music nerd and it's time for a review of the new Nick Cave and the Bad Seeds album push the sky away Nick Cave is an Australian singer-songwriter and the London band that he currently leads is on its 15th studio LP laying another collection of songs on top of the group's ever-growing and impressively consistent discography the songs that Nick Cave and the Bad Seeds turn out tend to be kind of dark tortured or melancholy or have this element of stomach-churning viciousness to them and while there are other CD singer-songwriters that I do enjoy quite a bit like Tom Waits for example Nick Cave has always kind of reached down into that lower level just that next level of seediness between songs like Mickey Mouse and the goodbye man from the new Grindr man LP the birthday party's album's tracks like where the wild roses grow up jump the devil good son I constantly find myself asking when I listen to much of what is related to Nick Cave is Nick Cave deeply disturbed I know Nick Cave has had his more pg-13 moments over the years but I really do feel like that there are either parts of his brain that he has been cursed with all his life or maybe we all have those parts in our brains and most of us are just kind of afraid to explore them or think about them obviously Nick Cave is not dangerously insane because he's managed to hold together a music career that really any musician would be proud of plus he's covered an impressive group of genres over the years post-punk goth rock alternative rock baroque pop as well as Foulke Nick Cave and his band maybe went a little easier on the ears in the 2000s the darkness was still there they weren't as brash as they were with their earlier noisier post-punk stuff it was I guess in a sense tortured but a bit more mature however in years Nick Cape has been kind of getting back to his punk rock punk blues and garage rock roots not only with new Bad Seeds releases like dig Lazarus dig and abattoir blues but the recent formation of his band grinder man and even though it's really only been a couple years since we've heard from Nick Cave through grinder man it has been a while since we've heard from the Bad Seeds I mean really since about 2008 with dig Lazarus dig which is more than enough time for some kind of stylistic or emotional reinvention and before this LP even came out there was this sense for me anyway that this LP would be receding back to Nick caves more sort of melancholy side especially because of the cover which looks like some kind of awkward breakup going on in a French new-wave film and the few tracks that drop before this LP Jubilee Street which does have an intense ending but is nowhere near Nick caves most intense song and we know who you are which is really one of the more somber tracks I've heard Nick Cave put out in recent years so of course when I sat down to listen to the entire LP it was no surprise that push the sky away overall is a much moodier experience than most of Nick caves output almost as if it were conceived in this sort of depressive state fueled by a very sad personal experience and some of what happens on this LP does seem to kind of shake cave in a personal way which is something that for a Bad Seeds fan is somewhat of a rare treat because often Nick Cave is sort of playing this narrator character or a character within a story that he's penning for a song that he's singing you're not really getting a moment like off this LP finishing Jubilee Street where he kind of sings specifically about finishing the track and how the imagery the dream inspired imagery off of that song has this deep emotional significance to him that has him kind of distraught which I'm sure for some Bad Seeds fans is going to be extremely intriguing to kind of see him in in this emotional state for an entire albums length but for me personally I mean I really missed despite how many times I listened to this album I really missed the gusto the fire the looming gloom and doom that cave typically brings to a track with the exception of the track Jubilee Street I really did not get even a whiff of that character that has told so many twisted stories over the years and it's not really the sadness or the melancholy about this album that has me kind of you know wandering other places with in my head when I'm listening to this thing I mean it really kind of feels like in a way Nick Cave has shrunken into himself and and it's difficult for him to project the emotions that he is feeling with the power that he typically does and and while yeah this isn't the most musical part of the album you know we're not exactly getting down to instrumentation here we're talking about vocal delivery we're talking about personality but I personally feel that Nick caves music is nothing if not extremely personality driven and if the personality isn't there for me the magic isn't there and this magic only shows up occasionally mostly on the first half of the LP and the LP here is not very long it's just about 42 minutes but to me it feels much longer despite only having nine tracks and that's mostly because the songwriting on this LP isn't all that sharp or concise it's not all that ballad driven or anything like that with the exception of maybe a few songs the songs on this LP aren't compartmentalized or cutting like they are on albums like the Bauman's call or Henry's dream instead Nick Cave uses a songwriting a performing technique that he's been using on and off over the years very consistently on the grinder man LPS and recent output from the Bad Seeds where he basically grabs a groove he grabs a musical idea and it sort of gets you know jammed out repeated in a sense over and over and over as he kind of tells his tale and sings over it it's more of a linear way of songwriting it's a more linear way of song performing and this Niq is executed awesomely on Jubilee Street where the track just gets more and more intense as it goes along you get this sense that you're moving from point A to point B as the song finishes not only because Kate is telling this story with detailed lyrics but the instrumentation gets hotter it gets heavier strings sort of seep in however there are moments on this LP where I personally feel like cave really needed to I guess sort of edit himself and maybe you know bring some of these songs down boil them down into a sharper ballad like we get on the song we know who you are like on the song wide lovely eyes which just to me feels like this very tame almost adult contemporary piece of gospel inspired songwriting and a lot of the instrumentation on this track especially the guitar riff feels just robotically and kind of annoyingly looped behind everything sort of taking away the the flow and the intimacy out of this song and in others on here too like we real cool this is an issue that I had off a dig Lazarus dig too a lot of the instrumentation felt chopped it fell looped but I feel like what kind of made that album scrape by anyways is the fact that so many of the songs were just loud and in-your-face and energetic in my opinion it's not working so well here on these softer and slower tracks and the songs that don't really have any clear loops in them and kind of wander around a little bit more when it comes to what's being said and the instrumentation for example the song mermaid the atmosphere is really nice the instrumentation on this track swells really awesomely but in my opinion the story that Nick tells and performed in the sense through his vocals and his storytelling the group vocals and the keyboards on the hook are really nice but Nick caves lyrics and his storytelling they wander and meander more hi everyone Anthony Fantana here internet's busiest music nerd and it's time for a review of the new beach fossils LP clash the truth this is the long awaited sophomore full-length LP from the new york band beach fossils whose self-titled debut pretty much got the ball rolling on a pretty big trend in underground indie rock and pop that's been just rolling and rolling and rolling over the past few years and that trend is just steady guitar-driven and echoey dream pop kind of like the light beach visiting pastel-colored cousin to the indie rock we once knew typically on the albums that have featured this style the vocals tend to be kind of apathetic the guitar tones are usually pretty stringy trevally with shimmering echoes on them maybe little bland and sound strum patterns drum patterns melody as well from the guitar and the vocals too they don't really tend to be that I guess sort of distinct or or flavorful when it comes to composition to me this sound has always been fine for a few songs or like a single but it all kind of tends to blend together in this really sort of unrewarding and kind of boring way when I listen to an entire album of it from beginning to end this has kind of been the tune that I've been singing whenever I've talked about a record in this style whether it be in a review or a y-you know review or a blogpost whatever and because of this sort of bias and this general uninterested music that has this sound in this style I wasn't anticipating expecting much from this new Beach fossils LP even though I did like the last EP that they put out which actually had wild nothing on it however I have to say with this new album I'm pleasantly surprised and not only because I think the band is writing better tunes the production is better on this LP but I just did not anticipate the kind of variety that Beach fossils would bring on clash the truth and the detail - I mean for one the vocals on this LP are way more audible than on any other previous efforts I mean they're they're no longer a prison to the reverb and the echo that they constantly use throughout every single song the melodies on this LP pop the playing and the instrumentation overall is just more energetic I've seen the band live a couple times they rock their songs out way harder in person than they are on record and I'm just feeling the interplay I'm feeling the momentum I'm feeling the grooves on this album there's actually more than one guitar tone on this album - there's thinner tones thicker ones some distortion here and there acoustic guitar and all of these additions are being brought into this new record while the band kind of still sticks to its signature sound the mood that this band usually brings to the table is still there the accessibility is still there simplicity is still a key feature to their sound what beach fossils does across this 35 minute record is not all that technical or flashy not profound not even I guess I would say novel at this point now that we have a bunch of albums popping up in this very same style every single year but on clash the truth Beach fossils does some embracing some soul searching of their influences and just end up with a more solid record because of it the introductory track on here is a bit of post-punk kind of Joy Division influence and has these very catchy chanted group vocals kind of a mantra it's a very lively start for this typically sleepy band and though the song is sure along with a lot of others on here Beach fossils kind of have this way of keeping their songs so stripped down yet so energetic that the brevity feels so complete anyway in the same way that a punk band like wire would the band kind of continues to put a defining characteristic on every single song on this LP like the track generational synthetic which has this galloping snare drum this descending vocal melody that's sticking in my head as well as some very melodic guitar phrasing or the chorus and the acoustic track on here that comes shortly after sleep apnea is a decent song as well it's a little short it's the one moment on this LP that I feel it could have been fleshed out more but I like the very sort of dreamy psychedelic textures that the band brings this track the song really feels tired in the way that a lack of sleep hood would make you feel but even songs on this LP that feel well within beach fossils comfort zone have this sort of new vibrance to them with just harder playing and some more detail like the song careless which has these burning guitar leads all over the place a danceable drumbeat all these sweet young male group vocals mmm the song is simultaneously sleepy intoxicating and poppy and exciting the tracks on this LP it's not like Beach fossils is pumping out these 15 minute epic progressive monsters but clash the truth features the band's most fleshed out material yet with melodies that actually stick out and are memorable and verses and courses that actually kind of feel like they're coming from different spots there's contrast there it just doesn't feel like this one endless sleepy tired boring blob of a song the band continues to put a distinct characteristic into every single song on this LP like the song burned you down which has this tick-tock tight dance beat the song birthday has some shark biting distortion on it but it washes over the whole track in this kind of My Bloody Valentine worship sort of way and the song in vertigo actually features Kasim Aquino from Blonde Redhead on vocals she slides into the song very nicely along with the male vocals that the band usually provides it's sweet to see them kind of tribute Blonde Redhead because they're no doubt an influence I love the stringy layers of guitar on the song caustic cross they're soft but they scream out confidently against these very fill filled drumbeats which hit me and remind me that man just overall the drumming on this LP is so much better there are a few drones on here a few interludes which are placed very nicely not taking away from the momentum of the album and the sounds that they actually bring forward our very pretty adding to the dreamy quality of the album this LP was put together really well Beach fossils actually conceived this album with just a grandeur point of view they weren't just trying to put together a bunch of singles that ended up sounding like crap when you put them together into an album overall the band sticks to its light and and youthful sound but feels mature and detailed enough to the point where you can actually take it seriously but not too seriously because really it's it's all about fun maybe you could make the argument that this LP is to say me say me for its own good I'm sure that there are going to be some people who are turned off a little bit by the band's constant constant dreamy sound but I still find this LP personally to be diverse enough to be enjoyed and a really interesting crossroads of things like indie rock shoegaze dream pop as well as punk rock the vocals could have been maybe a bit more distinct and that of course you know I would love to hear them lay on more melody in the future but there's not really any huge complaints from me honestly I'm feeling a decent too strong 8 on this LP if you've given it a listen what did you think did you love it hate it why and what do you think I should review next anthony Fantana Beach fossils forever [Music] you

hi everyone Anthony Fantana here internet's busiest music nerd and it's time for you review the new portal LP portal is an australian death metal act they've been at it since the 90s and have a handful of albums under their belt to show for it over the years the group has had about a dozen different members many of them contributing and being members of other australian extreme music acts as well however along with groups like disembowelment as well as nei oblivious chorus destroyer 666 and bella core portal has kind of seen a rise to international metal fame they're really one of the bigger underground australian metal acts at the moment but still it's not like they're a major player in death metal in general and i would say mostly that is because of how dam impenetrable the band's music is they make easily some of the most chaotic and and dense death metal I've heard in a while though the group at times is labeled as being technical death metal I wouldn't say the playing that they showcase in their songs is overly flashy or anything like that for the most part what's going to stick out to you about portal is just how muddy thick and just blood caked their sound is which has been a pretty consistent quality of theirs over the years albums like 2009 swarf is is not too far off from the original blueprint of death metal the guitars are really grimy the drums are extremely heavy the death grouser in there as well the chromatic chord changes are in there too it's just that portal likes to I guess sort of cover their songs in a noticeably larger amount of filth rendering a lot of the details that they usually put into their tracks a little I guess inaudible because these guys do like to write a lot of different passages into a single track that could be around three to five minutes making it difficult to get a bird's-eye view of a song quickly or in a handful of listens the band likes to kind of bombard the listener not only sonically with all these just heavy distorted sounds but I guess sort of musically with just all of these different ideas making albums like swarf kind of disorienting at times but I just get this like stillness from the band's music that I would normally get from like an ambient music piece or a noise music piece they're not really interested in in rocking out when I listen to a portal track especially on this new LP I kind of feel like I'm being shoved into an Iron Maiden and the last thing I want to do is move they don't really hit grooves they don't have tension releasing cathartic riffs or anything like that they're actually much more interested in experimenting like the finishing track on hero Blonde which really kind of closes up shop with several minutes of just these tremolo guitars dueling with nothing else in the mix other than maybe a little bit of bass to kind of back them up and the introduction of the same song too has these sort of weird metallic whales going way way way sounds like some kind of weird chilling sound effect from a horror movie they don't really care as much about composing songs as they do just working with sounds noises and textures because a lot of the sounds on here between the guitars and just the heavy muddy muddy drums they're really brutal they're dismal they're depressing but when it comes to the opening guitar chords on this track oh blonde that I've been talking about and these tremolo melodies toward the end pretty much everything that the band has written is is a really standard death metal affair I mean disappointingly standard very average I actually think this album doesn't live up to the compositional standards of most genres much less death metal like I said the band tends to assemble all of these quick parts that they quickly switch out for other parts in a single track but I mean honestly it's not like any of these single parts in my opinion are worth really dragging out as long as the band actually does that's actually kind of a saving grace on this LP what makes some of the songs on here engaging not many tracks hit me as being that great compositionally except maybe the track or bow morphia where there was actually a Gothic quality to the guitar leads and especially the set of intervals that kind of hit in this long drawn-out chord that's very sweet kind of romantic in a sense tracks I liked throughout and I mean like not necessarily loved liked throughout our songs like the back wards in our or Jori Jori on the sounds are definitely there the production is definitely there like I said not too far off from a standard death metal fair but much noisier much just more hectic the band puts a lot of intensity and puts a lot of energy into their performance I mean they're really kind of playing their hearts out until they're just like bursting in their chests and the blood is spurting out everywhere I like the guitar freak-outs on the backwards I like the fact that these syncopated snare rolls come in and lock in with the guitars kind of reminds me of something liturgy would do because when you're actually able to breach through the noise and breach through the ugliness the details it kind of appears that they didn't put as much effort into that much more effort kind of went into this outer shell that makes it difficult to get into that boney skeletal center there's not much release to a lot of these songs there are a lot of parts but there's not much in terms of structure it's just tension tension tension tension it's a lot of noise but still I kind of end up waiting for something to happen I guess though I do like portal sounds vex void I just found to be kind of a unrewarding listen to an extent I mean it's really kind of like dragging your injured army buddy through ten miles of swamp just to have them die as soon as you get to shore honestly I guess I'm feeling a strong forward of a light five on this LP if you've given it a listen what did you think of it did you love it did you hate it why and what do you think I should review next Anthony Fantana portal forever [Music] [Music]

yada yada and this is a review for the bauer track harlem shake baauer is a new york electronic music producer and this track of his has been taking the internet by storm but not by itself of course I mean this track was actually dropped through the label Mad Decent last year spring of last year and the track slipped by even me because when I first heard of this guy it was through the collaboration he did with Just Blaze recently on the track hire which is an amazing freakin banger which a few videos ago I told you guys I said I feel like is banger of the year potential but of course I got that completely and utterly wrong because hire is not the banger of the year at all Harlem shake is the banger of the year except it came from last year making it the banger of last year this year we live at a very interesting time for music and this track is proof of it that you can release a song almost a year ago and then all of a sudden through no control of your own it just all of a sudden blows up overnight because there's some guy dancing to it with a group of friends and in weird costumes in a video which in turn causes a group of people in a dorm room to dance to it or a group of people in an office or a men's swimming team or the military the joke that people have attached to this song seems to have kind of transcended numerous walks of life in the internet generation but I feel like part of the reason that this joke has sort of become so universal as understood so universally is because the song the way it works in the way it appeals is so universal because Harlem shake is an electronic banger with bass heavy beats that hit hard hard in the errors now of course bangers come in different shapes and in size and and flavors and are produced by a variety of different artists some producers that are that are kind of hot for making really great bangers a rap music tonight or like that really awesome flostre Damas remix of the original don track from Major Lazer and all of these artists specifically take a lot of direction from trap rap the instrumentals from this Southern bread style of hip hop that is essentially an ode to America's drug dealers a style of music that's currently for fronted by artists like Gucci Mane as well as waka flocka flame of course this style of hip hop predates these two artists but these two artists are two of the larger names in this newer breed of southern trap style hip hop that has these heavy bass hits these just skittering snare drums rattling high hats and all of these sounds and ideas are featured in Bowers Harlem shake but they're all twisted and revamped and recontextualized until these sounds serve a completely different purpose because the track we're talking about here isn't exactly the dark gritty Southern Fried soundtrack to selling crack outside of a dilapidated house instead it's an all-out dance party where your energy matters way more than your moves so Bower just does a great job of just taking these pre-existing musical ideas and transforming them into something else to me that is what art is all about to an extent but the Internet has brought us into this age where that is kind of being hyper accelerated the way that we are able to take ideas from one musical culture and pepper them throughout pretty much every single other musical culture in 2010 waka flocka flame drops his breakout album flock of le which features track for track all of these trap style southern hip hop beats produced by lex luger from there it kind of spreads into every other facet of hip-hop culture with numerous MCS hopping on beats that have these skittering high hats other producers kind of taking out some of these ideas these busier snare drums these heavier bass hits again this hi-hat style into their production kind of adopting these sounds and even electronic music artists are starting to peek at some of the things they're hearing in these beats and DJs are playing these kinds of songs out too and here on this track we're hearing these trap style rhythms fused together with these wonky synthesizer grooves as well as a dubstep style build and drop and with these slight alterations that Bauer has made to these ideas he's turned this musical style into something that is just again so catchy and so instantly enjoyable you don't even really need to explain what makes it so goddamn enjoyable everything in this track is just engaging and blood pumping from the attention-grabbing vocal cut right at the start in Spanish that sounds like it's being screamed through a megaphone the rising handclaps and synthesizers that just make things feel more tense behind it there's all these synthesizers making a ruckus that kind of sound like a spaceship is getting ready to take off in a Sega Genesis game and Bauer just quickly delivers the drop and just cuts the listeners head off with force and this perfectly perfectly resonating punch of bass and synthesizers the snare drums and the hi-hat sore clickety clackety they're like the tiny little gears twittering along as they push and just sort of huff and puffing move the machinery that dishes out these heavy pummeling base hits that cause your hips to shake so hard they fly out of your body Bauer seems to kind of progress the track through different grooves ideas takes on the same theme that the song started off with which is really all I can ask for because the first idea that the song presents is a really great freaking idea and to hear a few more versions of it as it continues along is you know just pretty much more icing on the cake you know the song's not too busy it's not too flowery it's just strictly business hips shaking just business and honestly that's what I freaking love about it I love this track trap bangers for all it's all I got to say if you've given this track a listen I'm sure you have what do you think of it is it the perfect drop and you know what do you think of this electronic trap fusion hi everyone Anthony Fantino here the Internet's ATS is a nerd and it's time for a review group er the man who died in his boat I should be quieter here Gooper quiet music should be softer sorry grouper is the pseudonym for experimental and ambient music producer as well as multi-instrumentalist Liz Harris and she grabbed the full attention of the burgeoning music blogosphere in 2008 with the album dragging a dead deer up a hill which is a nasty awesome album title and at the time the album was a bit of a departure from her typically very ambient kind of droney style instead Liz was delivering these very kind of funky sort of meditative songs that had very spacious obscured vocals it was music that was very psychedelic very otherworldly very basic in sound melody and structure but still very heavy with feelings of loneliness and kind of desolation these are feelings that in my opinion Liz ended up capturing so much better on the very ambitious double album that she dropped a few years ago dream loss / alien observer which features much more material longer material sounds that are way more nocturnal shadowy varied roni synthesizer filled - and what I also loved about this double album is that I saw Liz playing with many more sounds and textures and kind of filtering them all through this low pass filter that made everything so muddy and yet a lot of the sounds on this LP had this kind of unmastered sharpness to them with an occasional wash of distortion or crackle which actually was nothing too distracting actually felt like a lot of the damaged sounds the damaged quality of many of the sounds on this double album brought a lot of character to these tracks and despite just being very simple from a musical and technical perspective the song was on this double album are just so friggin in pen Tribble AIA took a while to grow on me which is really why I did not do a full review of the double album in the year that it had dropped however this new collection of tracks from grouper comes from that much more accessible territory that draging did with acoustic guitar soft shy vocals with the occasional multi-tracked vocal harmony those psychedelic effects in a lot of ways this album is a return to all those things that made grouper a name in the first place things are still feeling pretty muddy pretty shadowy but maybe overall this LP is sonically a little clearer a little cleaner than dragging a dead deer I can't help but feel like maybe some people disagree with that and the thing is just in general groupers music is so freakin open to interpretation it's certainly not something that is easy to judge from an ambient perspective but it's not really easy to judge from a singer/songwriter perspective either because Liz isn't exactly penning tunes in the traditional fashion because I personally don't feel like you can really condense Liz Harris's appeal in a three to five minute song groupers music is really something I personally feel you need to have a certain kind of personality type for or you need to be in a certain kind of emotional state because to me it's music that is is really for people who need a little bit of emotional soothing because listening to a group or album for me is so much like going through a process or something like that there's no moment where I want to put a single group or song on because I'm in to really hearing that catchy melody or you know that really infectious hook which is why I think grouper really asks more of her audience than the most singer songwriters do you know singer songwriters and in the most sort of vague sense that I can possibly mean it it's always always taken in albums length of songs for groupers emotional magic to kind of work itself on me and that's no different for this album as well from the very sharp drone at the intro track to the very audible surprisingly audible song living room where you can actually make out a lot of Liz's vocals her lyrics which I match with a lot of beautiful guitar arpeggios which is why my first impression listening to this LP was you know it's sort of math kind of boring it's really there in the background but by the end of the whole experience I was like wow this is beautiful and when I started all over again what I originally thought was just kind of yeah was actually striking me as being pretty because while at first listen I could definitely make out everything that I'm hearing and what is being done it doesn't necessarily mean that it's impacting me emotionally as I was listening to this album again and again I found tracks like being her shadow the very droney track being her shadow to be very kind of touching and somber I like the very echo heavy track difference to which had all these layered vocals on it I think the only downside for me personally to the track is that the guitar chords had a really kind of farty quality to them they just didn't feel like they were being played well and it was just kind of this sharp noisy quality sort of just kind of killing that smoother more ethereal vibe and then there are songs like cloud in places and and cover the long way which feature guitar strumming patterns that don't really do all too much for me honestly and I don't feel like the vocal harmonies on the second of those two tracks are as well arranged as I typically hear from Grouper they don't feel like they're gliding together or working together or working in tandem they're sort of muddying each other up because they're not synced up or performed in a way where they can actually complement each other well the echoing Keys on the track vanishing point were pretty decent I liked the sound I liked the tone but I wish there was more of a I guess a song to it a structure direction I actually don't think this album gets really captivating again until it's its last few moments especially the song living room which is a gorgeous track and really one of the most beautiful I guess in the traditional sense songs that Grouper is written and I love the six-minute drone that comes in before that track too it's another stunning ethereal piece of music that Grouper has bestowed upon me you know overall again I will say I do feel like this new al is clearer but I'm not exactly sure if that's spelled out into kind of a success or an improvement because I feel like it's exposed some things like a lot of these guitars which don't seem to be getting performed or played as proficiently as what I've heard on dragging dead deer I actually wish the guitars were a little more obscured and maybe that a few more of these tracks were sort of more awash in keyboards on this new LP a lot of the instrumentation kind of seems to be strewn about these tracks kind of like the contents within the ownerless boat that kind of inspired this album in the first place still I didn't come away from this album being very very dissatisfied or unhappy one big plus is that for sure for sure without a doubt the emotions are still here that at least what I interpret to be kind of sadness desolation that sort of wandering lonely feeling that is usually so potent in groupers music whether it be the more acoustic stuff whether it be the more droney stuff that is still so heavy on this new album I just feel like you know the songs could have been sharper and and really that said when it comes to writing and performing - I'm feeling a strong 6 - a light 7 on this album if you've given it a listen what did you think did you love it did you hate it why and what do you think I should review next anthony Fantan Oh grouper forever you you

hi everyone Anthony Fantana here the Internet's busiest music nerd and it's time for a review of the new pissed jeans album honey's pissed jeans is not only the most surefire way to put the brakes on a blind date where you're feeling uncomfortable they're also a rock band on their fourth full-length album the majority of this band's discography is on Sub Pop records including this new LP and when I typically listen to a piss jeans album whether it be their debut from 2005 shallow or hope for men or the album they dropped in 2009 king of jeans or this new album as well one single word comes to mind and that word is finesse and the reason that word comes to mind is because this band does not have a scratch of it I don't even know if they're interested in having any the band's singer just wails and gargles his lyrics kind of like a drunk guy being held down by three police officers outside of a trashy nightclub downtown on a Friday night most of the band's songs kind of run at this mid-paced kind of grungy kind of sludgy tempo that I don't know if they played any faster they might lose their composure the band's drumbeats are typically pretty simple a lot of the fills spacious but thunderous going off like gunshots and as far as the guitars go when they're playing chords they are just pumping them out with force but the guitars tend to flail wildly when it comes to solos and then leads it's just a range of different ideas from noise rock sludge metal and post-hardcore there are moments in this band's discography that reminds me of early work from The Melvins as well as flipper on Seine and when they get really chaotic and slow most definitely the Jesus Lizard it's no secret that the band has been sticking very passionately to this kind of one sound and style with very minor adjustments over the years however that doesn't keep honey's from feeling just as real as any of the other band's albums when it comes to that pissed-off feeling especially since on this new wreck they're still working with Alex Newport who helped them record their last album which did display a heavier side of the band a more direct and kind of cut through outside of the band now honey's like usual for pissed jeans is kind of a crossroads of of different loud rock ideas and because the band is able to embrace so many different ideas in loud rock in one record even though they're kind of staying within their comfort zones they're still able to kind of deliver a pretty versatile set of tracks like the track bathroom laughter which kind of kicks the album off which has this sort of Punk momentum to it it actually reminds me of one of the flawless from ceremony's previous album runner Park the song sick to be specific except much noisier much more chaotic it's really a kick-ass way to start off the album just like they kind of started off their last LP but it's really a night and day change when it comes to tempo and emotion as soon as they jump into the next track which is chained worker and the song kicks off with these blast beats but then quickly dives into these slow distorted bass riffs that just move like molasses and it almost in a way kind of becomes sort of droney kind of atmospheric the vocals are just shouting what what feels like something very rageful hateful there's some moments where it actually kind of reminds me of a birthday party except way less noisy and avant-garde but still enjoyable all the same though there are some moments where the vocals do kind of get laid out with effects that make this track feel at least a little bit psychedelic the band feeds into the next track with this pretty catchy riff but honestly there's not too much about this song other than the riff that really kind of sticks with me unfortunately the band doesn't hit me again with something that really kind of sticks in the back of my head until the track you're different in person which just has all these dissonant guitar chords flying at me from every direction when it comes to just very sour intervals and then note combinations this song has that down and when it comes to speed and just the vocals being so manic and so wild this song is just wallowing in its own emotional filth the song cafeteria food comes shortly after which I loved off of this LP it's a much slower track it's toned down when it comes to being noisy and intense but with the lyrics which kind of reference seeing this person with his stick figure family on his car sort of saying weird things about you know him making healthy choices with this cafeteria food being sung with these deadpan vocals it's just kind of an eerie set of images the narrator of the track maybe seems kind of disturbed and this song also kind of runs congruent with a lot of tracks that they've written over the years that sort of see this sickness and mundaneness and everyday mainstream you know kind of normal life after this the band just kind of continues its downward spiral into Slaven Leacock rock with a lot of noise and a lot of riffs and even though I like it especially the raw emotion especially with the energy honestly pissed jeans is just not going to translate for people who like their songs maybe a little bit more composed or you know maybe a little more methodical but really it's all kind of a matter of degree I mean I think there are people who are into hardcore punk but may not necessarily get into just how freewheeling pissed jeans can be on a track because really this LP and most of piss jeans discography is about letting go it's about getting loose and about kind of unleashing the Beast which can be really great for kind of conjuring this really strong and ferocious and uncompromising vibe but it doesn't necessarily always add up to a memorable musical moment the song health plan on the latter half of this LP is absolutely freaking hilarious not only because its riffs are so pounding but the lyrics are amazing with shouting out this mantra that you know you want to know my secret I stay away from doctors it's just driving it's it's tough and the song shortly after this which I believe is pronounced lubes loves Loubs it's kind of odd it drags on a little bit but the way the bass groove works and the and the drums are hitting at this very slow tempo and the way the guitar leads are kind of slithering their way into the track in between the base and the rhythms it kind of feels like a bluesy sort of vibe about as bluesy as kind of a noise rock track could be there are moments like the closer on this LP teenage adult that musically could be a little more distinct could use a little bit more maybe guitar leads or just melody or just a weirder riff or groove to kind of make it pop out there's just a few spots on this LP where I feel like maybe just a little bit more than attitude is needed to make the song I'm listening to great however I mean I still did not come away from this album unsatisfied [Music] hi everyone Anthony Fantana here the Internet's busiest music nerd and it's time for a review of the new foals LP holy fire foals is a UK rock quintet whose third full-length album right here holy fire I have been maybe a little hesitant to review because of just my strong dislike for their last full-length album total life forever in my opinion foals used to be one of these young brash up-and-coming bands in indie rock that were just bursting with energy with all these dance punk beats and in math rock grooves and eccentric vocals they were just a fireball of energy especially with tracks like Casius and balloons which both had some awesome horn parts in them too I personally saw an incredible amount of potential in what the band was doing in their early stuff but you know maybe they didn't actually end up seeing it that way a lot like another English rock group block party it seemed like on their sophomore full-length foals was trying to do away with their original sound as quickly as possible however unlike block party I don't really think on their sophomore full-length LP foals tried to maintain their youthful energy it seemed to me that they were kind of in a rush to mature the beats were at times danceable but just not as hard not as Punk influenced for sure and it wasn't a total letdown I mean foals did supply some pretty good singles with tracks like this Orient as well as Miami but just that really colorful vibrant and and sort of rawness that the band had to their early stuff was just kind of sucked away and replaced with very glistening string kissed choruses with the occasional Radiohead style ambitious climax now unfortunately this new LP is not really that bold change in direction I was kind of crossing my fingers for it's not the return of that vibrant energy however again Foles does not leave me totally to hang out to dry they never really do there's always at least a handful of tracks that are great and maybe on this new album I actually think they have struck a somewhat better balance between their softer more mature side and that visceral energy that they're able to conjure as a rock band because there are some really good and lively tracks on here and some interesting moments where foals are trying to make some pretty strange chemical reactions between different musical flavors like the track inhaler which has these guitar chords that that just balance with echo rhythmically there's this pulsating drumbeat that kind of reminds me of a band like Maserati there's all these soaring falsetto vocals on the verses and then when the chorus bursts in with this heavy ass guitar riff it sounds like something Tom Morello from Rage Against the Machine could read and I think the execution of kind of this new vibe that this riff brings goes over really smoothly the song my number is another favorite of mine on here the song really pops with a lot of catchy group vocals there's more bouncy guitars more dance beats it doesn't really go as hard on the chorus like inhaler does but it's a really just sweet danceable pop/rock single and to me this song is really where the band does very well for themselves in trying to find a balance between making a dance tune making a tune that you can move to making a tune that's visceral but also sounding maybe a little lighter a little more flowery a little sweeter you know it's dancey but it's not superfluous and it has some really nice little baby tiny funky shiny guitar leads to those actually appear on quite a few tracks here the song Providence is another favorite of mine on here to the end of this track is so heavy and noisy and thick and climactic I didn't know foals was still capable of creating a sound that was that noisy in that intense anymore and everything that comes before that point is fantastic as well just these hard ass drum beats these jutting distorted riffs it's so aggressive and yet so dancey there's some interesting interludes here with some atmospheric ethereal keyboards as well as vocals that feel like they have some like echo e-dub effects on them for me this track was like a near jaw-dropping moment but then there are other tracks on here kind of like the song bad habit where it'll start off with a really cool beat but it doesn't really get much more interesting past that the song progresses into this ultra smooth glistening dance pop rock tune that actually feels like maybe it would actually be a Coldplay song if not for all the Pali rhythms going on in the background and again like on the album total life forever folds just continue to abuse reverb to the point where it just sucks the meat it sucks the energy out of their instrumentation and when they explode on a chorus it just has no bite whatsoever kind of like many of the courses on that last Maccabees LP I kind of feel the same way about the song late night too which is a cool track has some Radiohead esque vocal melodies it's got a really dark vibe to a kind of nocturnal but again those dance beats really kind of keep foals from reaching as high emotionally as the song could potentially go these tracks that I sort of mentioned negatively so far are even really the worst moments to me they don't so much ruin the album to me these tracks are just ok they're tolerable there are just more unbearable moments than this in my opinion like the song milk and black spiders which on this track the mixing is terrible I don't even know how it ended up on this LP mix wise it sounds way different than any other song on the album the reverb just swallows up every single instrument on here and all I can hear just the bad strings tossed all over the track it sounds like a really lackluster live recording of somebody kind of holding a microphone way back like thousands of people are between them and the stage and they're kind of holding their iPhone in the air just taking a recording of the band performing and the preload on this thing the intro track the boring chord progression and the and the guitar leads and the heavy distorted riff that comes in after it just sounds like one big post-rock nightmare when I listen to total life forever I didn't like it I still don't like it but now I kind of feel like I I know what the band is going for foals intentions on holy fire are a little bit clearer and you know it would seem that they want to make dance music they want to make dance rock and dance pop but they want it to have this delicate subtle kind of Flowery aura about it the concept is great but I feel like the band is yet to find a way to combine these two elements without water in each of them down with the other the dance beats don't feel is hard they don't move me they don't feel as exciting and on the other end these flowery moments that they go for feel kind of bogged down feel boring they don't feel emotionally powerful because they're kind of locked into these dance grooves instead of flowing beautifully like something subtle should I feel like that's kind of made apparent especially on the last two tracks where the band seems to ditch the dance beats a little bit or mix them down hi everyone Anthony Fantana here the Internet's busiest music nerd and it's time for a review of the new Veronica falls album waiting for something to happen Veronica Falls is a nice little pop outfit from the UK their debut LP caught my attention back in 2011 despite the the band's style pretty breezy pretty light but I found Veronica Falls music to be more like a breeze in the midst of January with kind of a frosty bite to it just the perfect amount of reverb on the guitars that they were playing they had a nice 20 tone to them some very ambitious and chilly boy/girl vocal harmonies and on top of that just a touch of English Reservation plus I was impressed with the influences that these guys were able to pull together not only were there some sounds coming from that old jangle pop style maybe a little bit of old-school Indian garage rock but there were definitely some moments that reminded me of The Velvet Underground The Mamas and the Papas the songs on this LP were straightforward and featured a lot of earworm choruses and some of the tracks came off maybe a little sour kind of morbid like the song love in a graveyard or the track that found him there were tracks like beachy head as well which were pretty noisy kind of abrasive and even though I really liked what Veronica Falls had to offer on this new LP I wasn't really sure if these guys had the the will or the drive or the chops to progress what they were doing here further I guess what I ended up expecting with this new LP was just not that much change at all just another heap of tracks that were endearing but also kind of sour and dark at times too I'm not even really sure if I got that to me the very chilly and wintry feel of the debut album is gone the morbid feel of the debut album has kind of disappeared as well and the noisier and in stranger moments like bleachy II don't really seem to be on here as well I feel like Veronica Falls has kind of stripped away all of these elements that I feel I gave them character and have settled down a little bit into this kind of one modulus style that is pretty much some quaint polite indie rock and pop with youthful boy/girl vocal harmonies I'm not really trying to sell this record as a complete departure or anything like that though Veronica Falls still sounds like Veronica Falls I just feel like they've kind of pruned the tree a little bit and have tried to drum together a collection of songs that are just a bit more uniform I suppose and I could appreciate that a band would want to make an album that feels a little bit more focused but I don't really think Veronica Falls was all that adventurous to begin with I mean if anything was going to make their next LP exciting it should have been more adventure because there are moments on this LP where the lack of adventure sonically and and when it comes to songwriting too can get pretty disheartening like the songs teenage waiting for something to happen and everybody is changing where you have moments like what's your Excuse baby there's so many moments on this record where I kind of feel like Veronica Falls is recycling chord progressions and the melodies over them feel so similar that I feel like I could sing the melody from one song over another song the only difference between a lot of these tracks is that these chord progressions are kind of worked out in two different keys don't get me wrong I still like a lot of these tunes I feel like Veronica Falls still brings that really cool energy especially on a track like teenage there are just too many songs on this record to me that sort of mirror each other in ways that make me maybe slightly annoyed or just kind of bored however there are moments on this record where Veronica Falls does try to push themselves outside of their comfort zone a little bit and add some extra bits of personality but maybe with not as much success as on their debut like the song shooting star which is one of the most quiet moments on this entire LP it kind of romps around very softly very slowly but it feels kind of drab and boring to me on my heart beats that was one of the first big singles to drop from this new LP and one of my favorite moments on here the song really propels itself really pushes itself has a nice driving beat to it and the guitars just sound so big it's really one of the bigger tracks that Veronica Falls has ever put together sure some of the lyrics on this track of kind of corny about dreaming together and so on and so forth but that sweet sentiment is is still there and still feeling very sincere and still feeling very real and it kind of you know in my opinion gives the song a pass because I get kind of sucked into this very for me anyway very real emotion the song everybody is changing I love the sentiment to that track to which kind of seems to be talking about looking back on your past your youth even though the songwriting melody wise and chord wise is very basic it's very simple the message behind the song which is about just kind of accepting change in your personal life I mean it just it's kind of close to home for me not to say that a message necessarily makes a song but a band has to have a certain kind of personality and sincerity to make a message like this go over well and that's a kind of power that Veronica Falls has and the song falling out is one of the softer ones on here I think goes over really well and has some of the better lyrics on the entire LP talking about how every seed is a flower every seconds an hour it's songs like these that have some pretty good lyrics a fresher energy to them to actually feel new to me when it comes to Veronica Falls writing new new material in a lot of ways I kind of feel like this sophomore album is again a homogenized version of their debut LP and and I wished that on this album instead they spread out a little bit more and even though I am let down by the subtraction of variety slightly on this new album I do think Veronica Falls for the most part wrote some decent songs in their usual style again it's just straightforward lean clean jangle pop whose appeal is very apparent from first listen I'm feeling a strong six on this new LP if you've given it a listen what did you think of it did you love it did you hate it why and what do you think I should review next anthony Fantana Veronica Falls forever

hi everyone Anthony Fantan oh here it's time for a review yeah on the modal Orchestra to unknown Mortal orchestra is a low fee psychedelic pop and rock outfit whose debut LP was reviewed here a few years ago I was pretty on the fence with it I wasn't as hot on it as other people for a number of reasons there were a lot of tracks on there that felt just shockingly short kind of underdeveloped a very sort of flat lo-fi production that didn't have a lot of detail or character to it really kind of got old by the end of the album which overall was pretty short of breath just like the songs on it however there were things to this band style in their sound that I liked a lot like they're very kind of beefy funky and sometimes hip-hop influenced I thought drum beats as well as some pretty flashy guitar playing - those two things came together really well on the track funny friends and the band had a great single with the track how can you love me - so there definitely was this glimmer of light and talent add me crossing my fingers that I would enjoy this new LP more and I'm actually happy to say that I do feel that this LP for unknown mortal Orchestra shows improvement their ambition shows on this album it's a longer record longer tracks they stick mostly to their - they're still there lo-fi sound but bring a more diverse palette of psychedelic flavors and sounds I guess the most obvious downside on some of these tracks though is that the mix and the recording can be off maybe the loaf I thing isn't isn't their best friend sometimes because there are some tracks here where the drums feel almost non-existent with how much they're turned down maybe they were recorded in sort of a strange way maybe just with one microphone I mean really that's how it feels like with how below they are the guitars and the bass which really kind of makes me miss how beefed-up they were on some tracks from the debut they sometimes brought a very funky character to their debut LP that I liked a lot unknown Mortal orchestra still manages to bring more for the listener on this LP though more sound more melody more personality it's a bit of a change in character that might not appeal to hardcore fans of the debut LP because while that album does have psychedelic characteristics there's also kind of a cute quaintness to it sort of a bubblegum flavor on a lot of spots with number two instead things are not feeling as sugary they're not feeling as bubblegum they're feeling kind of mature sort of soulful especially in the vocals mainly on tracks like the seven-minute song monkey which is really kind of slow-moving chilled out it might be my favorite song on here I mean it really feels like this vintage blend of psychedelic rock and funk sort of strange but undeniable with its grooves and sort of a new thing for me on here as well as there's a very prevalent Beatles influence on a few moments here especially the opening track on this album which I didn't feel was as strong on the debut not so strong that it would sort of bang me over the head as being Beatles Beatles Beatles the cadence and just the resonance of the vocal harmonies and just the quality of the vocal recording with the microphones that are being used and the way that the vocals are equalized I mean all these things just say Beatles to me on this opening track and these vocals are clashed with some beautiful just almost breathtaking guitar work the track has a great start it has a great middle but then it starts to sort of flounder at the end kind of fading out for quite a long time and I guess from the man during in the process again the band kind of presents material that feels kind of unfinished or just material that feels like the end wasn't really thought of or cared about I kind of feel the same way about the track so good at being in trouble which again has a great start but sort of ends up meandering around the middle because there are a lot of Peaks or anything in the song it's very chilled out and then it just so nonchalantly ends but despite some abruptness I'm still finding some beauty in these tracks the song swim and sleep like a shark has this kind of spectral vocal to it that has this sort of a throaty whisper quality to it that's kind of haunting and the guitar chords and the arpeggios on this track are just played and executed this really whimsical way I mean just flawless the way that they're sort of dancing so nimbly across this very tick-tock drum b is wonderful the song one at a time is another short track it's really well executed fun squawking guitar chords shots of horns really bright really flamboyant the most bombastic song in the entire LP I think but again the song kind of ends abruptly I guess I just can't understand why they take tracks like this and make them so short and yet drag out songs like the opposite of afternoon which I mean it's got some nice playing in it but the way the band is performing the song it feels like they're trying not to wake the neighbors or something songs like this really kind of make me feel like the band brought back that sort of refreshing first-timer attitude that they had on their debut you know I feel like this LP overall is interesting I can put it on and be engaged throughout the entire thing there's some very impressive playing occasionally it's beautiful but rarely is it exciting I guess one of the few moments where I feel like that happens is the song faded in the morning it just has this mean psychedelic rock groove to it and when the vocals pop in they are sung in falsetto and it's really fiery passionate falsetto and I love the way the guitar sort of just follows what the vocal is doing melodically so technically in the background it's just this extra layer of Anthony Fantana Internet's busiest music here but the needled rep hi everyone it's time for a review thanks for watching Dumbo gets mad quantum leap Dumbo gets mad is a psychedelic pop project that originates from Italy you may remember from a few years ago through the album elephants at the door not only were there some really awesome influences coming from what fell like schmaltzy corny organ pop music as well as gorillas Flaming Lips psychedelic rock garage rock dance music - because there's some awesome hip shaking beats on this album and I like that even though this album could also be very dense and overwhelming sonically it never really quite lost view of its pop sensibility now this is Dumbo gets Mads sophomore full-length LP quantum leap and of course because I liked the debut so much and was so impressed with how awesome it was that or at least the project was right out of the gate I mean I guess I expected a lot from this I mean I guess in a way I was looking for a more consistent full-length LP one that was showcasing some better production maybe a more potent style maybe Dumbo gets mad could develop I guess sort of way to make itself as a psychedelic project stick out past the ranks of other psychedelic music projects out there right now for psychedelic music Dumbo gets mad is extremely playful and at times I would say on this LP even bordering on absurd with all sorts of zany crazy falsetto vocals that that don't really feel like they're worried about how they sound execution-wise at all just sort of getting this crazy vibe coming from them seems to be the most important thing at times the instrumentation feels a little goofy slap bass lines multi organ sounds and a lot of the drum breaks and sequences on this LP are extremely extremely funky I would say even funkier than the last album I mean if you loved a lot of the on the tracks from elephants at the door quantum leap definitely brings that attitude even more like the song American day which to me has one of the better courses on this entire LP with American day just like any other one it's it's a catchy hook the song also has this awesome bass part where kind of feels like it's in this constant state of soloing and I love the ascending climax at the end of the track it's a big finish but the vocals that are kind of swirling just I guess sort of swimming backstroking through all of this atmosphere are just in my opinion kind of ridiculous they sound obscured as if they were I guess sort of meant to be hidden because they're not all that well performed which I guess I can understand because vocals have never really been the strongest weapon in DUMBO get smads arsenal but I still like the sounds on that track but I love the sounds on the track South Africa even more there's a really boomy drum break that kicks this song off there's a harp at the beginning a jazz flute like some of the great moments from Dumbo gets Mads debut LP this song just feels like swimming thousands of leagues underwater in a sea of Hawaiian Punch the project gets a little more diverse with tracks like Indian food which has this sweet sharp Indian melody coming through on what feels like I don't know like a fiddle or like some kind of reed instrument though that's really the only Indian thing about the entire track there's this awesomely soulful vocal that kind of leads the song way more soulful that I'm usually used to hearing from Dumbo gets mad of course a really awesome funky drum break is paired with this track the diversity continues with the track male ducat oh hope I'm pronouncing that correctly it's a bit of Spanish guitar with bongos vibraphone it's really one of the most instrumentally striking moments that Dumbo gets mad has pulled together on this entire LP it's so beautiful I wonder why there aren't more moments like this on the entire album because so many of the tracks on here just come together in such a cacophonous way that I guess it sort of feels a little bland or uneventful after a while because Dumbo gets mad isn't a full band and is really just kind of a studio project a lot of these jams that the song was venture on kind of lose their momentum and lose their flavor after a while because you're not really hearing this you know live instrumentation interaction or anything like that it just kind of feels like maybe a slightly missed opportunity for Dumbo gets mad to have all these tracks that kind of lose their flavor after a little while when there's this one song on here under the two-minute mark that is so impressive and shows this extreme knack for being able to orchestrate orchestration isn't really the goal on a lot of these tracks I guess Dumbo gets mad is kind of content to maybe just kind of throw those guitars and cents out there along with a drum break and just kind of let the chips fall where they may with a little bit of experimentation here and there like on the track Tahiti hungry jungle which has you know rapping on it due to the fact that it is in Azealia Banks medley and the rapping is you know a little weak a bit ridiculous at times though it does kind of work there is this very like the title would suggest jungle esque garage rock rapping beat in the background kind of giving things that Amazonian feel but the song is kind of back ended with this really sort of weak messy guitar solo that does nothing for me the song Bom Bom has this awesomely kind of Japanese pop sort of feel to it mixed together with Dumbo gets Matt's typical watery psychedelic poppy sound that is is actually really pleasing to the ear the song cougar is one of the zaniest on here and has this weird slap bass line really sharp guitars it's not really my favorite track out here because it meanders like a lot of others on here and has goofy vocals but strangely enough it kind of reminds me of like this stylistic crossroads of the b-52s female post-punk outfits like delta v but then on top of that there's all sorts of weird chipmunk vocals in there along with Dumbo gets mad as usual psychedelic pop stylings like that song Dumbo gets mad does a really great job of pulling together a sound pulling together a vibe but the songwriting is maybe a little too repetitive or basic or maybe the chorus and the don't really have that much of a difference between one another and it kind of makes me feel a little let down in a way songs like before kiddos death which has a strong sort of surf rock vibe to it or the house of love or the closing track down here punch and T unfortunately I was really just kind of feeling like this album was a mixed bag for me there were a handful of tracks on here that I thought were fantastic a few others that I felt like kind of fell into place with something very kind of comfortable and and safe for Dumbo gets mad and then there are songs where Dumbo gets mad takes some real risks tries to experiment but it just doesn't end up appealing to me because it seems so I guess weakly executed that it just makes me cringe a little bit I don't necessarily feel disheartened because I feel like Dumbo gets mad certainly put it all into this album and made the sincere effort to diversify the sound of this project has going which so many artists to have a successful debut album kind of forget to do I'm feeling a light six to a decent I'm feeling a light decent six on this LP if you've given it a listen what did you think of it did you love it did you hate it why and what do you think I should review next anthony Fantana Dumbo gets mad forever

hi everyone Anthony Fantan oh here the Internet's busiest music nerd and it's time for a review tomahawk Oddfellows tomahawk is an experimental and alternative rock band this is their new full-length LP and the band started as a collaborative effort between Dwayne Denison of the band the Jesus lizard and fantastic multi-talented vocalist my pen vocal phenom really as well as Trevor Dunn who has also worked with Mike Patton and groups such as mr. bungle and who some of you may remember as playing upright bass on quite a few tracks off that new Melvin's album and something I didn't even realize until this review because I'm a complete fool it is actually that this band features the drummer from helmet and battles so I mean because of all this experience and all the numerous groups that all of these people have taken part in over the years I mean this is just not tomahawks 4th full-length album but really a group of guys with just years and years and years of rock and experimental rock experience coming together to create a full-length LP between these four guys there are just too many different bands and projects to count and some of them completely different than others I mean dudes like Mike Patton versatility is pretty much their calling card not to mention the fact that this band's last LP had some really strong Native American music influences however on this new LP tomahawk seems to kind of abandon what they did on the LP anonymous they go back to their experimental and alternative rock ways but maybe with a slightly catchy or edge on some tracks I mean so catchy and straightforward I actually kind of feel like I'm listening to what potentially could have been a Faith No More single back in the day mainly with tracks such as stone letter but of course that is just kind of one side of this new album being a Patton fronted project it should be assumed that this record overall is is pretty versatile and jumps all over the place stylistically and emotionally all over this LP there are different singing styles levels of weirdness songwriting approaches as if the album title were like a reference to what these 13 songs feel like as a group but odd fellow still is not really the weirdest album that you're ever going to run across I mean even at weirdest tomahawk is able to kind of keep all of the tracks on this album around the two to four minute mark now even though alternative rock is not the most shocking adventurous or exciting of genres I feel like tomahawk makes a pretty convincing argument for the exact opposite they are able to sort of adventure outside of the box on a lot of tracks here but still stick to alternative rocks modern catchy hooks and riffs the opening track on here Odd Fellows has this 7/8 timing on the verse with this really awesome kind of heavy weird just odd guitar riff that is sort of iced with these really spooky grimy vocals from Mike Patton but once the band kicks into the chorus the vocals start kind of soaring this very close harmony that I think an Allison chains fan would really appreciate the tracks tone letter is kind of like a slightly sped up piece of arena rock without this really huge sense of grandiosity but still very melodic I could see members of the band back-to-back singing into the microphone and unison on this one but Mike Patton brings that weirdness and by having kind of this strange raspy 'no stew his voice over the verses it's a nice contrast the song southpaw goes down the same Road but maybe is a little bit on the corny er side especially with the lyrics and is kind of my least favorite track on this LP as a result the song IOU quietly builds in intensity and in harmony with these really awesome guitar leads the song itself feels you know sort of strange tortured but the atmosphere the reverb thrown on this track sort of brings it to a another level of cavernous sadness the song a thousand eyes comes on slow as well and it just sort of you know hit me especially on this song sometimes tomahawk is just really really great at sort of building that intensity in in a slower moment I love the pace that these guys are able to work at but still kind of keep the track engaging and of course their spots on this LP where Mike Patton kind of steals the show like on the song white hats black hats where his just gravelly voice which he kind of pulls out specifically for this track and maybe another one on here too sounds maniacal and and in a way kind of cartoony but sort of villainous as well but as far as just major downsides overall for this LP I think this album after numerous listens kind of exposed itself to me to be incredibly incredibly front-loaded I mean really in my opinion the most exciting tracks and pretty much all the new ground I guess for tomahawk is broken on the first half of the album on the other half the album you have songs that are either maybe a bit shorter kind of rehashing ideas that were earlier on the album or in some cases featured in other projects that these band members are in in my opinion these song baby let's play is just I mean really underwhelming the way that it just me Anders I mean really it's kind of like staring at dust flow through this beam of sunlight coming down from the window you notice it and it's kind of you know beautiful the way things kind of hang in the balance and that beam of light but still it gets kind of you know after a while and the closing track on here is this kind of weird blend of hard rock and and surf rock with vocals from Mike Patton really this is the only part in the entire album where I actually find his singing to be sort of borderline obnoxious I mean it feels kind of tagged on to the end of the LP because it doesn't really feel like it would flow into any other song here Odd Fellows is definitely one of Tomahawks more diverse efforts but they're just some songs on here that don't reach that experimental or adventurous level that I've always heard from these guys I'm feeling a strong six to a light seven on this album if you've given it a listen did you love it did you hate it why and what do you think I should review next Anthony Fantana tomahawk forever

hi everyone Anthony Fantino here the Internet's busiest music nerd and it's time for a review of the new self-titled California x record these guys are Massachusetts trio this is their debut album and on this LP they are laying the foundation for what I hope is a very loud and catchy rock and roll career these guys are an alternative rock and an indie rock band with an overall just kind of fuzzy sound in the production buzzsaw guitars and thick base hard heavy freakin drums and just like a whole lot of attitude punk garage garage punk and maybe just like a little bit of shoegaze and noise rock wiggle their way into many tracks on this LP kind of like the band's the men as well as the van yuck these guys kind of create this Frankenstein monster of an album that's kind of an amalgamation of all these groups that they really really love from the late 80s to mid 90s groups like dinosaur jr. Sonic Youth but I think some more modern comparisons that may sit well with people are guys like Jay Reatard for example and there are moments where songs on this help you really really kind of feel like I'm listening to waves but way way way less obnoxious it is kind of noisy and distorted it does have kind of a strong indie rock vibe even when they go on a longer journey here with a song with some sort of stoner rock s kriffing and there's actually quite a bit of heaviness just like this overbearing quality to the guitars that I love a lot I mean this album just pummels you with these guitars like I said I mean it does kind of feel like stoner rock but with a sort of punk bluntness to it no pun intended there however if you are looking for something bold experimental or challenging you might just want to look elsewhere I mean pretty much everything on this LP is just no  the song spirit world has this swinging rock and roll riff that sounds like something Chuck Berry would have played back in the day it's clashed with these blaring fiery guitar leads that sound like they're being data this tube amplifier turned all the way up it's got a lot of energy to it but just the lack of adventure on so many of these tracks in terms of the chord progressions and just the riffs that the guitars are playing it does kind of lead to a somewhat lackluster album because there aren't really any surprises there isn't really much I can say that the band is doing that is sort of distinct to this record for example the songs pond raw and mummy I mean the riffs and corporations on those tracks I mean I just kind of feel like they're sort of a dime a dozen with the riffs on this LP there's a lot of major second intervals a lot of syncopated guitar and drum hits that segue one section of the song to another and and for sure the band's guitar leads I mean they scream out like they're the most significant thing going on in music right now so the energy and the desire are there to the point where you know California X is is pretty I guess you could say convincing it's just stuff like the lack of adventure with the writing or even the vocals too which do very very little to kind of pull this album out of this somewhat generic slump or like a commonplace funk sort of like that Mets album that I dug last year this album sort of feels held back by the fact that the vocals aren't really stepping up they're not really coming forward and either delivering a voice that is memorable or somewhat interesting but they're not really saying much in terms of I guess sort of gripping or catchy lyrics either they just sort of hang awkwardly in the back of all the instrumentation as if they're like afraid to ruin the vibe of what California X is trying to do guitar wise anyway you know if the songs had a little more detail to them in terms of structure some more adventurous vocals less sort of melodic or riff cliches I mean this could be a really great album because the production is there the performance and the playing is there certainly California ex seems focused when it comes to just making a really freakin hard hitting rock album it just sort of needs that spice to kind of give it some replay value and just kind of give it some some nooks and crannies to dive into to really kind of bring it to the next level in my opinion feelin aight decent too strong six on this LP if you've given it a listen what did you think of it did you love it did you hate it why and what do you think I should review next Anthony Fantan Oh California x forever

Julian Casablancas best vocal cut that I've ever heard on one of his songs I mean I feel like even someone who likes this track and admit that the mix on his vocal is really not that good it's buried
