hi everyone Anthony Fantan oh here the Internet's busiest music nerd and it's time for a review local natives hummingbird local natives is a Silver Lake band and this is their sophomore full-length LP and help them that I was maybe a little apprehensive to get into because of just how lukewarm I was on their debut full-length a few years ago which did definitely definitely feel like a debut album in the sense that you have a group of guys who have created a band that feels so steeped in its influences that it's really difficult to separate the group themselves from what music inspires them because no matter how many times I really gave a listen to gorilla Manor I couldn't really figure out what this band was about outside of the artists that they kind of channels so well through their tracks their moments and local natives music where you might catch a bit of the eccentricity of Talking Heads a lot of moments where you hear the vocal harmonies of a group like Fleet Foxes sometimes the vocal harmonies and the experimental folk tendencies of a group like grizzly bear pop up as well and sometimes local natives are able to effectively channel the ambitious baroque instrumentation of Arcade Fire too but outside of a few blog Abel singles from gorilla Manor like the song Sun hands nothing really about that album stuck with me through 2010 and 2011 however for a lot of people local natives have resonated and that's not really that big of a surprise because the music that they're inspired by the artists they're inspired by have made some of the most popular indie rock folk and pop of the past ten years and when music fans typically come across an artist that they love and maybe they haven't really gotten their fill they seek out more music that sounds like that through either the genres that that music is boxed into or just similar sounding artists I'm not saying the local natives is necessarily riding the coattails of any one group but for sure they did not invent the sounds that they are toying with I mean they're more of a product of the environment that they're thriving in musically and I guess the twist that they put on a lot the artists that inspire them is that the music in terms of its appeal and its its beauty is pretty obvious right from the get-go especially on this new sophomore release that has a much slicker production value especially on tracks where you're getting a lot of atmospheric instrumentation and a little Radiohead esque falsetto singing - I guess what I'm getting at is that no matter how many times I listen back to local natives their music just does not not not move me clearly the band has a lot of musical talent whether it comes to technical ability or writing because they're able to copycat this close these great contemporary artists I just for the life of me cannot shake this very overwhelming sense of just lack of imagination an album that's unmemorable an album that's just uninvent Eurus I don't question the band's passion for the blueprint that they're working from but for me just the lack of surprises on this LP is depressing really for me style and sound and production as it impacts those other two things are my biggest issues on this album like the band's last LP either a few catchy standouts I suppose the instrumentation is fine the vocal harmonies are nice it just all kind of wears me down as I travel through the entire LP because I mean there's just really nothing I guess sort of unique to the band on this LP and in my opinion I'm feeling a strong five to a light six on this thing if you've given it a listen what did you think of it did you love it hate it why what do you think I should review next and and that's it thanks for watching Anthony Fantan au local natives forever you

hi hi everyone Anthony Fantana here the Internet's busiest music nerd and it's time for a review yeah Buchan case general dome you can gaze is a musical duo from New York I believe this is their second full-length LP and I will most sure for certainly definitely yeah be the first to admit that for quite a while I mean I guess since their debut LP I've always kind of dismissed this project not publicly but you know sort of personally thinking that maybe they were a little too enthralled with their homemade instruments to the point where they would name their musical project after them that sort of thing just kind of screams the word gimmick to me and despite the fact that they may have been able to conjure some semi unique sounds with the instruments that they made you know ultimately the question comes up is there as much attention being paid toward the music and the songwriting that was my perception that was sort of my attitude toward their first album but I gave this new LP of there's an honest-to-god shot and was pleasantly surprised because I think what I ended up finding on this LP was a lot of improvement and just a lot of appeal for one the production the sound the overall sound recording on this LP is is loads better no longer does buchen case sound I guess as tattered and sort of worn as their homemade setup is kind of strung together with maybe a little bit of tape some screws and some daisy-chained effects pedals and what's kind of come through in the process of maybe me giving them a better try and just hearing a better recording is that these guys have essentially kind of revealed themselves as being a pretty unique and interesting noise pop project they just have this really strong sense of eccentricity a penchant for kind of very strange angular melodies a lot like Deerhoof maybe not in the same exact way but the way that they write melodies the way they just come out so sharp there are also moments where just the tone and the dissonance and just the strain the chaos kind of reminds me of like Mika Chu in the shapes without the British swagger or sort of post-punk influence and there are other moments on here where I'm sort of feeling a really strong Dirty Projectors kind of vibe coming especially from the guitar riffs and and lines and melodies there isn't really kind of that virtuous flash from the playing that you would usually get on a Dirty Projectors record but the melodies and just the writing on on this album are no less dizzying and and maze-like buchen cases kind of idiosyncratic approach toward writing melodies and and structuring songs with kind of one phase after another but yet it all kind of comes together in verses and choruses is so damn impenetrable and yet it's so kind of odd and and just sharp sounding overall that I can't help but pay attention to it it is attention demanding beside for maybe like the soft interlude in the middle of contortion and training very little about this LP actually comes off as being smooth one track after another you're getting all these staccato guitar riffs and and leads that sort of hammer away mechanically right underneath Aaron dyers I'll use this word again very sharp sharp feminine voice it's got a nice twang to it I guess not a southern twang but it's like you know got a really kind of it just kind of hangs in this certain pitch range that again a lot like the guitars is just kind of sitting in this register where you can't help but pay attention to it it is like onion freakin normal enig normal which may be annoying to some people especially if they're kind of maybe looking for music that will help them chill out relax this is very much not in that mood to me this new buchen gas LP instead is is more like an imaginative crossroad between sort of like the hard-hitting and just straight rigid sounds of industrial combined with just stomping hollering hootenanny party attitude especially on the track pickup which has all these kind of thumping drums on it a lot of dissonant background guitar plays some Basie and patient guitarrists which are just kind of laying a nice solid rhythmic foundation des have a very kind of grinding just sandpaper rough quality to them you can gaze definitely conjure up a very dense array of sounds for just two people with you know some homemade instruments the title track on this thing is just guitar noises upon guitar noises with ass down on the riff and over that are all these weird leads and just kind of freak outs and when they kind of kick in with these thick scrum cords that are just so freakin dissonant on top of this it's like this downward spiral into just sour tones there are these swaths of just chromatically ascending guitar leaves on the track twisting the lasso of truth which totally earns its freakin title and it just feels like this insanely maniacal take on like circus music however my one issue with the track is that it doesn't really develop past the climax of this one really good musical idea that it presents and there are a few other tracks on here like the closing track two that do kind of feel like that like buchen gates are more interested in kind of doing this weird experiment than they are actually kind of crafting song but most of the time on this album in their own weird little way buchen gates are bringing some catchy melodic weirdly melodic verse chorus verse tracks that kind of sound like an old airplane engine on its last leg topped with guitar leads they're just kind of burn their way into my eardrums mainly on the track hard times now there is a nice sense of variety among these tracks they don't really get that kind of album arc or just sort of an obvious progression or anything like that especially with hi everyone Anthony Fantana here the Internet's busiest music nerd and it's time for a review of the new no such thing record home no no such thing such a thing no such thing is the pseudonym of West Coast electronic music producer Jason Chung a sophomore LP that has been pretty anticipated thanks to the work that Jason put into his semi breakout debut album drift which came out in 2009 now this guy does make electronic music but he's a beat meister as well he's a guy whose productions showcased quite a bit of hip hop influence on many tracks from drift the beats and the grooves are there but there are no MCS on this LP and it's not really a hard-hitting or edgy album either the sounds on here shoot for a much more atmospheric kind of glassy feel especially with the synthesizer work and there's a bit of a glitchy quality to the rhythms and the sense on some songs as well and there are some weird kind of experimental sounds on this thing too like the overuse of compression on some of the beats here which kind of ends up making the kick drums kind of seem like a black hole a sonic black hole that sort of when they hit they suck up every sound around them mm which is sort of a technique I've heard applied by other artists that have made glitch hop and and wonky albums like old Flying Lotus work or like baths other artists from the brain feeder collective and even some chill wave acts like Toro y Moi with the LP causers of this and surprisingly Toro y Moi actually makes a vocal appearance on this new LP and blonde redheads kazuma Tino actually makes a vocal appearance too on the second track here there is definitely evidence of Jason sort of capitalizing on the attention and success that he's had with drift in bringing in these guest artists and even though the successive drift does translate into some interesting collaborations on home the success doesn't really seem to kind of peter out into anything else on this new LP for the this part I guess Jason tries to make home a success merely on the back of his stylistic progression as an artist since the release of drift and he does make a pretty apparent change on this new LP which is kind of a surprise considering just how many people who are fans of hip hop kind of gravitated toward his music as glitch hoppin and wonky were kind of burgeoning genres in 2009 III on this new LP the hip hop influence is here in a few moments but it's not really as strong or as potent as it used to be he's not really fussing around with the distorted bass sounds or just sort of the hip-hop style rhythms and poly rhythms that you would layer on top of each other on track after track and in a way I guess this is a positive because it does make no such thing a little more difficult to quickly compare the Flying Lotus which is sort of an issue that a live artists suffer from in these glitch hop and wonky genres what keeps this album feeling like a project from Jason Chung even though there is sort of a stylistic change is that he is still working with a lot of sort of and being quaint and sort of shy sounds I actually feel a lot of influence from a guy like new trapeze in his productions especially the more hip-hop influenced ones but with a much more electronic direction as opposed to kind of like a jazz influence now this very calming kind of quality to know such things music is consistent throughout this new LP whether he is kind of fooling around and sort of glitchy and familiar territory with the song snap or bringing on guest vocalists or kind of toying a little bit with the sounds and rhythms of to step with a few songs on here most notably the track tell but even so I gotta say I think because of the hip-hop influence just the the stranger and more experimental colors drift is gonna come out the favor for people who have kind of listened up until this point especially since it for a lot of people was the first album from this project that they heard I actually think the lack of a hip-hop vibe on this new LP sort of subtracts what little edge no such thing had so far in the projects short career because a lot of songs on here without these hip-hop beats sort of pulsate along very apathetically and end at very inconspicuous song lengths and just continue with kind of uninspired progressions for sure Jason chung is making a very noticeable embrace of his ambient influences on this LP or at least that's what it kind of feels like I'm tracks like distance which has these tender kind of ringing synth tones murky bass and these reverb synth riffs and with like a little bit of added sound it kind of feels like an electronic ode to an abandoned subway tunnel again it sort of has that quaint quality that I think comes so easily from this projects music but it's not really anything I would replay the song safe shuffles along really serenely it's got a very kind of nocturnal robotic lullaby kind of quality to the synthesizers and with these vocal samples kind of hanging in the background very faintly it's a sweet track but it doesn't really pull that much from me emotionally and the song glue is a little bit more interesting for me rhythmically it's got that future garage kind of feel to it that I said that Jason kind of toys with a little bit on this album along with the song tell and it's sort of as if he wanted his fans to hear this kind of shift in his production style because these songs are noticeably louder than many other tracks here but there are spots on here that do feel familiar for no such thing but I just kind of feel like the sounds weren't crafted to be all that interesting which is surprised because a lot of the sounds were pretty good on drift the tracks snap which has a hip-hop influence to it rhythmically is actually pretty flat and bland when it comes to the sounds of the rhythm the beat is just really kind of colorless I guess and I do not get the sloppily placed high hats and claps on the song try either that just does not do anything for me and beyond that I'm not really sure if I'm feeling the auto-tune vocals of Toro y Moi either overall I'm feeling kind of indifferent on this elf sadly I still like drift and and I still think that album stands as a pretty good release in genre that at the time was making a lot of noise and was an extremely interesting and new and vibrant thing but this new album unfortunately is is pleasant for sure but nowhere near memorable I'm feeling a decent 5 on this LP but if you've given it a listen what did you think of it did you love it did you hate it why and what should I review next Anthony Fantana home forever

hi everyone Anthony Fantino here the Internet's busiest music nerd and it's time for a review villagers away land villagers is the musical project of singer songwriter and guitarist Connor J O'Brien whose music early in the inception of villagers moved me quite a bit in 2009 through the hollow kind EP on the CP it's just a nice handful of downtrodden songs of sadness tracks like the meaning of the ritual and then pieces certainly showcased a huge bright eyes slash Elliott Smith influence they are songs that O'Brien strung together shortly after the demise of his previous band the immediate I hadn't heard anything from the band in a little while and then the announcement came that in 2010 villagers would be signing on with Domino Records and releasing its first full-length LP the album which was eventually dropped was titled becoming a jackal it made it to number one on the Irish indie charts it was Mercury Prize nominated as well but still this full-length didn't really resonate with me in the same way that the EP that preceded it did the production was cleaner a lot of the songs on here were built up with with just slicker instrumentation but I felt like the the overall sound of villagers had become kind of sterile maybe a little neutered kind of predictable especially on reworked versions of older tracks on this new album such as the meaning of the ritual so I was going into this new sophomore LP hoping for more and I definitely feel like I got that for sure O'Brien makes some really clear and obvious attempts to kind of break or move away from that mole that his first album was cast in but the recipe may end up tasting maybe a little funny to people who have been hardcore fans of the very short progression that villager's has undergone so far O'Brien without a doubt is still a very captivating singer/songwriter with lyrics and a lot of emotion and and maybe for many fans that will be all that that truly matters at the end of the day but on this new LP with a lot of songs here there are a lot of electronics running in tandem with the usual mix of guitar bass drums and vocals in addition to the electronics I would say more pianos brass and strings too I think in general villager's is coming off way more ambitious in the studio with this release just take a listen to the hustling and bustling electronic tones at the beginning of the track the waves or the glitchy electronic sequenced percussion on the song earthly pleasure on top of this you're getting a lot of instances of just cascading horn arrangements that that swell and fall lots and lots of effects on some tracks villager's is definitely moving away from its kind of simple and humble beginnings with just a lot of sonic flash and while overall I didn't really end up loving this LP to death I do admire and much more than becoming a jackal not only are the songs really good the production is great but this LP is definitely the sound of a guy trying to just add a little bit of spark to his craft the song the waves which is one of the main promotional tracks that came out before this record and a great one that there's a lot of cute bubbly electronics at the start of this track with some moody guitar and vocals kind of coming up underneath it with some touches of piano as well that are really beautiful it's like all of these synthetic sounds are just sounding really kind of light and airy inand sweet on the ears while everything else is just kind of becoming more and more sour and I love the way that the vocals kind of speed up with intensity in the lyrics the way that they kind of hit rhythmically as O'Brien delivers them and I love the way this track just kind of moves and shifts and builds up from one section to another with just these subtle swells of piano organ and horns just before the chorus kind of kicks in there's a serious flow to the instrumentation all over this album whenever there are some arrangements involved they're so well played and so meticulously crafted as the waves continues the vocals just kind of fall backwards and kind of like a James Blake sort of way into this cavernous mountain of reverb as the electronics kind of get glitchy ER and then noisier it's just really apocalyptic huge ending and I like the way that villagers kind of builds up toward the end of the song The Grateful song that's got a really ambitious ending filled with strings that yeah it's not really the same mood as the previous track that I just mentioned but man is it a thick mood I mean thick with just this kind of uplifting soaring head and the clouds kind of vibe instrumentally at least there are a few other tracks on here that I wish kind of went that far like the introductory track my lighthouse or passing a message both of which I just kind of feel like get cut short and sort of but other tracks on here do a really great job at embracing sort of a sense of simplicity and don't leave me hanging in the hi everyone Anthony Fantino here the Internet's busiest music nerd and it's time for a review Yo La Tengo faid Yo La Tengo is a New Jersey rock trio whose versatility is only matched by their influence between the bands three main members and their 20 or so years of recordings they've actually been able to drop quite a few rock and pop styles everything from garage rock psychedelic rock lo-fi nose pop and rock indie rock dream pop folk music and more and when it comes to you ought n go there is definitely an influence in most sort of noisy off-kilter messy indie rock bands that are out there today of course you could also attribute a lot of this influence to bands such as guided by voices and modest mouse as well as pavement but still Yolo tango I can always count on them to kind of bring a thought-provoking mixed bag of ideas that may not always line up but are surely featuring a few surprisingly inspired left hooks spontaneity and the challenge of spontaneity has been kind of a standard that Yolo tango has held themselves and their fans to for many years whether they are putting together some kind of soundtrack or like a side project such as condo or doing their annual wfm you fun dr.colin radio session cover gauntlet the band's ability to function in numerous musical dimensions has been a selling point of theirs for a long time I would actually say especially on their last few LPS like the very back loaded and sometimes poppy popular songs and the very quirky and yet sometimes awe-inspiringly lovely I am not afraid of you and I will beat your ass however fade is actually surprisingly consistent not a lot of surprise shifts all over this LP and it's pretty soft too I actually don't think yellow tango has put out an album this soft since like 2003 summer fun or to thousands and then nothing turned itself inside out where they actually I guess flirted with some ambient sounds on that LP that may definitely beat out fade in terms of a low volume but I do find fate to be a bit more cohesive but even though the album does feel a little bit more connected song to song it does have its low points like the song stupid things which has all these quietly pulsating drums it's a very dreamy piece of krautrock with these meandering guitar solos that don't really feel like they've got much direction to them IRA comes in singing with his occasionally weak vocals that for some reason on this track don't really come off as charming I don't really find that much to engage with on that track but being very pleasant on the ears gentle maybe sometimes awash in effects these are recurring sonic themes on fade lots of explorative guitars repetitive rhythm instrumentation maybe a few arrangements here and there whether it be strings especially horns and vocals that are either maybe obscure a little bit with effects or just like whisper quiet after you law tango kind of has all of these elements in place with each song it's just kind of a question of whether or not Yolo tango has created something that is beautiful or maybe a little bit boring thankfully over on this LP I'd say it's more the beauty like the opener own which to me is like this really intoxicating repetition rock it's got this really kind of danceable drum circle rock bee buzzing guitar drones catchy mantra lyrics that are as awesome as the first day I heard them and the entire experience gets more and more psychedelic as the song continues on just getting heavier thicker hazy err on the track Cornelia and jane.georgia actually sings lead and she's singing beautifully over these patiently strummed and picked guitars and bass and these guitars get a really nice lift from some horn arrangements that are to me is beautiful really gives the song some body and the final track on here kind of has a similar appeal - there's some shorter sweeter less psychedelic morsels on here like the track is that enough it's kind of got this alt-country bassline shuffling drums some buzzing guitar in the background and nearly with every Yolo tango release there is one track that really sticks out to me is having a very sort of bold Velvet Underground feel to it and I would definitely pick this track as having that quality on fade I will say the song does feel a little bit formless though like a lot of tracks on here can because of the sort of wandering nature of the of the writing and the performance I actually like the track right after a bit more well you better it's way leaner the drum beat is very snappy and the keyboards are just really cute and really pretty on this track too it's just way more instantly enjoyable and straightforward for me there are other tracks on here like I'll be around that I feel like are very pretty on the ears but kind of need to cut the fat I guess a little bit not a lot to kind of bite into after a while as the song draws on extending itself to the five-minute mark and yet there are other songs out here like the song to train the rapper no not the rapper Soul Train two trains which is just about as long and as spacious I love the layers of guitar sound on this track they feel so lighten sort of ambient sleek sexy these swelling guitar courts that might have been played with an ebow or something like that lots of our Peggy O's very atmosphere reverb leads overall fate is actually a really sweet and surprisingly solid album from Yo La Tengo in this I guess sort of latter part of their career again it's one of the more consistent releases that the band has ever had stylistically but still I feel like maybe some new listeners may have a difficult time gravitating to this album because of I guess how soft and quiet on first listen it may be this does to me feel like an album that not hardcore fans but maybe a general fan would be more into because to really appreciate this LP I feel like you might need to be a little bit more familiar Yola tangos louder and then sometimes noisier side as well so again I will say the fade is solid it's sweet its pleasant and what I like so much about is that it has the beauty the detail and the emotion that sometimes just simply Capital steez blew up with respective tapes and singles like 1999 and American corruption which just kind of exemplified that blueprint East Coast hardcore hip hop sound which there has kind of been a Called Quest biggie organized confusion Black Moon as well I mean the list could really kind of go on forever progressive era pretty much takes what they feel are the best elements of a lot of these artist styles and just brings them all together into one young up-and-coming New York hip hop supergroup and they also take some cues from modern purveyors of sort of the boom bap or old-school styles such as Stones Throw Records artists like mad lib and doom as well a lot of the cultural references and the lyrics of course are modern though the production is still pretty old-school maybe a little less stripped-down than a beat you would normally hear in the 90s simply because of the ease at which you can throw detail into a newer beat with modern technology digital audio washer and samplers as
